dc:dc.dc:creator: Volpi, Guido
dc:dc.dc:title: A Fast Hardware Tracker for the ATLAS Trigger System
dc:dc.dc:subject: Detectors and Experimental Techniques
dc:dc.dc:description: As the LHC luminosity is ramped up to 3×1034 cm−2 s−1 and beyond, the high rates, multiplicities, and energies of particles seen by the detectors will pose a unique challenge. The current three-level trigger is designed to allow a rate reduction from 40 MHz to about 400 Hz. The Fast Tracker (FTK) is an approved upgrade to the current ATLAS trigger system that will operate at full Level-1 output rates and provide high-quality tracks reconstructed in the entire inner detector by the start of processing in the Level-2 Trigger. This will allow to select signals with high purity selection and reject efficiently fakes from QCD background and therefore will free time in Level-2 farm for more refined selections. FTK solves the combinatorial challenge inherent to tracking by exploiting the massive parallelism of associative memories that can compare inner detector hits to millions of pre-calculated patterns simultaneously. The tracking problem within matched patterns is further simplified by using pre-computed linearized fitting constants and relying on fast DSPs in modern commercial FPGAs. Overall, FTK is able to compute the helix parameters for all tracks in an event and apply quality cuts in less than 100 μs. The system design is defined and the performance presented with respect to high transverse momentum (high-pT) Level-2 objects: b jets, tau jets, and isolated leptons.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Borodin, Mikhail
De, Kaushik
Garc\xc3\xada Navarro, Jos\xc3\xa9 Enrique
Golubkov, Dmitry
Klimentov, Alexei
Maeno, Tadashi
South, David
Vaniachine, Alexandre
dc:dc.dc:title: Unified system for processing real and simulated data in the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The physics goals of the next Large Hadron Collider run include high precision tests of the Standard Model and searches for new physics. These goals “at the Gates of Nature” require detailed comparison of data with computational models simulating the expected data behavior. To highlight the role which modeling and simulation plays in future scientific discovery, we report on use cases and experience with a unified system built to process both real and simulated data of growing volume and variety.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: DAMDID Full Paper submission deadline is April 30.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kaplan, Benjamin
Haas, Andy
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Higgs bosons decaying to $aa$ in the $\mu\mu\tau\tau$ final state in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = $8 TeV with the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the the decay to a pair of new particles of either the Standard-Model-like Higgs boson ($h$), or a second CP-even Higgs boson ($H$) is presented. The dataset used is 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $\sqrt{s}=$ 8 TeV $pp$ collisions recorded by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC in 2012. The search was done in the context of the next-to-minimal supersymmetric standard model, in which the new particles are the lightest neutral pseudoscalar Higgs bosons ($a$). One of the two $a$ bosons is required to decay to two muons while the other is required to decay to two $\tau$-leptons. No significant excess is observed above the expected backgrounds in the $m_\mu\mu$ range from 3.7 GeV to 50 GeV. Upper limits are placed on the production of $h\rightarrow{aa}$ relative to the Standard Model $gg\rightarrow{h}$ production, assuming no coupling of the $a$ boson to quarks. The most stringent limit is placed at 3.5 % for $m_a = 3.75$ GeV. Upper limits are also placed on the production rate of $H\rightarrow{aa}$ from 2.33 pb to 0.72 pb, for fixed $m_a = 5$ GeV with $m_H$ ranging from 100 GeV to 500 GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hawkings, Richard
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of lepton differential distributions in $t\bar{t}$ production in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using $e\mu$ events with $b$-tagged jets
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes measurements of the differential distributions of leptons and lepton paris produced in dileptonic $t\bar{t}$ events with an opposite sign $e\mu$ pair, using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV recorded with the ATLAS detector at the LHC. The events were selected using the leptons, and jets tagged as being likely to originate from $b$-quarks using the MV1 tagging algorithm. Absolute and normalised differential cross-sections were measured as a function of single lepton transverse momentum and rapidity, the difference in azimuthal angles of the two leptons, and various kinematic variables related to the dilepton system. The results are compared to the predictions of various $t\bar{t}$ Monte Carlo event generators.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Lister, Alison
Owen, Mark
Kind, Oliver
Costa, Maria Jose
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS and CMS summary plot for single top production cross section (TopLHCWG)
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Summary of the ATLAS and CMS measurements of the single top production cross-sections in the t-, s- and Wt-channels as a function of center of mass energy. For the s-channel only an upper limit is shown. The measurements are compared to theoretical calculations based on: NLO QCD, NLO QCD complemented with NNLL resummation and NNLO QCD (t-channel only).

Schott, Matthias
dc:dc.dc:title: Summary Report on the Expected Impact of a Large Eta Detector in ATLAS on Standard Model Physics Analyses
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The extension and upgrade of ATLAS sub-detectors (inner tracker system, calorimeters, muon-system) in the forward $\eta$-region between $2.5$ and $4.0$ leads to an improved reconstruction of physics objects and hence leads also to am improvement in physics measurement at the LHC. In this note, we summarize several studies, which estimate the impact of an extended ATLAS detector on physics measurements in the Standard Model group. In particular, the effect of an extend inner tracker system is discussed.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Pleskot, Vojtech
dc:dc.dc:title: Studies of azimuthal decorrelation of dijets with a jet veto with ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Measurements of di-jet systems with a veto on additional jets, probe QCD radiation effects. The two jets in each event with the highest transverse momentum are taken as the dijet system and a rapidity interval is defined as the region in rapidity between the centroids of these two jets. The fraction of dijet events without an additional jet in this rapidity interval and the mean jet multiplicity in the interval are presented as a function of the mean transverse momentum of the dijets and of the rapidity interval size. Correlations between the azimuthal angles of the dijets are studied both with and without a veto on additional jet activity in the rapidity interval between the jets. This study probes different approaches to the resummation of large logarithms when performing QCD calculations.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Dear referee, the document size was restricted to one page by the conference organizers. The conference in question is MPI@LHC 2014. The deadline for proceedings is 16.1.2015. Best regards Vojtech

dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvet, David
dc:dc.dc:title: The Laser calibration of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter during the LHC run 1
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This article describes the Laser calibration system of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter, with details about the stability of its associated readout electronics and about the method developed to compute the calibration constants to correct for the variations of the gain of the calorimeter photomultipliers. The detection and correction of timing mis-configuration of the Tile Calorimeter using the Laser system are also presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The goal is to publish this paper with a Tile list of authors.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Jia, Jiangyong
Mohapatra, Soumya
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the correlation between flow harmonics of different order in lead--lead collisions at $\sqrt{s_{_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$=2.76 Te
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Correlations between the elliptic or triangular flow coefficients, $v_m$ ($m=2$ or 3), and other flow harmonics, $v_n$ for $n=2$ to 5 are measured using 7 $\mu$b$^{-1}$ of Pb+Pb collision data at $\sqrt{s_{_{\mathrm{NN}}}}=2.76$ TeV collected by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC. The $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations are measured as a function of centrality, and, for events within the same centrality interval, also as a function of event ellipticity or triangularity. The $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations for a fixed centrality interval are very different from the correlations as a function of centrality. For events within the same centrality interval, $v_3$ is found to be anti-correlated with $v_2$ and this anti-correlation is compatible with similar anti-correlations between the corresponding eccentricities $\epsilon_2$ and $\epsilon_3$. On the other hand, it is observed that $v_4$ increases strongly with $v_2$, and $v_5$ increases strongly with both $v_2$ and $v_3$. The trend and strength of the $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations for $n=4$ and 5 are found to disagree with $\epsilon_m$-$\epsilon_n$ correlations predicted by initial geometry models. Instead, these correlations are found to be consistent with the combined effects of a linear contribution to $v_n$ and non-linear term that is a function of $v_2^2$ or of $v_2v_3$, as predicted by hydrodynamic models. A simple two-component fit is used to separate these two contributions. The magnitudes of the linear and non-linear contributions to $v_4$ and $v_5$ are found to be consistent with previously measured event-plane correlations.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: This is a paper converted from confnote https://atlas.web.cern.ch/Atlas/GROUPS/PHYSICS/CONFNOTES/ATLAS-CONF-2014-022/

dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS procedures for the approval of physics results
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document provides guidelines and details of the procedures for the preparation and approval of physics results. It describes the roles of all the individuals and groups involved in the approval process, the purpose of the meetings, and gives a step-by-step guide on the procedures. Papers, conference notes and public notes are described.

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for the Standard Model Higgs boson produced in association with top quarks and decaying into $\boldsymbol{b\bar{b}}$ in $\boldsymbol{pp}$ collisions at $\sqrt{\bf s} ~{\bf=}$ $\boldsymbol{8 TeV}$ with the ATLAS detector at the LHC}
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the Standard Model Higgs boson produced in association with a pair of top quarks, $t\bar{t}H$, is presented. The analysis uses 20.3~\ifb~of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8 $ TeV, collected with the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider during 2012. The search is designed for the $H \to b\bar{b}$ decay mode and uses events containing one or two electrons or muons. %or one electron or muon with a hadronically decaying tau. The Higgs boson is assumed to have a mass of 125 GeV. In order to improve the sensitivity of the search, events are categorised according to their jet and $b$-tagged jet multiplicities. A multivariate technique is used to discriminate between signal and background events, which are dominated by $t\bar{t}$+jets production. In the single lepton channel, a matrix element technique is employed. No significant excess of events above the background expectation is found and an observed (expected) 95 % confidence-level limit of 3.4 (2.2) times the Standard Model cross section is obtained. By performing a fit allowing for an arbitrary Higgs boson signal strength, the ratio of the measured signal strength to the Standard Model expectation is found to be $\mu = 1.5 \pm 1.1$.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: paper draft

dc:dc.dc:creator: Grimm, Kathryn
Pagan Griso, Simone
Prokofiev, Kirill
Meloni, Federico
Rudolph, Matthew Scott
Wildauer, Andreas
Yu, David Ren-hwa
Beringer, Juerg
Piacquadio, Giacinto
dc:dc.dc:title: Vertex Reconstruction in Run 1
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This paper presents primary vertex reconstruction methods and performance in proton- proton collision data recorded by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC. Data was taken during 2012 at a center-of-mass energy of √s = 8 TeV. Vertex reconstruction is studies in both data and Monte Carlo simulation by looking at properties such as track multiplicity and track transverse momentum. Vertex reconstruction efficiency and resolution are also presented. The studies are performed both for single vertex interactions and in the presence of multiple particle interactions. It is found that the effects of increased interactions are well understood and modeled effectively.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: For the purpose of ATLAS circulation, this paper has been re-classified as PHYS. The new CDS entry is located here: ATL-COM-PHYS-2016-263 https://cds.cern.ch/record/2140021

dc:dc.dc:creator: Spousta, Martin
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet fragmentation and multijet studies in heavy ion collisions at ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We report on two measurements done by ATLAS in a context of exploring the jet quenching physics at LHC: the jet fragmentation measurement and the measurement of \nearby jet production. Both of these measurements were done using the data collected in 2011 Pb+Pb run providing Pb+Pb collisions at $\sqrt{s_{NN}} = 2.76~$TeV. These measurements are expected to provide an insight into the modifications of jets initiated by partons passing through hot and dense QCD matter created in heavy ion collisions.

dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of beam orbit drifts on 2012 van der Meer calibration
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The orbit drift correction for luminosity calibration in the 2012 van der Meer scans using BCM and LUCID detectors is presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Lundberg, Olof
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for Dark Matter with the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ATLAS is a multi-purpose detector aimed at fully exploiting the discovery potential of the proton-proton collisions at a center of mass energy of 8-14 TeV provided by CERN Large Hadron Collider. It is able to precisely identify and measure the properties of electrons, muons, photons, taus and hadronic jets. Thanks to an excellent hermeticity it is able to infer the production of neutrinos and dark matter particles from conservation of momentum using the missing energy observable. This talk will focus on the results of several dedicated searches for WIMP Dark Matter using the ATLAS detector. Among these searches are the so called "Mono-X" searches looking for signatures with large missing momentum recoiling against a gauge boson. We also present searches for decays of the Higgs boson into invisible states and searches for final states with missing transverse energy and third generation quarks. The results are interpreted in terms of Effective Field Theories as well as Simplified Models, and limits on nucleon-WIMP cross sections are inferred for both spin-dependent and spin-independent scenarios. Finally some prospects for the upcoming LHC Run 2 with collisions at the unprecedented 13-14 TeV center-of-mass energies will be presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: January 25, 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Van Den Wollenberg, Wouter
Kagan, Michael
Thompson, Emily
Zhou, Lei
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the Track-Jet $b$-Tagging Efficiency of the MV1 algorithm in $pp$ Collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using $e\mu$ Dilepton $t\bar{t}$ events
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes a measurement of the $b$-tagging efficiency of the MV1 $b$-tagging algorithm for $R=0.4$ and $R=0.3$ track jets built from inner detector tracks in the complete 2012 ATLAS $pp$ collision dataset at $\sqrt{s} = 8$~\TeV, using dilepton $t\bar{t}$ events with an opposite-sign $e\mu$ pair in the final state. This analysis follows the technique previously used for the calibration of the calorimeter jet $b$-tagging efficiency, and as such uses a tag-and-probe based method to extract an unbiased estimate of the $b$-tagging efficiency using events with exactly two jet. The $b$-tagging efficiency is measured as a function of track jet $p_{T}$ in the range $7 < p_{T} < 250$~\GeV and as a function of $|\eta|$. The Monte Carlo Simulation is found to describe the $b$-tagging efficiency observed in data well. Results of the calibration to correct any differences between the Monte Carlo Simulation and the data in the form of scale factors, derived from the data to Monte Carlo Simulation ratio, are presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Duda, Dominik
Maettig, Peter
Scanlon, Timothy Paul
Piacquadio, Giacinto
Duda, Dominik
dc:dc.dc:title: Calibration of ATLAS $b$-tagging algorithms in dense jet environments
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes the calibration of various ATLAS $b$-tagging algorithms using reconstructed $t\bar{t}$ candidate events in the final state of one charged lepton, missing transverse momentum, and at least four jets, in the ATLAS $\sqrt{s}=8 \TeV$ $pp$ collision data sample. Expanding on previous $b$-tagging calibration studies, the $b$-tagging efficiencies are measured not only as a function of the transverse momentum or the pseudorapidity of the jets, but also as a function of quantities that are sensitive to close-by jet activity. The results measured in data are in good agreement with the predictions from simulation.

dc:dc.dc:title: Re-interpretations and combinations of electroweak limits in 20.3 fb−1 pp collisions at √s = 8 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the total and differential Higgs boson production cross sections using the $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ ^{*}\rightarrow 4\ell$ channels at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the total and differential cross sections of Higgs boson production is performed using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions produced by the Large Hadron Collider at a centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV and recorded by the ATLAS detector. Cross sections measured in the $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^* \rightarrow 4\ell$ decay channels are extrapolated to the inclusive phase space, combined, and compared to state-of-the-art predictions. Differential cross sections are reported as a function of Higgs boson transverse momentum, Higgs boson rapidity, number of jets in the event, and transverse momentum of the leading jet. The total production cross section is determined to be $\sigma_{pp \to H} = 33.0 \pm 5.3 \mathrm{(stat)} \pm 1.5 \mathrm{(sys)}$.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: CDS entry for supporting note: https://cds.cern.ch/record/1757268

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dolezal, Zdenek
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS studies of spectroscopy and B-decays
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ATLAS has a wide programme to study the production cross section and decay properties of particles with beauty, as well as charmonium and bottomonium states. This presentation will cover the latest ATLAS results, including searches for excited b-hadrons, new decay modes of b-hadrons, indirect New Physics searches in rare B-hadron decays, as well as sthe study of mixing and CP violation in the Bs system. We will also review the results in the domain of charmonium production, including J/psi, psi(2s) and chi_c states, associated vector boson + J/psi production and search for hidden-beauty state Xb, the bottomonium counterpart of X(3876) in the Upsilon pi pi channel.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dolezal, Zdenek
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS studies of spectroscopy and B-decays
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ATLAS has a wide programme to study the production cross section and decay properties of particles with beauty, as well as charmonium and bottomonium states. This presentation will cover the latest ATLAS results, including searches for excited b-hadrons, new decay modes of b-hadrons, indirect New Physics searches in rare B-hadron decays, as well as sthe study of mixing and CP violation in the Bs system and parity violating asymmetry parameter alpha_b in Lambda_b -> Lambda J/psi decays. We will also review the results in the domain of charmonium production, including J/psi, psi(2s) and chi_c states, associated vector boson + J/psi production and search for hidden-beauty state Xb, the bottomonium counterpart of X(3876) in the Upsilon pi pi channel.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Rossi, Leonardo Paolo
Gemme, Claudia
Guido, Elisa
Passaggio, Stefano
Favareto, Andrea
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for metastable heavy charged particles with the ATLAS detector in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Many extensions of the Standard Model predict the existence of charged and heavy long-lived particles, such as $R$-hadrons or charginos. These particles, if produced at the Large Hadron Collider, should be moving non-relativistically and are therefore identifiable through the measurement of an anomalously large specific energy loss in the ATLAS pixel detector. Measuring heavy long-lived particles through their track parameters in the vicinity of the interaction vertex allows sensitivity to metastable particles with lifetimes from 0.6 ns to 30 ns. A search for such particles with the ATLAS}detector at the LHC is presented, based on a data sample corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 18.4 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV. No significant deviation from Standard Model background expectation is observed, and lifetime dependent upper limits on $R$-hadrons and chargino production cross sections and masses are set. Gluino $R$-hadrons with 10 ns lifetime and masses up to 1185 GeV are excluded at 95\% confidence level as well as charginos with 15 ns lifetime and masses up to 482 GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cortiana, Giorgio
Nisius, Richard
Compostella, Gabriele
Maier, Andreas Alexander
Balli, Fabrice
Schwindling, Jerome
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the top quark mass in the $t\bar t \to {\rm lepton+jets}$ and $t\bar t \to {\rm di-lepton}$ channels using $\sqrt{s}=7$ TeV ATLAS data: Paper Draft
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The top quark mass was measured in the channels $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{lepton+jets}$ and $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{dilepton}$ ($e, \mu$) based on ATLAS data recorded in 2011. The data were taken at the LHC with a proton--proton centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s}=7$ TeV and correspond to an integrated luminosity of 4.6fb$^{-1}$. The $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{lepton+jets}$ analysis uses a three-dimensional template technique which determines the top quark mass together with a global jet energy scale factor, and a relative $b$-to-light-jet energy scale factor, where the terms $b$-jets and light-jets refer to jets originating from $b$-quarks and $u, d, c, s$-quarks or gluons, respectively. The analysis of the $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{dilepton}$ channel exploits a one-dimensional template method using the $m_{\ell b}$ observable, defined as the average invariant mass of the two lepton+$b$-jet pairs in each event. The top quark mass is measured to be $172.33\pm 0.75(\rm {stat}) \pm 1.02(\rm {syst})$ GeV, and $173.79 \pm 0.54({\rm stat}) \pm 1.30({\rm syst})$ GeV in the $t\bar{t} \to lepton+jets$ and $t\bar{t} \to dilepton$ channels, respectively. The combination of the two results yields $m_{\mathrm top} = 172.99 \pm 0.48({\rm stat}) \pm 0.78({\rm syst})$ GeV, with a total uncertainty of $0.91$ GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kosek, Tomas
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent Results on Hard Probes of the Quark-Gluon Plasma with the ATLAS Experiment at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Jets provide a powerful tool for probing the dynamics of the quark-gluon plasma created in Pb+Pb collisions at the LHC. The modification of high-pT parton showers as they propagate in the quark-gluon plasma, often referred to as "jet quenching", provides insight on the short-distance dynamics of the plasma. Jet quenching has been observed in a variety of single jet, dijet, and photon-jet measurements at the LHC as well as in measurements of modified production of charged-particle These results will be presented along with a survey of results of control measurements in Pb+Pb and p+Pb collisions including electroweak final states.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date is 26 January 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hryn'ova, Tetiana
Fedorko, Woiciech
Hayden, Daniel
Savage, Graham
Berry, Tracey
Solovyev, Victor
Long, Brian Alexander
Tsirintanis, Nikolaos
dc:dc.dc:title: Model-Independent Reinterpretation of the ATLAS 8 TeV Z’->ll and W’->lnu Run 2 results
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Heavy gauge bosons giving sizable signals with Standard Model leptons in the final state can appear in one of two possible multiplets: a) Triplets, which contain a Z' and a W', and have only 2 independent couplings or 2) Singlets, which contain just a Z' particle, and have 5 independent couplings to fermions. This note presents a first attempt to combine existing W'->lnu and Z'->ll 8TeV analysis results and to present the resulting limits in terms of couplings.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Other Authors: Manuel Perez-Victoria and Javier Lizana

dc:dc.dc:creator: Metcalfe, Jessica
Valencic, Nika
Pleier, Marc-Andre
Schnoor, Ulrike
Schott, Matthias
Gumpert, Christian
Vest, Anja Simone
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of an Extended Tracker on Same Sign WW at 14 TeV for HL-LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The impact of an extended tracker in a future upgraded ATLAS detector is evaluated for the process of same-electric-charge $WW$ scattering ($W^\pm W^\pm jj$) at a High-Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) at $\sqrt{s} = 14$ TeV. Pileup suppression and identification of jets and leptons are evaluated for their impact on the significance of the $W^\pm W^\pm jj$ signal. An extension of the forward tracking system from pseudorapidities $|\eta|\le 2.5$ to $|\eta|\le 4.0$ has the potential to improve the significance of the $W^\pm W^\pm jj$ measurement by approximately 80% with mean number of $pp$ interactions per bunch crossing $\langle \mu \rangle$ = 140. The discovery potential for new physics is also evaluated in an effective field theory framework for the anomalous gauge boson coupling parameter $f_{T,1}$.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for invisible decays of the Higgs boson produced in association with a hadronically decaying vector boson in pp collisions at √s = 8 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the Higgs boson decay to invisible (weakly interacting) particles is performed using 20.3 fb-1 of pp collision data at a centre-of-mass energy of 8 TeV recorded by the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider. The process considered is the Higgs boson production in association with a vector boson (W or Z) that decays hadronically, resulting in events of two or more jets with large missing tranverse momentum. No excess of candidates is observed in the data beyond the background expectation. The null result leads to an upper limit of XX at the 95% confidence level on the decay branching ratio of the Higgs boson to invisible particles.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Andreazza, Attilio
Battaglia, Marco
Dao, Valerio
Debenedetti, Chiara
Duffield, Emily Marie
Facini, Gabriel John
Gavrilenko, Igor
Pagan Griso, Simone
Jansky, Roland Wolfgang
Milesi, Marco
Morley, Anthony Keith
Shapiro, Marjorie
Ungaro, Francesca
Zaidan, Remi
dc:dc.dc:title: The Optimization of ATLAS Track Reconstruction in Dense Environments
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents recent changes in the ATLAS track reconstruction chain derived from detailed studies of track reconstruction in dense environments. The cores of high $p_{T}$ jets and $\tau$-leptons are characterized by charged particle distances comparable to the inner detector sensor dimensions. The ambiguity processor stage of the reconstruction chain was over-halled including an improvement of the usage of a NN based approach to identify clusters created by multiple charge particles. Single particle samples are used to demonstrate the alteration in a simple environment. The impact of these changes on tracks in high $p_{T}$ jets are shown to result in more pixel hits on track, a more meaningful split hit definition, and improved track parameter estimation. A 10% increase in b-jet identification for an equal fake rate has been shown.

dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search - Appendices

dc:dc.dc:title: {Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search - Appendices
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves as support for the note ``Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I \wh~search'', holding an extended selection of plots as an Appendix.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: An a posteriori support note for the Run I WH analysis and its paper, focusing on the b-jet energy corrections for the dijet invariant mass distribution. Several potential corrections are also discussed and a recommendation is made for the Run II analysis.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Amaral Coutinho, Yara
Buzatu, Adrian
Nunes De Moura Junior, Natanael
Mullen, Paul
Ravenscroft, Thomas
Robson, Aidan
Seixas, Jose
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves both as \emph{a posteriori} support for the Run I \vh~search paper, and investigates several potential $b$-jet energy corrections, proposing one of them for the Run II analysis. Since the di-$b$-jet invariant mass (\mbb) is the best known signal to background discriminant, the search sensitivity increases when the \mbb~resolution improves. We reproduce the 2-jet 2-$b$-tag \wh~sample. After the $b$-jet reconstruction and event selection are reviewed, the four consecutive jet energy corrections are studied and confirmed to be beneficial to the \wh~search. We further show that a transverse momentum (Pt) correction derived in the \wh~sample gives consistent results with the one used, derived in the \zhll~sample. In 12\% of cases where the $b$ quark decays semileptonically through a muon and a neutrino, even after the muon-in-jet (Mu) correction, the jet energy response is about 10\% smaller due to the unaccounted neutrino. 78.7\%, 20.1\% and 1.2\% of events have zero, one or two jets with muons, respectively. Relative to the generated \mbb~peak, the reconstructed peak is 0.7\% higher, 3.4\% lower and 5.9\% lower, respectively. This is improved to 0.4\% lower, 0.3\% higher and 2.2\% higher, respectively, and the total \mbb~width is improved by 1.5\%, from 12.9 GeV to 12.7 GeV, when two different Pt corrections are used, depending on whether the jet contains or not a muon. We therefore recommend that, at a minimum, this approach is taken for the Run II analysis. We also investigate corrections based on regressions using artificial neural networks. We show that using the Pt as sole input is equivalent to the existing Pt correction, and adding the change in Pt due to the Mu correction as a second input is equivalent with two Pt corrections depending on whether there is a muon or not. Several other further potential improvements are outlined for future study.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: An a posteriori support note for the Run I WH analysis and its paper, focusing on the b-jet energy corrections for the dijet invariant mass distribution. Several potential corrections are also discussed and a recommendation is made for the Run II analysis. This is the main note, while the previous one is supporting this note with many plots in Appendix style.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for direct top-squark pair production in final states with two $\tau$ leptons in \boldmath{pp} collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$~TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for direct pair production of supersymmetric partners of the top quark decaying via a $\tau$ slepton to a light weakly interacting particle has been performed using 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$~TeV, collected by the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider in 2012. Top squark candidates are identified in events with two oppositely charged leptons, including one or two hadronically decaying $\tau$ leptons. No excess over the Standard Model expectation is found ({\em or maybe it is...}). Exclusion limits at 95\% confidence level are set as a function of the top squark and $\tau$ slepton masses. Depending on the $\tau$ slepton mass, lower limits between xxx~GeV and yyy~GeV are placed on the top squark mass.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: paper draft

dc:dc.dc:title: Charged Higgs boson searches at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We present the latest results from searches for singly charged Higgs bosons carried out by the ATLAS and CMS Collaborations at the LHC. Both experiments have searched for production of charged Higgs bosons in pp collisions of up to 20 (5) fb^-

dc:dc.dc:title: Setting Limits on the Higgs width using interference information in the di-photon channel with √s = 8 TeV data
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This support note documents limits on the Higgs boson decay width extracted using interferometry in the di-photon channel, as well as the expected impact from interferometry on the Higgs mass measurement in the H \to \gamma\gamma channel.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cooper, Ben
Wardrope, David Robert
Thompson, Emily
Alison, John
Zhou, Lei
Bellomo, Massimiliano
Kagan, Michael
Konstantinidis, Nikolaos
BIN NORJOHARUDDEEN , Nurfikri
Falla, Rebecca Jane
Willocq, Stephane
Van Den Wollenberg, Wouter
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for di-Higgs production in the 4b final state from pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for $pp\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm} hh\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm} b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ has been performed in 19.5 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, which were recorded by ATLAS in 2012. The decay of each Higgs boson is reconstructed as a high-$p_{T}$ $b\bar{b}$ system with either a pair of small-radius jets or a single large-radius jet, the latter exploiting jet substructure techniques and associated $b$-tagged track jets for the first time in ATLAS. No evidence for resonant or non-resonant Higgs pair production is observed. Using a bulk Randall-Sundrum Kaluza-Klein graviton with $k/M_{Pl} = 1.0$ as a benchmark resonant signal, a 95$\%$ confidence level upper limit on $\sigma\left(pp\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm}G^{*}_{KK}\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm}hh\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm}b\bar{b}b\bar{b}\right)$ of 3 (5) fb is set for $m_{G^*_{KK}} = 1.0$ (1.5) TeV. For this model, gravitons with $500 < m_{G*} < 720$ GeV are excluded at the 95$\%$ confidence level. The search for non-resonant SM $hh$ production sets an observed 95\% confidence level upper limit on $\sigma(pp\hspace{-1mm}\rightarrow\hspace{-1mm}hh\hspace{-1mm}\rightarrow\hspace{-1mm}b\bar{b}b\bar{b})$ of 198 fb, which corresponds to $\mu = \sigma/\sigma_{\rm{SM}} = 57^{+8}_{-6}$, a significant improvement on the previous best limit of $\mu = 205^{+29}_{-22}$

dc:dc.dc:creator: Alstaty, Mahmoud
Djama, Fares
Miglioranzi, Silvia
dc:dc.dc:title: Cluster Properties and Lorentz Angle Measurement in the 4-Layer Pixel Detector Using Cosmic Rays
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The 4-layer Pixel Detector with the recently installed innermost layer called IBL saw its first data during the 2014 fall cosmic run. This note shows cluster properties and Lorentz angle fits for IBL sensors as well as old barrel layer sensors.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gross, Eilam
Adye, Tim
Yang, Hongtao
dc:dc.dc:title: Combined measurement of the Higgs boson mass from the $H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^{(*)}\rightarrow \ell\ell\ell\ell$ channels with Run I $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=7$~TeV and $8$~TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A combined measurement of the mass of the Higgs boson by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at the CERN Large Hadron Collider is presented. The measurement is derived from a combined fit to the reconstructed invariant mass spectra of the decay channels $H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^{(*)}\rightarrow \ell\ell\ell\ell$. The dataset used corresponds to an integrated luminosity per experiment ranging from 4.5 to 5.1 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions recorded at center-of-mass energy of 7 TeV, and 19.7 to 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ recorded at 8 TeV. The measured value of the Higgs boson mass is $m_{H} =125.09\pm0.21\mathrm{(stat.)}\pm0.11\mathrm{(syst.)}~\mathrm{GeV}$. The consistency between the mass value measurements from individual decay channels and from individual experiments is within 1$\sigma$.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Canepa, Anadi
dc:dc.dc:title: Selected Highlights from the LHC and HL-LHC Physics Program
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Selected Highlights from the LHC and HL-LHC Physics Program
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: January 26th, 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bawa, Harinder Singh
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent results from Beyond Standard Model (BSM) searches at LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We present the results and prospects for searches beyond the Standard Model (SM) at the LHC by the ATLAS and CMS collaborations. The minimal supersymmetric extension of the SM has been investigated in various configurations at 8TeV center of mass energy at LHC and lower limits are set on the s-particle masses. The searches for other scenarios of physics beyond the SM are also presented. The data are found to be consistent with the Standard Model. The non-observation of a signal is converted to limits at the 95% confidence level(C.L) on the production cross section times branching ratio and on the masses of the hypothesized new particles for appropriate benchmark models (new heavy gauge bosons, extra-dimensions, compositeness or dark matter).

dc:dc.dc:title: Recent results from Beyond Standard Model (BSM) searches at LHC

dc:dc.dc:description: We present the results and prospects for searches beyond the Standard Model (SM) at the LHC by the ATLAS and CMS collaborations. The minimal supersymmetric extension of the SM has been investigated in various configurations at 8TeV center of mass energy at LHC and lower limits are set on the s-particle masses. dc:dc.dc:creator: Tavares Delgado, Ademar
ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Design and performance of the ATLAS jet trigger system
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The CERN Large Hadron Collider is the biggest and most powerful particle collider made by man. It produces 40 million proton-proton collisions per second at unprecedented energies to explore the fundamental laws and properties of Nature. The ATLAS experiment is one of the detectors that analyse and record these collisions. It generates an infeasible large data volume that has to be selected before it can be permanently stored. The event selection is made by the ATLAS trigger system, which reduces the data volume by a factor of 10^5 . The trigger system has to be highly configurable in order to adapt to changing running conditions and maximize the physics output whilst keeping the output rate under control. A particularly interesting pattern generated during collisions consists of a collimated spray of particles, known as hadronic jet. To retain the interesting jets and efficiently reject the overwhelming background, optimal jet energy resolution is needed. Therefore the Jet trigger software requires CPU-intensive reconstruction algorithms. In order to reduce the resources needed for the reconstruction step, a partial detector readout scheme was developed, which effectively suppresses the low activity regions of the calorimeter. In this paper we describe the overall ATLAS trigger software, and the jet trigger in particular, along with the improvements made on the system. We then focus on detailed studies of the algorithm timing and the performance impact of the full and partial calorimeter readout schemes. We conclude with an outlook of the jet trigger plans for the next LHC data-taking period.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Perepelitsa, Dennis
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet quenching measurements in lead-lead collisions at 2.76 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Measurements of jets from highly energetic partons are considered to be one of the most direct probes of the hot and dense QCD medium produced in ultrarelativistic collisions of large nuclei. These fast partons suffer energy loss and the modification of their parton shower though interactions with the traversed medium. This phenomenon, known as jet quenching, may be experimentally investigated in a variety of ways, such as through measurements of the nuclear modification factor and modifications to the fragmentation function for inclusive high-pT reconstructed jets, or through the angular correlations of jets in multijet production. In this talk, the latest results from measurements of jet quenching in 2.76 TeV lead-lead collisions with the ATLAS detector at the LHC will be presented. The centrality of these collisions is characterized using the total transverse energy in the forward calorimeters, situated at 3.1 < |eta| < 4.9. Jets are reconstructed within the hermetic, large acceptance ATLAS hadronic calorimeter, allowing for a detailed probe of jet quenching phenomena over a wide kinematic range in transverse momentum and rapidity.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: conference start date is 2 February 2015 (but the talk is not until 4 February 2015)

dc:dc.dc:creator: Chen, Chunhui
De Lorenzi, Francesco
Prell, Soeren
Pluth, Daniel
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Type III Seesaw heavy leptons in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS Detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search is presented for production of heavy leptons predicted by the Type III seesaw theory in order to explain the origin of the small neutrino masses. The analysis is performed using the final state that contains two leptons (electron or muon), two jets from a hadronically decaying $W$ boson and large missing transverse momentum. The data used in the measurement corresponds to an integrated luminosity of 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV collected by the ATLAS detector at the LHC. No evidence of heavy lepton production is observed. Depending on the considered theoretical scenarios, heavy leptons with masses below 320-450~GeV are excluded at 95\% confidence level.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Marchiori, Giovanni
dc:dc.dc:title: Prospects for the measurement of the rare Higgs boson decay $H\to\mu\mu$ with 3000 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions collected at $\sqrt{s} = 14$ TeV by the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents an updated study of the prospects for the measurement of the rare decay $H\to \mu\mu$ using 3000 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=14$~TeV recorded with the ATLAS detector at the high-luminosity (HL) LHC. Generated samples of the main signal and background processes, combined with parametrisations of the detector performances (efficiencies and resolutions) are used to estimate the expected signal and background yields after a selection similar to the analysis performed in Run 1. The sensitivity of the analysis is improved by classifying events in categories with different $S/B$. A fit to the distribution of the di-muon invariant mass of the selected candidates is used to perform the final discrimination between signal and background, to estimate the significance of the signal yield, to extract the $H\to\mu\mu$ branching ratio and compare it to the Standard Model prediction. For an Asimov dataset generated at 3000 fb$^{-1}$, the fitted signal strength is $\mu = 0.98 \pm 0.13$ and the significance of the signal, estimated from the profile of the likelihood vs $\mu$ upon maximisation of the other nuisance parameters is around $7.7\sigma$ neglecting all systematic uncertainties (including theoretical ones).
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: other author: Charles Delporte (UPMC, Paris)

dc:dc.dc:creator: Chekanov, Sergei
Paramonov, Alexander
Proudfoot, James
dc:dc.dc:title: Simulation of energies per TileCal PMT for pileup events for the LHC phase 2 upgrade
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: An examination of truth-level energies per photomultiplier (PMT) of the Tile calorimeter (TileCal) using Monte Carlo simulations is presented. The full detector simulation was performed for minimum-bias events and for events with high-$p_T$ jets. We studied different pileup scenarios, assuming the average number of interactions per beam crossing $<\mu>$=23, 30, 140 and 200. The truth-level energy distributions for separate TileCal PMTs discussed in this note are valuable inputs for the phase 2 TileCal upgrade studies.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Brosamer, Jacquelyn
Shapiro, Marjorie
Cooke, Mark
Hinchliffe, Ian
Tibbetts, Mark James
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of jets produced in top quark events using the $e\mu$ final state with 2 $b$-tagged jets in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The transverse momentum $p_T$ and multiplicity of jets produced in top quark events are measured using 20.3fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at a center-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV. Jets are selected from top events requiring an opposite-charge $e\mu$ pair and two $b$-tagged jets in the final state. The data are corrected to obtain the particle-level fiducial cross section $\frac{1}{\sigma_{e\mu+2~b-\textrm{jets}}} \frac{d\sigma_{\mathrm{jet}}}{dp_T}$for additional jets rank 1-4, where rank=1 is the leading additional jet. These distributions are used to obtain the extra jet multiplicity as a function of minimum jet $p_T$ threshold. The $p_T$ distribution of the $b$-jets are also presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bertsche, Carolyn
Hawkings, Richard
Strauss, Michael
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of $t\bar t$ production with a veto on additional central jet activity in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents a measurement of the amount of QCD radiation in top quark pair-production ($t\bar t$) events, using dilepton $t\bar t$ events that have an opposite-sign $e\mu$ pair and two $b$-tagged jets in the final state. The measurement includes the complete 2012 ATLAS data sample of 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ integrated luminosity of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$~\tev{}, and identifies jets containing $b$-quarks with the MV1 tagging algorithm, which leverages the long lifetime, high decay multiplicity, and high mass of $b$-hadrons. The fraction of signal events that does not contain additional jet activity in a central rapidity region is measured as a function of (a) the minimum transverse momentum of any additional jet in the event, and (b) the minimum scalar transverse momentum sum of all additional jets in the event, and the results shown for four central rapidity regions and four invariant mass regions. Compensation for detector effects is applied to the experimental measurement and the results compared at the particle level to simulations by several next-to-leading order (NLO) and leading order (LO) Monte Carlo generators. The resulting gap fraction measurements, in comparison with simulation, can be used to tune Monte Carlo modeling of QCD radiation, which is influenced by parameters such as the choice of renormalisation/factorisation scales, the parton shower matching procedure, and initial and final state radiation simulation. The results may also reduce associated modeling uncertainties for ATLAS top quark physics measurements.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gabaldon, Carolina
Schwienhorst, Reinhard
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of correlation of PDF uncertainty in single top and top pair production at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The incomplete knowledge of parton distribution functions is an important source of systematic uncertainty for top-quark measurements, including top-quark pair and single top-quark production cross sections, as well as for analyses that have a large background from these processes. The correlation of the parton-distribution-function uncertainty is studied for top-quark pair production and single top-quark production in association with a W boson, in final states with two reconstructed leptons. Four types of correlation are studied: between total production cross-sections, between cross-section and acceptance correction, between the two processes for common selection requirements, and between different jet multiplicity requirements. The uncertainty correlation is evaluated for several sets of parton distribution functions using simulated samples of top-quark pair and single top-quark events.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Grimm, Kathryn
Meloni, Federico
Pagan Griso, Simone
Prokofiev, Kirill
Rudolph, Matthew Scott
Wildauer, Andreas
Yu, David Ren-hwa
dc:dc.dc:title: Reconstruction of primary vertices in Run I proton-proton collisions at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents studies on the reconstruction of primary vertices in high luminosity Run I $pp$ collisions using the ATLAS detector at the LHC. Results include both 7 TeV and 8 TeV collisions, but the focus is on 8 TeV running. During the year $2012$, the peak value of instant luminosity recorded by ATLAS was $8\cdot10^{33}\;{\rm cm}^{-2}{\rm s}^{-1}$. While the average number of events per bunch crossing was near 25 for most of 2012 running, special high-pile up runs recorded as many as 70 events per bunch crossing. In such conditions, correct reconstruction of the signal primary vertex and identification of all pile-up interactions in a bunch crossing represents a significant challenge. In this note we quantify the different processes affecting the efficiency of primary vertex reconstruction in such conditions. The mathematical model of such processes is developed and their importance is studied on both Monte Carlo simulation and data collected by the ATLAS experiment. The efficiency of correct reconstruction and identification of primary vertices are studied in detail for several key physics processes at LHC.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Support note for ATL-COM-INDET-2015-002

dc:dc.dc:creator: Malek, Fairouz
dc:dc.dc:title: Non-SUSY Beyond Standard Model Searches: Recent Results from ATLAS and CMS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Standard Model of particle physics is a sensational success, especially since the discovery of the 125 GeV Higgs boson. However, there are still numerous unanswered questions. Why is the Higgs so light? Do the interactions couplings unify and how can gravity be included? Why three fermion generations? What is dark matter? Theories Beyond the Standard Model (BSM), such as Grand Unified Theories, Extra Dimensions or Technicolour are trying to answer these questions. In this proceedings, we will focus on the most recent results obtained by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at the LHC for BSM searches, excluding Higgs and supersymmetry searches. New results on Dark matter, heavy narrow bosons, new heavy quarks and third generation leptoquarks are presented. A summary of the prospects at 14 TeV and at the High Luminosity LHC period is given.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: THE DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 27 2015 Page allocation: Parallel-session talks: 10 – 15 pages

dc:dc.dc:creator: Savage, Graham
dc:dc.dc:title: 8 TeV Non-Resonant Dilepton Search at ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search is conducted for non-resonant new phenomena in dielectron and dimuon final states, originating from either contact interactions or large extra spatial dimensions. The full LHC 2012 proton-proton collision dataset recorded by the ATLAS detector is used, corresponding to 20 fb-1 at √s = 8 TeV. The invariant mass spectrum is used as a discriminating variable alongside forward-backward asymmetry where relevant to increase the search sensitivity. A Bayesian approach is used to set lower limits on the new physics parameters of interest at the 95% credibility level.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The conference starts on the 15th of February 2015.

Zanzi, Daniele
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for the associated production of the Higgs boson with a top quark pair in multi-lepton final states with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the associated production of the Higgs boson with a top quark pair is performed in multi-lepton final states using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data recorded by the ATLAS experiment at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV at the Large Hadron Collider. Five final states are examined for the presence of the Standard Model Higgs boson with a mass of 125 GeV: two same-charged light leptons ($e$ or $\mu$) without an additional hadronically decaying tau, three light leptons, two same-charged light leptons with an additional hadronically decaying tau, four light leptons, and one light lepton and two hadronically decaying taus. No significant excess of events is observed above the background expectation. The best fit for the $t\bar t H$ production cross section is $2.2 ^{+1.4}_{-1.2}$ times the Standard Model expectation, and the observed (expected) upper limit at the 95% confidence level is 4.6 (2.3) times the Standard Model rate.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Mondragon, Matthew Craig
Cribbs, Wayne Allen
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of 2011 and 2012 cosmic ray muon data in ATLAS hadronic calorimeter TileCal
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Cosmic ray muons provide an means of cross checking the calibration of the ATLAS hadronic calorimeter TileCal. The goal of this study was to present the data in a similar fashion to the cosmic ray studies done for the 2008, 2009, and 2010 data for comparison. Cosmic ray data taken in 2011 and 2012 were analyzed to show the uniformity in cell response in TileCal cells in different layers, modules and regions of the detector.

dc:dc.dc:title: DESIGN AND OPERATION OF A QUAD PCB FOR THE AIDA BEAM TELESCOPE PLANE

dc:dc.dc:creator: Oleiro Seabra, Luis Filipe
dc:dc.dc:title: ALFA Detector Control System
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ALFA (Absolute Luminosity For ATLAS) is one of the sub-detectors of ATLAS (A Toroidal LHCApparatus). The ALFA system is composed by four stations installed in the LHC tunnel 240 m away from the ATLAS interaction point. Each station has a vacuum and ventilation system, movement control and all the required electronics for signal processing. The Detector Control System (DCS) provides control and monitoring of several components and ensures the safe operation of the detector contributing to good Data Quality. This paper describes the ALFA DCS system including a detector overview, operation aspects and hardware control through a SCADA system, WinCC OA.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Glaysher, Paul
dc:dc.dc:title: A study of VH->Vbb for High Luminosity LHC Running
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: For Standard Model Higgs boson production in the decay mode H -> bb in association with a W or Z boson for High Luminosity LHC Running, the expected signal significance and signal strength is presented for 300 fb-1 and 3000 fb-1 with an average pile-up of <µ>=60 and <µ>=140 respectively.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: 4Mar 2015 LHCC

dc:dc.dc:creator: Huhtinen, Mika
Salek, David
Tovey, Daniel
Gibson, Stephen
Asquith, Lily
dc:dc.dc:title: Beam-induced and cosmic backgrounds observed in the ATLAS detector during the 2012 proton-proton running period
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This paper discusses various observations on beam induced background in the ATLAS detector during the 2012 proton-proton run. Building on the paper on 2011 observations, the background vs residual pressure correlations are revisited. Ghost charge evolution over 2012 and its role for backgrounds are discussed in detail. A thorough analysis of a particular LHC fill, where abnormally high background was observed, is presented. Backgrounds under special beam conditions, namely some LHC test fills with 25 ns bunch spacing and fills at very high beta* are evaluated. Data from the BCM and Pixel detectors are used to assess azimuthal symmetry of the beam backgrounds and results are compared with dedicated Monte Carlo simulations. Some results of two short periods of dedicated cosmic background data-taking are shown, in particular cosmic muon induced fake jets rates. Monte Carlo simulations are compared to the cosmic data.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: supporting document for https://cds.cern.ch/record/1701144

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bilbao De Mendizabal, Javier
Guescini, Francesco
Miucci, Antonio
Stucci, Stefania Antonia
dc:dc.dc:title: IBL Module Loading onto Stave and Quality Check
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: During the long shutdown between Run 1 and Run 2 of the LHC, a fourth, innermost, Pixel Detector layer has been installed in the ATLAS experiment: the Insertable B-Layer, IBL. The purpose of the new layer is to add redundancy against radiation damage of the B-layer, to ensure high quality tracking and improve the flavor tagging performance. New pixel silicon detector modules have been produced and loaded onto support structures known as staves, the building blocks of IBL. A total of 20 staves have been assembled. Procedures and results of the stave loading process are presented in this note.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Paul already assigned ATL-INDET-PUB-2015-002 as ID

dc:dc.dc:creator: Sun, Xiaohu
Fang, Yaquan
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for the Heavy Higgs Scalar in 8 TeV $pp$ collisions using the ATLAS detector with the combination of $b\bar{b}\gamma\gamma$, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$, $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ and $b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ final states
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the Higgs pair using $20~fb^{-1}$ collected by the ATLAS detector in 8 TeV $pp$ collisions is presented. With the combination of $b\bar{b}\gamma\gamma$, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$, $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ and $b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ final states, a 95% confidence level upper limit on the cross section times branching ratio of the non-resonant production is set at XXX pb, while the expected limit is XXX pb. For the resonant production with the mass below 500 GeV, where $b\bar{b}\gamma\gamma$, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$ and $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ are taken into account in the combination, the observed limit ranges between XXX and XXX as a function of heavy higgs mass. For the mass region higer than 500 GeV, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$, $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ and $b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ are considered and the observed limit are from XXX and XXX.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Pernegger, Heinz
dc:dc.dc:title: The Pixel Detector of the ATLAS Experiment for LHC Run-2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Pixel Detector of the ATLAS experiment has shown excellent performance during the whole Run-1 of LHC. Taking advantage of the long shutdown, the detector was extracted from the experiment and brought to surface, to equip it with new service quarter panels, to repair modules and to ease installation of the Insertable B-Layer (IBL). IBL is a fourth layer of pixel detectors, and has been installed in May 2014 between the existing Pixel Detector and a new smaller radius beam-pipe at a radius of 3.3 cm. To cope with the high radiation and hit occupancy due to the proximity to the interaction point, a new read-out chip and two different silicon sensor technologies (planar and 3D) have been developed. Furthermore, the physics performance will be improved through the reduction of pixel size while, targeting for a low material budget, a new mechanical support using lightweight staves and a CO2 based cooling system have been adopted. An overview of the refurbishing of the Pixel Detector and of the IBL project as well as the experience in its construction will be presented, focusing on adopted technologies, module and staves production, qualification of assembly procedure, integration of staves around the beam pipe and commissioning of the detector.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The organizer informed me that he would need the proceedings very soon if possible - sorry for the rush & thank you for your understanding

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bernard, Nathan Rogers
Blackburn, Daniel
Brau, Benjamin
Coccaro, Andrea
Iuppa, Roberto
Lubatti, Henry
Pais, Preema
Russell, Heather Lynn
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for long-lived, weakly-interacting particles that decay to displaced hadronic jets in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search in the ATLAS detector for the decay of neutral, weakly-interacting, long-lived particles in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV in the data recorded in 2012 at the LHC is presented. The search employs techniques for reconstructing decay vertices of long-lived particles decaying to jets in the ATLAS inner tracking detector and muon spectrometer. No significant excess of events is found, and limits are reported for the decay of the Higgs or a scalar boson to long-lived particles and for Hidden Valley and Stealth SUSY benchmark models. The first search results for displaced heavy $Z'$ and Stealth SUSY decays are presented. The upper bound of the exclusion limits are the most stringent to date.

dc:dc.dc:title: Data points for ATLAS-HION-2011-03
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment

dc:dc.dc:creator: Whiteson, Daniel
Akesson, Torsten Paul Ake
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for new phenomena in dijet angular distributions in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$~TeV measured with the ATLAS Detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for new phenomena produced in LHC proton-proton collisions at center-of-mass energy $\sqrt{s}=8$~TeV has been performed with the ATLAS detector using an integrated luminosity of 17.3/f. The angular distributions are studied in events with two jets, including dijet masses up to ~5.5 ~TeV. All angular distributions are consistent with the predictions of the Standard Model. In a benchmark model of quark contact interactions, a compositeness scale below XX (YY)~TeV in a destructive (constructive) interference scenario have been set at 95\% CL.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Schnoor, Ulrike
Vest, Anja Simone
dc:dc.dc:title: Prospects for Vector Boson Scattering in the $W^\pm W^\pm jj$ final state with an extended ATLAS tracking detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents prospects for the measurement of vector boson scattering in the $W^\pm W^\pm jj$ final state at an upgraded LHC with an extended ATLAS tracking detector. Simulation of detector effects is used to estimate the sensitivity to this process for proton-proton collisions at 14 TeV and a total luminosity of 3000 fb−1 . In addition, the sensitivity to BSM resonances in this final state is presented. The measurement benefits from an extended tracking detector through improved background rejection as well as jet reconstruction efficiency.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: This note is a supporting documentation for ATL-COM-PHYS-2015-022

dc:dc.dc:creator: Sivolella Gomes, Andressa
Solans, Carlos
Solodkov, Alexander
Ferreira, Fernando
Maidantchik, Carmen
dc:dc.dc:title: Tile-in-ONE: A web platform which integrates Tile Calorimeter analyses
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Tile-in-ONE (TiO) is a unique platform that assembles various web systems used by the calorimeter community through a single framework and a standard technology. It provides an infrastructure to support the code implementation, avoiding duplication of work while integrating with an overall view of the detector status. Database connectors smooth the process of information access since developers do not need to be aware of where records are placed and how to extract them. Within the environment, a dashboard stands for a particular Tile operation aspect and gets together plugins, i.e. software components that add specific features to an existing application. By now, TiO attends 3 types of users: interested in tile, Data Quality validator and Calibrations expert. Plugins can be coded straight on the web platform, avoiding the user technical knowledge concerning the data access (as i.e. setting environment variables or data sources access configuration). TiO is designed to be extended and has interfaces to almost all services in ATLAS.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Metcalfe, Jessica
Valencic, Nika
Pleier, Marc-Andre
dc:dc.dc:title: Same-sign WW Scattering Performance Studies with Delphes for the Large Eta Task Force
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The impact of an extended tracker for the future Upgraded ATLAS detector was evaluated for the same sign $WW$ electroweak vector boson scattering process for runs at the high luminosity Large Hadron Collider at $\sqrt{s}$ = 14 TeV. The performance of pileup, jets, and leptons was evaluated and found to have a large impact on the significance of the measurement of ssWW. A silicon tracker extended out to $|\eta|$ $\le$ 4 compared to $|\eta|$ $\le$ 2.5 has the potential to improve the significance of the ssWW measurement by 82\% in a low pileup scenario, $<\mu>$ = 80, or 174\% given $<\mu>$ = 140. The potential discovery of new physics was also evaluated for the gauge boson coupling parameter, $f_{T1}$, in an effective field theory framework.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: supporting note for ATL-COM-PHYS-2015-022

dc:dc.dc:creator: Pirumov, Hayk
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of background subtraction on 2012 van der Meer calibration
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The estimation of the level of background in the BCM and LUCID detectors during the 2012 July and November van der Meer scans and the background subtraction procedure for luminosity calibration are presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bini, Cesare
Messina, Andrea
Vanadia, Marco
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of the performance of Resistive MicroMegas chambers instrumented with the VMM-1 ASIC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A new analysis of MicroMegas data collected in 2012 with a 120 GeV muon beam is presented. The setup comprises 8 MicroMegas chambers instrumented with VMM-1 electronics. The resolution on the earliest time measurement of the chambers is measured to be 15-20 ns. We measure a reconstruction efficiency of the detectors which is significantly lower than that of APV25-instrumented chambers. The resolution of the centroid reconstruction is measured as a function of the angle of the incident particles, with results in agreement with APV25 ones for perpendicular particles, but worse by 30-40% for inclined ones. A resolution measurement for the $\mu$TPC reconstruction is also performed. We find that 70-80% of particles with an impinging angle of 30° can be reconstructed with a $\mu$TPC fit with a resolution of 0.12-0.15 mm, while a 10-20% fraction of those particles is reconstructed with a resolution worse than that. With appropriate quality cuts the resolution can be improved to 0.11-0.13 mm and the fraction of particles reconstructed with a worse resolution is reduced to 6-8%, but these cuts reduce the efficiency to 40-50%. Finally, we prove that the uncertainty on the position measured with the $\mu$TPC reconstruction is significantly event dependent, and that we are able to describe this event-by-event uncertainty with good approximation.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Limosani, Antonio
Zhou, Chen
Kruse, Mark
Finelli, Kevin Daniel
Paramonov, Alexander
Benjamin, Douglas
Rifki, Othmane
Saavedra, Aldo
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t\bar{t}W$ production cross-section using events with same-sign leptons from $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document summarizes a measurement of the $t\bar{t}W$ cross-section using a combined likelihood fit to the distribution of $E_T^{\mathrm{miss}}$ and $N_{\mathrm{jets}}$. The measurement uses $20.3\,\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of data from proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}$=8 TeV observed by the ATLAS experiment at CERN. This document is focused on the two same-sign lepton channel intended to improve the accuracy of the cross-section for $t\bar{t}W$ in a multi-channel combination. The measured cross-section of $t\bar{t}W$ production using only the same-sign channels described in this note is $429\pm100$ fb using the 1 and 2 $b$-tagged jets samples. Using only the 2 $b$-tagged jet sample, the cross-section is measured to be $490\pm128$ fb for $t\bar{t}W$ These measurements correspond to $t\bar{t}W$ signal significances of $5.1\sigma$ and $5.0\sigma$, respectively.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: One of five supporting notes (2LOS, 2LSS, 3L, 4L, combination) for the paper TOPQ-2013-05, “Measurement of the tt¯W and tt¯Z production cross sections in pp collisions at s√=8 TeV with the ATLAS detector” submitted on 2015/09/17 to JHEP

These analyses are based on the 2012 pp collision dataset collected by ATLAS at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV. Upper limits are presented, as well as their interpretation in CP-conserving 2HDMs.

dc:dc.dc:title: PDF uncertainties in precision electroweak measurements, including the W mass, in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Now that the Higgs mass is known all the parameters of the SM are known- but with what accuracy? Precision EW measurements test the self-consistency of the SM- and thus can give hints of BSM physics. Precision measurements of $sin^2\theta _W$ and the W mass are limited by PDF uncertainties This contribution discusses these uncertainties and what can be done to improve them.

Schreuder, Frans Philip

Vermeulen, Jos
dc:dc.dc:title: Improving Packet Processing Performance in the ATLAS FELIX Project: Analysis and Optimization of a Memory-Bounded Algorithm
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Experiments in high-energy physics (HEP) and related fields often impose constraints and challenges on data acquisition systems. As a result, these systems are implemented as unique mixtures of custom and commercial-off-the-shelf electronics (COTS), involving and connecting radiation-hard devices, large high-performance networks, and computing farms. FELIX, the Frontend Link Exchange, is a new PC-based general purpose data routing device for the data-acquisition system of the ATLAS experiment at CERN. Performance is a very crucial point for devices like FELIX, which have to be capable of processing tens of gigabyte of data per second. Thus it is important to understand the performance limitations for typical workloads on modern hardware. We present an analysis of a packet processing algorithm that is used in FELIX, and show how the PC system's memory architecture plays a key factor in the overall data throughput achieved by the application. Finally, we present optimizations that increase the processing throughput by a factor of more than 10x.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: DEBS2015 camera-ready deadline: May 13th

dc:dc.dc:creator: Spagnolo, Stefania
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of vector boson with associated jet production with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Productions of light and heavy-flavour jets in association with a W or a Z boson in proton-proton collisions are important processes to study QCD in multi-scale environments and the proton parton content. Cross sections, differential in several kinematics variables, have been measured with the ATLAS detector in 7 TeV proton-proton collisions and compared to high-order QCD calculations and Monte Carlo simulations. The production of heavy flavour in association with a W or Z boson is sensitive to parton density functions and the modelling of heavy-quark flavour production mechanisms.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Slides for talk at LLWI2015 Conference start date 15 Feb 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Jansky, Roland Wolfgang
dc:dc.dc:title: Novel methods and expected run II performance of ATLAS track reconstruction in dense environments
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Detailed understanding and optimal track reconstruction performance of ATLAS in the core of high pT objects is paramount for a number of techniques such as jet energy and mass calibration, jet flavour tagging, and hadronic tau identification as well as measurements of physics quantities like jet fragmentation functions. These dense environments are characterized by charged particle separations on the order of the granularity of ATLAS’s inner detector. With the insertion of a new innermost layer in this tracking detector, which allows measurements closer to the interaction point, and an increase in the centre of mass energy, these difficult environments will become even more relevant in Run II, such as in searches for heavy resonances. Novel algorithmic developments to the ATLAS track reconstruction software targeting these topologies as well as the expected improved performance will be presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: LLWI15 start date: 16 February

dc:dc.dc:creator: Jakoubek, Tomas
dc:dc.dc:title: Flavour-tagged time-dependent angular analysis of the $B_s^0 \rightarrow J/\psi(\mu^+\mu^-)\Phi(K^+K^-)$ decay with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We present a flavour tagged time dependent angular analysis of the $B_s \rightarrow J/\psi\phi$ decay, using 4.9 fb$^{−1}$ of integrated luminosity collected by the ATLAS detector from 7 TeV proton-proton collisions recorded in 2011. CP violation in this channel is described by a weak phase $\phi_s$, which is sensitive to new physics contributions. The measured value is $\phi_s$ = 0.12 $\pm$ 0.25 (stat.) $\pm$ 0.05 (syst.) rad, which is in good agreement with Standard Model expectations. Also other measured parameters are consistent with the world average.

dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Forward Proton Detector: Technical Design Report
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
