dc:dc.dc:creator: Wildauer, Andreas
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent top-physics results from ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The top quark is the heaviest known fundamental particle. As it is the only quark that decays before it hadronizes, it gives a unique opportunity to probe the properties of bare quarks. This talk will focus on a few recent precision measurements by the ATLAS Collaboration of the top quark: fiducial top pair and single top production cross sections including differential distributions will be presented, alongside measurements of top quark properties. Interpretations in terms of limits on beyond the Standard Model physics using top quarks will also be presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Lake Louise Winter Institute, Start 15.02.2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dao, Valerio
Guindon, Stefan
Shabalina, Elizaveta
Vazquez Schroeder, Tamara
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the associated production of a vector boson (W, Z) and top quark pair in the opposite sign dilepton channel with $\boldsymbol{pp}$ collisions at $\boldsymbol{\sqrt{s} = 8}$ TeV with the ATLAS detector at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the production of vector bosons (W, Z) in association with a pair of top quarks ($t\bar{t}V$) is presented. The analysis uses 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8TeV$, collected with the ATLAS detector of the Large Hadron Collider. The search focuses on final states containing two opposite-sign leptons, electrons or muons. A $t\bar{t}V$ signal strength $\hat{\mu} = 0.63^{+0.64}_{-0.58}$ times the Standard Model value is obtained, with an observed significance of 1.09 $\sigma$. Additionally, a model-independent two-dimensional fit is performed to measure the signal strength of both $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ processes.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: One of five supporting notes (2LOS, 2LSS, 3L, 4L, combination) for the paper TOPQ-2013-05, “Measurement of the tt¯W and tt¯Z production cross sections in pp collisions at s√=8 TeV with the ATLAS detector” submitted on 2015/09/17 to JHEP

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gignac, Matthew
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for direct pair production of a chargino and a neutralino decaying to the 125 GeV Higgs boson with 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of 8 TeV pp collisions using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search is presented for the direct pair production of a chargino and a neutralino $pp$ $\rightarrow$ $\tilde{\chi}^{\pm}_{1}$$\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{2}$, where the chargino decays to the lightest neutralino and the $W$ boson, $\tilde{\chi}^{\pm}_{1}$ $\rightarrow$ $\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{1}$ $(W^{\pm}\to\ell^{\pm}\nu)$, while the neutralino decays to the lightest neutralino and the 125~GeV Higgs boson, $\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{2}$ $\rightarrow$ $\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{1}$ $(h\to bb/\gamma\gamma/\ell^{\pm}\nu qq)$. The final states considered for the search have large missing transverse momentum, an isolated electron or muon, and one of the following: either two jets identified as originating from bottom quarks, or two photons, or a second electron or muon with the same electric charge. The analysis is based on 20.3fb$^{-1}$ of $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV proton$-$proton collision data delivered by the Large Hadron Collider and recorded with the ATLAS detector. Observations are consistent with the Standard Model expectations, and limits are set in the context of a simplified supersymmetric model.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date: February 15th 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Santoyo Castillo, Itzebelt
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for electroweak production of supersymmetry, supersymmetry in resonance production, R-parity violating signatures and events with long-lived particles with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This talk summarises the latest ATLAS results in the context of searches for electroweak production of supersymmetric particles, R-Parity violating/conserving SUSY scenarios, and long-lived supersymmetric particles using the full 2012 data corresponding to 20.3~fb^{-1} at \sqrt{s} = 8~TeV of p-p collisions collected by the ATLAS.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Start date 15/02/2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Sawyer, Craig
Young, Christopher John
Issever, Cigdem
Lopez Mateos, David
dc:dc.dc:title: Monte Carlo Calibration and Combination of In-situ Measurements of Jets in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The stages in the final Run-1 jet energy scale calibration in the ATLAS detector are described. The Monte Carlo based calibration is discussed for both small and large radius jets and the final combination of various in-situ measurements and the resultant jet energy scale uncertainty is presented. Finally the combination of in-situ measurements of the jet energy resolution and associated uncertainties is discussed.

Sotiropoulou, Calliope Louisa
Stabile, Alberto
Volpi, Guido
dc:dc.dc:title: Highly Parallelized Pattern Matching Execution for ATLAS Event Real Time Reconstruction
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: In this paper a high performance "pattern matching" system is presented. The system is based on the concept of Associative Memory (AM), designed to solve the track finding problem that is typical of high energy physics experiments executed in hadron colliders. It is powerful enough to process data produced from 80 overlapping proton-proton collisions at a 100 kHz rate, in a time span of a few microseconds, even very high multiplicity events. The AM is suitable for massive parallelism in data correlation searches. This system is implemented as a large array of custom VLSI chips (AM chips), based on Content Address Memory (CAM). All the chips are identical and each one of them stores a preset number of “patterns”. All the patterns in all the chips are compared in parallel to the incoming data from the detector while the detector is being read out. Data are distributed to the AM chips through a huge network of high speed serial links. The complexity of the "pattern matching" problem is one that increases exponentially when CPU-based algorithms are used. With the proposed system the complexity increase is reduced to linear and the problem is solved by the time data are loaded in the system.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet global sequential corrections with the ATLAS detector in proton-proton collisions at sqrt(s) = 8 TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The determination of the jet energy scale and the achievement of the optimal performance in terms of jet energy resolution are of key importance to many LHC physics analyses. This note describes sequential jet corrections, derived from Monte Carlo simulated events and using global properties of the jet, which improves the performance of the existing calibration schemes used in ATLAS. Performance improvements are achieved by using tracking, calorimeter energy deposit, and muon spectrometer information. The performance of the GS corrections using Monte Carlo simulated events, and the validation on data using the 2012 dataset at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV, are presented. The corrections have been derived in the full pseudorapidity ($\eta$) and transverse momentum ($p_{\rm T}$) ranges considered in ATLAS analyses. The relative improvement in resolution increases with the $p_{\rm T}$ and can go up to 35%, depending on the $\eta$ of the jet and the initial calibration applied. The fragmentation differences between jets initiated by a quark and jets initiated by a gluon lead to a flavour dependence in the jet energy scale. The relative improvement in the flavour dependence after applying the global sequential corrections ranges typically between 20% (80%) at low (high) $p_{\rm T}$, depending also on the $\eta$ of the jet and the initial calibration applied.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Vazeille, Francois
Theveneaux-Pelzer, Timothee
Drake, Gary
Bonnefoy, Romeo
Sahuc, Eric
dc:dc.dc:title: NIEL and TID certifications of the active dividers of the Tile Calorimeter of the ATLAS detector for the Phase II upgrade
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: By following the ATLAS radiation safety rules, the active dividers of the Tile Calorimeter of the ATLAS detector have been certified to NIEL and TID radiations at, respectively, Valduc (France) for neutrons and Brookhaven (USA) for photons. They match the requested radiation criteria entirely.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Becot, C
Andari, N
Fayard, L
Unal, G
dc:dc.dc:title: Difference of energy response between the high and medium gain of the ATLAS electromagnetic calorimeter
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: In this note we report a study of the difference of energy response between the high and medium gain chains, done using the $Z$ boson mass. A sizeable difference is observed between the two chains, especially in a few well defined regions of the detector. An ad-hoc correction has been derived and will be applied to physics analysis using electrons or photons. As no hint of error source have been found it was decided to include a systematic error of the same size than the correction.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Chan, S
Huth, J
Lopez Mateos, D
Mercurio, K
dc:dc.dc:title: $ZH\to llb\bar{b}$ Analysis with Telescoping Jets
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note summarizes the work done to improve the significance of invariant mass measurements in the $ZH\to llb\bar{b}$ analysis using the telescoping jets algorithm. Two $b$-jet axes are used as points in the $\eta,\phi$ plane around which multiple circles (cones) are drawn. The collections of particles in these cones form the successively larger telescoping jets and are used to build multiple event interpretations. Improvements come from using information from these multiple event interpretations. This study uses 2012 Monte Carlo and closely follows the event selection of the of the first full Run 1 preliminary search for $H\to b\bar{b}$ in ATLAS. At reconstructed level, using 12 telescoping radii, from $0.4-1.5$ in steps of $0.1$, gives a 20.5% improvement in the expected statistical significance using a simple $S/\sqrt{B}$ metric.

dc:dc.dc:title: {Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search - Appendices
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves as support for the note ``Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I \wh~search'', holding an extended selection of plots as an Appendix.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Amaral Coutinho, Yara
Begalli, Marcia
Buzatu, Adrian
Do Nascimento Gaspar, Philipp
Nunes De Moura Junior, Natanael
Mullen, Paul
Ravenscroft, Thomas
Robson, Aidan
Seixas, Jose
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves both as \emph{a posteriori} support for the Run I \vh~search paper, and investigates several potential $b$-jet energy corrections, proposing one of them for the Run II analysis. Since the di-$b$-jet invariant mass (\mbb) is the best known signal to background discriminant, the search sensitivity increases when the \mbb~resolution improves. We reproduce the 2-jet 2-$b$-tag \wh~sample. After the $b$-jet reconstruction and event selection are reviewed, the four consecutive jet energy corrections are studied and confirmed to be beneficial to the \wh~search. We further show that a transverse momentum (Pt) correction derived in the \wh~sample gives consistent results with the one used, derived in the \zhll~sample. In 12\% of cases where the $b$ quark decays semileptonically through a muon and a neutrino, even after the muon-in-jet (Mu) correction, the jet energy response is about 10\% smaller due to the unaccounted neutrino. 78.7\%, 20.1\% and 1.2\% of events have zero, one or two jets with muons, respectively. Relative to the generated \mbb~peak, the reconstructed peak is 0.7\% higher, 3.4\% lower and 5.9\% lower, respectively. This is improved to 0.4\% lower, 0.3\% higher and 2.2\% higher, respectively, and the total \mbb~width is improved by 1.5\%, from 12.9 GeV to 12.7 GeV, when two different Pt corrections are used, depending on whether the jet contains or not a muon. We therefore recommend that, at a minimum, this approach is taken for the Run II analysis. We also investigate corrections based on regressions using artificial neural networks. We show that using the Pt as sole input is equivalent to the existing Pt correction, and adding the change in Pt due to the Mu correction as a second input is equivalent with two Pt corrections depending on whether there is a muon or not. Several other further potential improvements are outlined for future study.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Quality, Data
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Data Quality Operations in 2012
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note summarizes the data quality performance of the ATLAS subdetectors during the 2012 data taking period, corresponding to 22.7 fb−1 of data recorded by the ATLAS detector. It also contains a summary of the data quality operation and organization within each subdetector group.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kroha, Hubert
dc:dc.dc:title: Proposal for the Improvement of the ATLAS Muon Spectrometer Momentum Resolution in Barrel Sectors 12 and 14
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Proposal for the installation of new BMG sMDT Chambers in the ATLAS Barrel muon spectrometer in the feet regions in sectors 12 and 14 in order to improve the muon momentum resolution in these regions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hoecker, Andreas
Murray, Bill

Heinemann, Beate

Kado, Marumi
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS procedures for the approval of physics results
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document provides guidelines and details of the procedures for the preparation and approval of physics results. It describes the roles of all the individuals and groups involved in the approval process, the purpose of the meetings, and gives a step-by-step guide on the procedures. Papers, conference notes and public notes are described.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Molander, S
dc:dc.dc:title: Studies of Non-iterative Optimal Filtering Using the Athena Pulse Simulator
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A pulse simulator for generating samples similar to pulses from the ATLAS TILE calorimeter is presented and its functionality and usage explained. An investigation of out-of-time pile-up effects on non-iterative optimal filtering reconstruction is presented, using the pulse simulator tool. The investigation is done using both ideal pulses and effects of noise, time jitter and pulse shape imperfections. A scan of different out-of-time pile-up scenarios shows that it is a possibility that pile-up leads to incorrect energy reconstruction. However, a second part of the investigation using a more likely pile-up distribution shows that such high pile-up scenarios are not common.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dano Hoffmann, Maria
Jakobsen, Sune
dc:dc.dc:title: Determination of Light Yield of an ATLAS Minimum Bias Trigger Scintillator for LHC Run II with Cosmic Radiation
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We report on measurements of the light yield of an ATLAS Minimum Bias Trigger Scintillator (MBTS) to be used in Run II. The measurements were performed before integration in ATLAS in a dedicated cosmic stand. At first we report on the estimation of the attenuation of the clear optical fibers used for light transport. Subsequently, the yield from the outer sector of the MBTS counter is determined with both 4 and 8 wave-length shifters. Furthermore, a direct comparison of the light yield from the inner and outer sector is performed.

dc:dc.dc:title: A search for high-mass resonances decaying to $\tau^{+}\tau^{-}$ in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for high-mass resonances decaying into $\tau^{+}\tau^{-}$ final states using proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}= 8$ TeV produced by the Large Hadron Collider is presented. The data were recorded with the ATLAS detector and correspond to an integrated luminosity of 19.5-20.3 fb$^{-1}$. No statistically significant excess above the Standard Model expectation is observed; 95% credibility upper limits are set on the cross section times branching fraction of $Z^{\prime}$ resonances decaying into $\tau^+\tau^-$ pairs as a function of the resonance mass. As a result, $Z^{\prime}$ bosons of the Sequential Standard Model with masses less than 2.02 TeV are excluded at 95% credibility. The impact of the fermionic couplings on the $Z^{\prime}$ acceptance is investigated and limits are also placed on a $Z^{\prime}$ model that exhibits enhanced couplings to third generation fermions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bulekov, O
Marino, C
Romaniouk, A
Smirnov, Y
Zimmermann, S
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for heavy long-lived multi-charged particles in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for heavy long-lived multi-charged particles is performed using the ATLAS detector at the LHC. Data collected in 2012 at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV from $pp$ collisions corresponding to an integrated luminosity of $20.3$ fb$^{−1}$ are examined. Particles producing anomalously high ionisation, consistent with long-lived massive particles with electric charges from $|q|=2e$ to $|q|=6e$ are searched for. No signal candidate events are observed, and $95\%$ confidence level cross-section upper limits are interpreted as lower mass limits for a Drell--Yan production model. The mass limits range between $660$ and $785$ GeV.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of top-quark pair differential cross-sections in the $l$+jets channel in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note documents the measurement by the ATLAS experiment of the top pair produc- tion differential cross-sections as a function of the top quark transverse momentum, absolute rapidity and of the transverse momentum, mass and absolute rapidity of the $t\bar{t}$ system. The study was performed using data from pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV collected by the ATLAS detector in 2012 and corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{−1}$. The $t\bar{t}$ events were selected in the lepton (electron or muon) + jets channel. Due to the large $t\bar{t}$ cross section at the LHC, such measurements allow a detailed study of the properties of the top- quark production and decay, enabling precision tests of perturbative QCD. There is good agreement between the measured data and the theoretical predictions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: HSG1, The
HSG2, The
HSG7, The
dc:dc.dc:title: Combination of differential fiducial cross-sections of Higgs boson production measured in the $H \rightarrow ZZ^* \rightarrow 4\ell$ and $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ channels using 20.3 fb$^{−1}$ of $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV $pp$ collision data at the ATLAS detector.
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note decribes the combination of the measurements of differential cross-sections of Higgs boson production in the $H \rightarrow ZZ^* \rightarrow 4\ell$ and $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ decay channels. The measurements are extrapolated to the total and a common fiducial phase space. They are compared to results from different calculations. Measurements are performed in bins of the transverse momentum and the rapidity of the Higgs boson, as well as the number of jets and the transverse momentum of the leading jet. For this analysis, 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data were used, produced at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV center-of-mass energy at the LHC and recorded by the ATLAS detector.

dc:dc.dc:title: Performances of a Remote High Voltage Power Supply for the Phase II Upgrade of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The experience gained in the working of the present High Voltage system of the Tile calorimeter and the new HL-LHC constraints, in particular the increase of the radiations, lead to the proposal of moving the embedded regulation system to a remote system in the USA15 room, by adding easily new functionalities. This system is using the same regulation scheme as the present one and distributes the individual HVs with multi-conductor cables. The tests show that it reaches the same performances in terms of regulation stability and noise, with a full working reliability of every channel.

dc:dc.dc:title: Constraints on promptly decaying supersymmetric particles with lepton-number- and $R$-parity-violating interactions using Run I ATLAS data
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Searches for supersymmetry (SUSY) at the LHC frequently assume the conservation of R-parity in their design, optimisation and interpretation. In the case that R-parity is not conserved, the resulting constraints on SUSY particle masses may be significantly weakened. In this document, a selection of ATLAS SUSY searches, mostly optimised for R-parity-conserving SUSY, are reinterpreted in new R-parity-violating (RPV) SUSY models. All forms of renormalisable RPV interactions with lepton-number violation are considered. For LLE and LQD RPV operators, squark and gluino production cross-sections are constrained as a function of the $\tilde{\chi}_1^0$ branching fraction to taus and $b$-quarks. These limits imply exclusion of squark and gluino masses below $\mathcal{O}(1~\rm TeV)$ at 95% confidence level, except in the case of squark production when $m(\tilde{\chi}_1^0)/m(\tilde{q})=0.1$, where no mass limit can be set. Additionally, a new parameter space of bilinear R-parity violation is considered, one with a natural SUSY spectrum with light third-generation squarks and higgsinos. A large part of the associated parameter space is excluded, up to values of $\mu\approx 550~\rm GeV$ and $m_{\tilde{q}_{\rm L,3}}\approx 800~\rm GeV$.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cetin, Serkant Ali
Romaniouk, Anatoli
Sasmaz, Uygar
dc:dc.dc:title: Induced Radioactivity of Argon and Krypton as Active Gas in ATLAS-ID-TRT
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Estimates of the radioactivity levels of the TRT gas system with alternative gas options of Argon and Krypton activated during LHC operation are presented. Activity and dose rate calculations for these gases are evaluated and compared with the original active gas which is Xenon. Finally the results are discussed in view of CERN safety limits.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Rangel Smith, Camila
Madsen, Alexander
Ferrari, Arnaud
Isacson, Max Fredrik
Burghgrave, Blake
Griffiths, Justin
Bertsche, David
Chakraborty, Dhiman
Gradin, Per Olov Joakim
Pelikan, Daniel
Schaarschmidt, Jana
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for charged Higgs bosons in the $\tau$+lepton final state with $pp$ collision data recorded at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS experiment.
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The experimental observation of charged Higgs bosons, $H^{\pm}$, which are predicted by many models with an extended Higgs sector, would indicate physics beyond the Standard Model. This note presents the results of a search for charged Higgs bosons in 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data recorded at $\sqrt{s} = 8~\mbox{TeV}$ with the ATLAS experiment, using the $\tau$+lepton channel with a hadronically decaying $\tau$ in the final state. No evidence for a charged Higgs boson is found. For the mass range of $m_{H^{\pm}}$ = 80--160~GeV, upper limits are set on the branching fraction $\mbox{BR}(t \to bH^{\pm}) \times \mbox{BR}(H^{\pm} \to \tau\nu)$ between 1.1% and 0.3%. For the mass range of $m_{H^{\pm}}$ = 180-1000 GeV, upper limits are set on the production cross section times branching fraction, $\sigma(pp \to tH^{\pm} + X) \times \mbox{BR}(H^{\pm} \to \tau\nu)$, between 0.93 and 0.03 pb.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Isaev, Alexander
Karyukhin, Andrey
Shalanda, Nikolay
Solodkov, Alexander
Solovyanov, Oleg
Starchenko, Evgeny
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Tile Calorimeter special cells properties
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The optical properties of the ATLAS hadronic Tile calorimeter non-standard scintillating tiles have been studied using point like Sr90 radioactive source. A side by side comparison of the results with those of standard tiles, including the response to the Cs137 source, helps to transfer the overall properties of the standard tiles to the cut ones. Acquired response distributions and ratios, supported by MC studies, might be used for precise calibration of special cells of the Tile calorimeter.

dc:dc.dc:title: The LUCID detector

dc:dc.dc:title: Comissioning of the ATLAS tau-lepton reconstruction using $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: As part of the preparations for the commissioning of the ATLAS tau reconstruction and identification algorithms for Run 2 of the Large Hadron Collider, a set of studies is presented, based on data taken during $pp$ collisions at a center-of-mass energy of $13\TeV$ during 2015. Some of the basic input quantities from selected reconstructed tau objects were measured and the results were compared to the prediction of the Monte Carlo simulation.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gaudiello, Andrea
dc:dc.dc:title: Pixel dE/dx plots in Run 2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS Pixel detector can measure the charge released by particle crossing the sensors with good resolution. An algorithm to provide a track Pixel dE/dx was developped in Run1. A new algorithm that exploits the new layer added in Run 2 (IBL) has been deployed and performance is shown in these plots.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Oide, Hideyuki
dc:dc.dc:title: Run2 Pixel and IBL Timing Performance Plots
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Pixel and IBL Timing Performance Plots Run2 and M-week commissioning

dc:dc.dc:creator: Yamaguchi, Daiki
dc:dc.dc:title: The average hit occupancies and the average fraction of modules with synchronization errors at Pixel/IBL in Run2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The average hit occupancy at IBL and B-Layer as a function of the average number of pile-up in luminosity block units (one luminosity block corresponds approximately to one minute of data-taking) in Run1 and Run2 are shown. The average fraction of modules with synchronization errors for each run of the data-taking at IBL and Pixel barrel layers in Run2 are shown.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Motohashi, Kazuki
Oide, Hideyuki
dc:dc.dc:title: Approval Candidates of IBL DCS Monitoring Plots
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: IBL DCS monitoring software has been developted to monitor the operation stability. This slides contain some plots of IBL DCS which demonstrate the ability of the monitoring in offline DQ.

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for New Phenomena in Dijet Events with the ATLAS Detector at $\sqrt{s}=$13 $\rm TeV$
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Mass and angular distributions of dijet events produced in LHC proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=13~\rm TeV$ and collected by the ATLAS detector will be studied using the first 2015 LHC Run-2 data set with an integrated luminosity of XX fb−1. Dijet masses up to XX $\rm TeV$ are probed.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Henriques Correia, Ana Maria
Ishino, Masaya
Paramonov, Alexander
dc:dc.dc:title: The potential of using the ATLAS Tile calorimeter in Phase-II for the Level-0 muon trigger
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document describes the potential of the hadronic (Tile) calorimeter to register muons for the Level-0 muon trigger. The calorimeter can be used in combination with MDT, RPC, and TGC chambers to enable high-efficiency and high-coverage Level-0 triggers for single muons with $p_{\rm T}>15$ GeV or for two-lepton signatures with a lower threshold. The Level-0 muon trigger is intended for the Phase-II of the LHC operations program. Performance of a coincidence requirement applied to energy deposited in the calorimeter and L1_MU10 and L1_MU15 muon triggers was evaluated as a benchmark. The calorimeter provides nearly hermetic coverage for muon detection within $|\eta|<1.4$. The overall efficiency for detection of a muon with $p_{\rm T}>10$ GeV is expected to be better than 98% when the fake rate is less than 13%. Some of the inefficiency observed in Run-I is caused by disabled channels and other intermittent issues affecting the calorimeter. None of those are expected to remain in the Phase-2 since the readout electronic system of the calorimeter is going to be upgraded. The new system is expected to feature smaller noise and all-digital readout for the Level-0 triggers. Time of a muon crossing a cell is measured with accuracy of 4-5 ns. The spacial resolution in $\phi$ is $\pi/32$ and the resolution in $\eta$ is about 0.2. The outermost layer of the calorimeter, D-layer, is used to make the muon detection robust against pileup $pp$ collisions.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the tt̄W and tt̄Z production cross sections in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV: combination of the $2ℓ$OS, $2ℓ$SS, $3ℓ$ and $4ℓ$ channels.
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The combination of the measurements of the production cross sections of top quark pairs in association with a $W$ or $Z$ boson performed in four different final states using 20.3/fb of data collected by the ATLAS detector is presented. Final states with two opposite- or same-signed, three or four leptons, are considered. From a simultaneous fit of the tt̄Z and tt̄W signal processes, the tt̄Z cross section is measured to be $\sigma_{tt̄Z} = 176^{+58}_{-52}$ fb, corresponding to a $4.2\sigma$ excess over the background-only hypothesis, while the tt̄W cross section is measured to be $\sigma_{tt̄W} = 369^{+100}_{-91}$ fb, corresponding to a $5.0\sigma$ excess over the background-only hypothesis. The background-only hypothesis with neither tt̄Z nor tt̄W is excluded at $7.1\sigma$. All measurements are consistent with next-to-leading-order theoretical calculations for the tt̄Z and tt̄W processes.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bessidskaia Bylund, Olga
Khandanyan, Hovhannes
Mcfayden, Joshua Angus
Sjoelin, Joergen
Suruliz, Kerim
Gellerstedt, Karl
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t \bar t Z$ and $t \bar t W$ production cross sections in final states with three leptons or two same-sign muons with 20.3 $\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of $\sqrt s = 8$ TeV $pp$ collision data collected by the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ production at the ATLAS detector at the LHC is presented. The search is performed on $20.3 \, {\rm fb}^{-1}$ of data collected by the ATLAS detector in 2012. Final states with three leptons and two same-sign muons are considered in which the $Z$ or non-top $W$ bosons decay to a pair of leptons, and one of the $W$ bosons coming from $t\to bW$ decays gives rise to a charged lepton. In a simultaneous fit for $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ production, the $t\bar{t}Z$ production signal strength with respect to the Standard Model is measured to be $0.74^{+0.32}_{-0.28}$ with a significance of 3.1$\sigma$ (3.7$\sigma$ expected), and the $t\bar{t}W$ production signal strength is measured to be $1.35^{+0.61}_{-0.51}$ with a significance of 3.1$\sigma$ (2.3$\sigma$ expected).

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dao, Valerio
Guindon, Stefan
Shabalina, Elizaveta
Vazquez Schroeder, Tamara
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the associated production of a vector boson (W, Z) and top quark pair in the opposite sign dilepton channel with $\boldsymbol{pp}$ collisions at $\boldsymbol{\sqrt{s} = 8}$ TeV with the ATLAS detector at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the production of vector bosons (W, Z) in association with a pair of top quarks ($t\bar{t}V$) is presented. The analysis uses 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8TeV$, collected with the ATLAS detector of the Large Hadron Collider. The search focuses on final states containing two opposite-sign leptons, electrons or muons. A $t\bar{t}V$ signal strength $\hat{\mu} = 0.63^{+0.64}_{-0.58}$ times the Standard Model value is obtained, with an observed significance of 1.09 $\sigma$. Additionally, a model-independent two-dimensional fit is performed to measure the signal strength of both $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ processes.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Limosani, Antonio
Zhou, Chen
Kruse, Mark
Finelli, Kevin Daniel
Paramonov, Alexander
Benjamin, Douglas
Rifki, Othmane
Saavedra, Aldo
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t\bar{t}W$ production cross-section using events with same-sign leptons from $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document summarizes a measurement of the $t\bar{t}W$ cross-section using a combined likelihood fit to the distribution of $E_T^{\mathrm{miss}}$ and $N_{\mathrm{jets}}$. The measurement uses $20.3\,\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of data from proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}$=8 TeV observed by the ATLAS experiment at CERN. This document is focused on the two same-sign lepton channel intended to improve the accuracy of the cross-section for $t\bar{t}W$ in a multi-channel combination. The measured cross-section of $t\bar{t}W$ production using only the same-sign channels described in this note is $429\pm100$ fb using the 1 and 2 $b$-tagged jets samples. Using only the 2 $b$-tagged jet sample, the cross-section is measured to be $490\pm128$ fb for $t\bar{t}W$ These measurements correspond to $t\bar{t}W$ signal significances of $5.1\sigma$ and $5.0\sigma$, respectively.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cristinziani, M
Meyer, C
Schulte, A
Yau, K
Machefer, Evan
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the production cross-section σ(tt̄Z) in final states with four leptons using 20.3/fb of pp collisions at 8 TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for tt̄Z production in final states with exactly 4 isolated electrons or muons with the ATLAS detector at the LHC is presented in this note. The data sample used corresponds to 20.3/fb of data collected in the year 2012. A simultaneous fit is used to constrain the dibosonic background with two $Z$ bosons - which is one of the major backgrounds for this analysis - and to measure the signal strength for the tt̄Z process in dedicated signal regions. The signal strength is measured to be $1.44^{+0.99}_{-0.69}$ and the background only hypothesis can be ruled out at a confidence level of 2.4$\sigma$ (2.0$\sigma$ expected). The inclusive tt̄Z cross-section is measured as $\sigma_{tt̄Z} = 0.30^{+0.18}_{-0.13} \text{(stat.)} ^{+0.09}_{-0.04} \text{(syst.) pb} = 0.30^{+0.20}_{-0.14}\:\text{pb}$.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the $t\bar{t}$ production cross-section in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV using $e\mu$ events with $b$-tagged jets
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes a measurement of the inclusive $t\bar{t}$ production cross-section $\sigma_{t\bar{t}}$ with an initial ATLAS data sample of 0.078 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV, using dilepton $t\bar{t}$ events with an opposite-sign $e\mu$ pair in the final state. Jets containing $b$ quarks were tagged using the MV2c20 tagging algorithm exploiting the long lifetime, high decay multiplicity and high mass of $b$-hadrons. The numbers of events with exactly one and exactly two $b$-tagged jets were counted and used to simultaneously determine $\sigma_{t\bar{t}}$ and the efficiency to reconstruct and $b$-tag a jet from a top quark decay, minimising the associated systematic uncertainties. The cross-section was measured to be $\sigma_{t\bar{t}}=825\pm 49 \pm 60 \pm 83$ pb, where the three uncertainties are due to data statistics, internal systematic effects and the knowledge of the integrated luminosity, giving a total relative uncertainty of 13.7 %.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Durglishvili, Archil
Djobava, Tamar
Mosidze, Maia
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of flavor changing neutral currents inspired top quark decays $t\rightarrow qZ$ in $t\bar{t}$ pairs production at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV in 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data collected with the ATLAS Detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for flavour changing neutral current (FCNC) processes in top-quark decays is presented. Data collected from proton-proton ($pp$) collisions at the LHC at a centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV during 2012, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{-1}$, were analysed. A search was performed for top-quark pair-production events, with one top quark decaying through the $t \rightarrow qZ$ FCNC $(q = u, c)$ channel, and the other through the Standard Model dominant mode $t \rightarrow Wb$. Only the decay of the $Z$ boson to charged leptons and hadronic decay of $W$ boson were considered as signal. Consequently, the final-state topology is characterized by the presence of two isolated charged leptons and at least four jets. No evidence for a signal is found and an observed (expected) upper limit on the $t \rightarrow qZ$ branching ratio of $2.9\times10^{-3}$ ($2.7\times10^{-3}$) is set at the 95$\%$ confidence level.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Aaboud, Morad
Santoni, Claudio
dc:dc.dc:title: Response of the gap/crack scintillator counters in Run 1
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Isolated muons measurements were used to check a) the uniformity, b) the stability and c) the energy scale of the gap/crack scintillator counters response. Data collected in 2010, 2011 and 2012 were analyzed. No clear evidence of miss calibrated cell was detected. The response of the E1, E2, and E3 cells in the three years and of the E4 cells in 2011 and 2012 is stable and equalized inside few percent. In 2010 the response of the E4 cell shows a deviation of about -8% corresponding to 3 sigmas with the respect to the mean observed in the following years. The data show that the EM scale used in ATLAS to measure the jet energy deposited in the gap/crack scintillator counters deviate from the value obtained using electrons at test beam by about 5%.

dc:dc.dc:creator: O'Rourke, Abigail Alexandra
dc:dc.dc:title: Software for the Sonar project
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Sonar project uses custom ultrasonic instruments in the ATLAS experiment to measure gas flow and analyse binary gas mixtures. These parameters are determined from measurements of sound velocity within the gas, by transmitting and detecting ultrasound pulses. Five instru- ments are integrated into the ATLAS detector control system. Three monitor coolant leakage within the ATLAS silicon tracker while two are integrated into the external plant. Software to control and monitor these systems has been developed using Siemens SIMATIC WinCC.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Yamaguchi, Daiki
dc:dc.dc:title: Pixel/IBL offline monitoring plots in Run2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The history of hit readout occupancy, the charge distributions of cluster on tracks for IBL and Pixel Barrel layers, the hit readout occupancy maps for IBL and B-Layer, the hit readout occupancy as a function of the average number of interactions per bunch crossing, the truncation flag rate plots are shown.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Biedermann, Dustin
Grancagnolo, Sergio
dc:dc.dc:title: Assessing the quality of Lorentz angle measurement in the ATLAS SCT subdetector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Lorentz angle might evolve during data taking periods, and a procedure has been developed to establish the quality of its measurement. After applying various scaling factors, a full reconstruction was performed and residuals were recalculated. On a sample of express stream data collected in September 2012, it has been verified that the optimal correction is currently in place. The same procedure can be used in the future to find out when any adjustment will be required.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Robinson, Dave
Ward, Patricia
Lewis, Dave
Barlow, Nick
dc:dc.dc:title: SCT Lorentz Angle Plots for Approval
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Lorentz angle data measured with the SCT detecor in the first 13TeV pp collisions

dc:dc.dc:creator: Mortensen, Simon Stark
Jakobsen, Sune
Guerrero Llorente, Alonso
dc:dc.dc:title: Trigger efficiency for the ALFA detector at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, $\beta^{*}$ = 90 m
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The trigger efficiency of the ATLAS subdetector ALFA is investigated for elastic like events in $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, $\beta^*=90$ m data. The calibration stream is used to find the efficiency of an elastic event and the result is normalized to the physics stream. The efficiency for the CTP trigger items aimed for physics analysis (L1\_ELAST15 and L1\_ELAST18) is found to be $99.912\pm0.002\%$. The trigger efficiency for the individual ALFA detector is found in three ways: Using the trigger tiles, using the CTP items, and using the CTP items with a random event selection. The efficiency in all three cases is above $99\%$ except for detector B7L1U where one of the trigger tiles might have a problem.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Koi, Tatsumi
Marley, Daniel Edison
Morinaga, Masahiro
Weber, Stefan Wolf
Young, Charles
dc:dc.dc:title: New SmallWheel Background Studies
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The SmallWheel in theMuon Spectrometer will be replaced by the New SmallWheel as part of the Phase-I upgrade, and its shielding will have to be modified accordingly. This Note summarizes the shieldiong studies leading up to the final design of the New Small Wheel, and reports on the expected background in this new geometry. There is a substantial increase in rate relative to the Run 2 geometry: up to a factor of 2 in the small radius region of the New Small Wheel, and ' 50% at the high jzj region of the innermost barrel muon chamber. Additional cladding around the New Small Wheel support can reduce this background.

dc:dc.dc:title: The ATLAS Jet Trigger for Initial LHC Run II
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note gives an overview of the jet trigger running in the ATLAS High Level Trigger for initial LHC Run-2 data taking. It gives details of the jet trigger menu, explaining its design, gives a description of the most important components of the online selection software, describes the validation and monitoring infrastructures developed to allow its operation, and concludes with an account of early jet trigger commissioning.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Becot, C
Andari, N
Fayard, L
Unal, G
dc:dc.dc:title: Difference of energy response between the high and medium gain of the ATLAS electromagnetic calorimeter
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: In this note we report a study of the difference of energy response between the high and medium gain chains, done using the $Z$ boson mass. A sizeable difference is observed between the two chains, especially in a few well defined regions of the detector. An ad-hoc correction has been derived and will be applied to physics analysis using electrons or photons. As no hint of error source have been found it was decided to include a systematic error of the same size than the correction.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Chan, S
Huth, J
Lopez Mateos, D
Mercurio, K
dc:dc.dc:title: $ZH\to llb\bar{b}$ Analysis with Telescoping Jets
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note summarizes the work done to improve the significance of invariant mass measurements in the $ZH\to llb\bar{b}$ analysis using the telescoping jets algorithm. Two $b$-jet axes are used as points in the $\eta,\phi$ plane around which multiple circles (cones) are drawn. The collections of particles in these cones form the successively larger telescoping jets and are used to build multiple event interpretations. Improvements come from using information from these multiple event interpretations. This study uses 2012 Monte Carlo and closely follows the event selection of the of the first full Run 1 preliminary search for $H\to b\bar{b}$ in ATLAS. At reconstructed level, using 12 telescoping radii, from $0.4-1.5$ in steps of $0.1$, gives a 20.5% improvement in the expected statistical significance using a simple $S/\sqrt{B}$ metric.

dc:dc.dc:title: {Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search - Appendices
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves as support for the note ``Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I \wh~search'', holding an extended selection of plots as an Appendix.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Amaral Coutinho, Yara
Begalli, Marcia

dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves both as \emph{a posteriori} support for the Run I \vh~search paper, and investigates several potential $b$-jet energy corrections, proposing one of them for the Run II analysis. Since the di-$b$-jet invariant mass (\mbb) is the best known signal to background discriminant, the search sensitivity increases when the \mbb~resolution improves. We reproduce the 2-jet 2-$b$-tag \wh~sample. After the $b$-jet reconstruction and event selection are reviewed, the four consecutive jet energy corrections are studied and confirmed to be beneficial to the \wh~search. We further show that a transverse momentum (Pt) correction derived in the \wh~sample gives consistent results with the one used, derived in the \zhll~sample. In 12\% of cases where the $b$ quark decays semileptonically through a muon and a neutrino, even after the muon-in-jet (Mu) correction, the jet energy response is about 10\% smaller due to the unaccounted neutrino. 78.7\%, 20.1\% and 1.2\% of events have zero, one or two jets with muons, respectively. Relative to the generated \mbb~peak, the reconstructed peak is 0.7\% higher, 3.4\% lower and 5.9\% lower, respectively. This is improved to 0.4\% lower, 0.3\% higher and 2.2\% higher, respectively, and the total \mbb~width is improved by 1.5\%, from 12.9 GeV to 12.7 GeV, when two different Pt corrections are used, depending on whether the jet contains or not a muon. We therefore recommend that, at a minimum, this approach is taken for the Run II analysis. We also investigate corrections based on regressions using artificial neural networks. We show that using the Pt as sole input is equivalent to the existing Pt correction, and adding the change in Pt due to the Mu correction as a second input is equivalent with two Pt corrections depending on whether there is a muon or not. Several other further potential improvements are outlined for future study.

dc:dc.dc:title: Proposal for truth particle observable definitions
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document summarises the main points of the truth particle workshop about the use of the truth objects in the performance and physics analyses.

dc:dc.dc:title: A search for high-mass resonances decaying to $\tau^{+}\tau^{-}$ in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for high-mass resonances decaying into $\tau^{+}\tau^{-}$ final states using proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}= 8$ TeV produced by the Large Hadron Collider is presented. The data were recorded with the ATLAS detector and correspond to an integrated luminosity of 19.5-20.3 fb$^{-1}$. No statistically significant excess above the Standard Model expectation is observed; 95% credibility upper limits are set on the cross section times branching fraction of $Z^{\prime}$ resonances decaying into $\tau^+\tau^-$ pairs as a function of the resonance mass. As a result, $Z^{\prime}$ bosons of the Sequential Standard Model with masses less than 2.02 TeV are excluded at 95% credibility. The impact of the fermionic couplings on the $Z^{\prime}$ acceptance is investigated and limits are also placed on a $Z^{\prime}$ model that exhibits enhanced couplings to third generation fermions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bulekov, O
Marino, C
Romaniouk, A
Smirnov, Y
Zimmermann, S
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for heavy long-lived multi-charged particles in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for heavy long-lived multi-charged particles is performed using the ATLAS detector at the LHC. Data collected in 2012 at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV from $pp$ collisions corresponding to an integrated luminosity of $20.3$ fb$^{−1}$ are examined. Particles producing anomalously high ionisation, consistent with long-lived massive particles with electric charges from $|q|=2e$ to $|q|=6e$ are searched for. No signal candidate events are observed, and $95\%$ confidence level cross-section upper limits are interpreted as lower mass limits for a Drell--Yan production model. The mass limits range between $660$ and $785$ GeV.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of top-quark pair differential cross-sections in the $l$+jets channel in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note documents the measurement by the ATLAS experiment of the top pair produc- tion differential cross-sections as a function of the top quark transverse momentum, absolute rapidity and of the transverse momentum, mass and absolute rapidity of the $t\bar{t}$ system. The study was performed using data from pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV collected by the ATLAS detector in 2012 and corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{−1}$. The $t\bar{t}$ events were selected in the lepton (electron or muon) + jets channel. Due to the large $t\bar{t}$ cross section at the LHC, such measurements allow a detailed study of the properties of the top- quark production and decay, enabling precision tests of perturbative QCD. There is good agreement between the measured data and the theoretical predictions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: HSG1, The
HSG2, The
HSG7, The
dc:dc.dc:title: Combination of differential fiducial cross-sections of Higgs boson production measured in the $H \rightarrow ZZ^* \rightarrow 4\ell$ and $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ channels using 20.3 fb$^{−1}$ of $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV $pp$ collision data at the ATLAS detector.
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note decribes the combination of the measurements of differential cross-sections of Higgs boson production in the $H \rightarrow ZZ^* \rightarrow 4\ell$ and $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ decay channels. The measurements are extrapolated to the total and a common fiducial phase space. They are compared to results from different calculations. Measurements are performed in bins of the transverse momentum and the rapidity of the Higgs boson, as well as the number of jets and the transverse momentum of the leading jet. For this analysis, 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data were used, produced at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV center-of-mass energy at the LHC and recorded by the ATLAS detector.

dc:dc.dc:title: Constraints on promptly decaying supersymmetric particles with lepton-number- and $R$-parity-violating interactions using Run I ATLAS data
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Searches for supersymmetry (SUSY) at the LHC frequently assume the conservation of R-parity in their design, optimisation and interpretation. In the case that R-parity is not conserved, the resulting constraints on SUSY particle masses may be significantly weakened. In this document, a selection of ATLAS SUSY searches, mostly optimised for R-parity-conserving SUSY, are reinterpreted in new R-parity-violating (RPV) SUSY models. All forms of renormalisable RPV interactions with lepton-number violation are considered. For LLE and LQD RPV operators, squark and gluino production cross-sections are constrained as a function of the $\tilde{\chi}_1^0$ branching fraction to taus and $b$-quarks. These limits imply exclusion of squark and gluino masses below $\mathcal{O}(1~\rm TeV)$ at 95% confidence level, except in the case of squark production when $m(\tilde{\chi}_1^0)/m(\tilde{q})=0.1$, where no mass limit can be set. Additionally, a new parameter space of bilinear R-parity violation is considered, one with a natural SUSY spectrum with light third-generation squarks and higgsinos. A large part of the associated parameter space is excluded, up to values of $\mu\approx 550~\rm GeV$ and $m_{\tilde{q}_{\rm L,3}}\approx 800~\rm GeV$.

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for charged Higgs bosons in the $\tau$+lepton final state with $pp$ collision data recorded at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS experiment.
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The experimental observation of charged Higgs bosons, $H^{\pm}$, which are predicted by many models with an extended Higgs sector, would indicate physics beyond the Standard Model. This note presents the results of a search for charged Higgs bosons in 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data recorded at $\sqrt{s} = 8~\mbox{TeV}$ with the ATLAS experiment, using the $\tau$+lepton channel with a hadronically decaying $\tau$ in the final state. No evidence for a charged Higgs boson is found. For the mass range of $m_{H^{\pm}}$ = 80--160~GeV, upper limits are set on the branching fraction $\mbox{BR}(t \to bH^{\pm}) \times \mbox{BR}(H^{\pm} \to \tau\nu)$ between 1.1% and 0.3%. For the mass range of $m_{H^{\pm}}$ = 180-1000 GeV, upper limits are set on the production cross section times branching fraction, $\sigma(pp \to tH^{\pm} + X) \times \mbox{BR}(H^{\pm} \to \tau\nu)$, between 0.93 and 0.03 pb.

dc:dc.dc:title: Comissioning of the ATLAS tau-lepton reconstruction using $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: As part of the preparations for the commissioning of the ATLAS tau reconstruction and identification algorithms for Run 2 of the Large Hadron Collider, a set of studies is presented, based on data taken during $pp$ collisions at a center-of-mass energy of $13\TeV$ during 2015. Some of the basic input quantities from selected reconstructed tau objects were measured and the results were compared to the prediction of the Monte Carlo simulation.

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for New Phenomena in Dijet Events with the ATLAS Detector at $\sqrt{s}=$13 $\rm TeV$

dc:dc.dc:description: Mass and angular distributions of dijet events produced in LHC proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=13~\rm TeV$ and collected by the ATLAS detector will be studied using the first 2015 LHC Run-2 data set with an integrated luminosity of XX fb−1. Dijet masses up to XX $\rm TeV$ are probed.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the tt̄W and tt̄Z production cross sections in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV: combination of the $2ℓ$OS, $2ℓ$SS, $3ℓ$ and $4ℓ$ channels.
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The combination of the measurements of the production cross sections of top quark pairs in association with a $W$ or $Z$ boson performed in four different final states using 20.3/fb of data collected by the ATLAS detector is presented. Final states with two opposite- or same-signed, three or four leptons, are considered. From a simultaneous fit of the tt̄Z and tt̄W signal processes, the tt̄Z cross section is measured to be $\sigma_{tt̄Z} = 176^{+58}_{-52}$ fb, corresponding to a $4.2\sigma$ excess over the background-only hypothesis, while the tt̄W cross section is measured to be $\sigma_{tt̄W} = 369^{+100}_{-91}$ fb, corresponding to a $5.0\sigma$ excess over the background-only hypothesis. The background-only hypothesis with neither tt̄Z nor tt̄W is excluded at $7.1\sigma$. All measurements are consistent with next-to-leading-order theoretical calculations for the tt̄Z and tt̄W processes.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bessidskaia Bylund, Olga
Khandanyan, Hovhannes
Mcfayden, Joshua Angus
Sjoelin, Joergen
Suruliz, Kerim
Gellerstedt, Karl
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t \bar t Z$ and $t \bar t W$ production cross sections in final states with three leptons or two same-sign muons with 20.3 $\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of $\sqrt s = 8$ TeV $pp$ collision data collected by the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ production at the ATLAS detector at the LHC is presented. The search is performed on $20.3 \, {\rm fb}^{-1}$ of data collected by the ATLAS detector in 2012. Final states with three leptons and two same-sign muons are considered in which the $Z$ or non-top $W$ bosons decay to a pair of leptons, and one of the $W$ bosons coming from $t\to bW$ decays gives rise to a charged lepton. In a simultaneous fit for $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ production, the $t\bar{t}Z$ production signal strength with respect to the Standard Model is measured to be $0.74^{+0.32}_{-0.28}$ with a significance of 3.1$\sigma$ (3.7$\sigma$ expected), and the $t\bar{t}W$ production signal strength is measured to be $1.35^{+0.61}_{-0.51}$ with a significance of 3.1$\sigma$ (2.3$\sigma$ expected).

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dao, Valerio
Guindon, Stefan
Shabalina, Elizaveta
Vazquez Schroeder, Tamara
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the associated production of a vector boson (W, Z) and top quark pair in the opposite sign dilepton channel with $\boldsymbol{pp}$ collisions at $\boldsymbol{\sqrt{s} = 8}$ TeV with the ATLAS detector at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the production of vector bosons (W, Z) in association with a pair of top quarks ($t\bar{t}V$) is presented. The analysis uses 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8TeV$, collected with the ATLAS detector of the Large Hadron Collider. The search focuses on final states containing two opposite-sign leptons, electrons or muons. A $t\bar{t}V$ signal strength $\hat{\mu} = 0.63^{+0.64}_{-0.58}$ times the Standard Model value is obtained, with an observed significance of 1.09 $\sigma$. Additionally, a model-independent two-dimensional fit is performed to measure the signal strength of both $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ processes.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Limosani, Antonio
Zhou, Chen

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t\bar{t}W$ production cross-section using events with same-sign leptons from $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document summarizes a measurement of the $t\bar{t}W$ cross-section using a combined likelihood fit to the distribution of $E_T^{\mathrm{miss}}$ and $N_{\mathrm{jets}}$. The measurement uses $20.3\,\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of data from proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}$=8 TeV observed by the ATLAS experiment at CERN. This document is focused on the two same-sign lepton channel intended to improve the accuracy of the cross-section for $t\bar{t}W$ in a multi-channel combination. The measured cross-section of $t\bar{t}W$ production using only the same-sign channels described in this note is $429\pm100$ fb using the 1 and 2 $b$-tagged jets samples. Using only the 2 $b$-tagged jet sample, the cross-section is measured to be $490\pm128$ fb for $t\bar{t}W$ These measurements correspond to $t\bar{t}W$ signal significances of $5.1\sigma$ and $5.0\sigma$, respectively.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cristinziani, M
Meyer, C
Schulte, A
Yau, K
Machefer, Evan
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the production cross-section σ(tt̄Z) in final states with four leptons using 20.3/fb of pp collisions at 8 TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for tt̄Z production in final states with exactly 4 isolated electrons or muons with the ATLAS detector at the LHC is presented in this note. The data sample used corresponds to 20.3/fb of data collected in the year 2012. A simultaneous fit is used to constrain the dibosonic background with two $Z$ bosons - which is one of the major backgrounds for this analysis - and to measure the signal strength for the tt̄Z process in dedicated signal regions. The signal strength is measured to be $1.44^{+0.99}_{-0.69}$ and the background only hypothesis can be ruled out at a confidence level of 2.4$\sigma$ (2.0$\sigma$ expected). The inclusive tt̄Z cross-section is measured as $\sigma_{tt̄Z} = 0.30^{+0.18}_{-0.13} \text{(stat.)} ^{+0.09}_{-0.04} \text{(syst.) pb} = 0.30^{+0.20}_{-0.14}\:\text{pb}$.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the $t\bar{t}$ production cross-section in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV using $e\mu$ events with $b$-tagged jets
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes a measurement of the inclusive $t\bar{t}$ production cross-section $\sigma_{t\bar{t}}$ with an initial ATLAS data sample of 0.078 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV, using dilepton $t\bar{t}$ events with an opposite-sign $e\mu$ pair in the final state. Jets containing $b$ quarks were tagged using the MV2c20 tagging algorithm exploiting the long lifetime, high decay multiplicity and high mass of $b$-hadrons. The numbers of events with exactly one and exactly two $b$-tagged jets were counted and used to simultaneously determine $\sigma_{t\bar{t}}$ and the efficiency to reconstruct and $b$-tag a jet from a top quark decay, minimising the associated systematic uncertainties. The cross-section was measured to be $\sigma_{t\bar{t}}=825\pm 49 \pm 60 \pm 83$ pb, where the three uncertainties are due to data statistics, internal systematic effects and the knowledge of the integrated luminosity, giving a total relative uncertainty of 13.7 %.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Durglishvili, Archil
Djobava, Tamar
Mosidze, Maia
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of flavor changing neutral currents inspired top quark decays $t\rightarrow qZ$ in $t\bar{t}$ pairs production at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV in 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data collected with the ATLAS Detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for flavour changing neutral current (FCNC) processes in top-quark decays is presented. Data collected from proton-proton ($pp$) collisions at the LHC at a centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV during 2012, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{-1}$, were analysed. A search was performed for top-quark pair-production events, with one top quark decaying through the $t \rightarrow qZ$ FCNC $(q = u, c)$ channel, and the other through the Standard Model dominant mode $t \rightarrow Wb$. Only the decay of the $Z$ boson to charged leptons and hadronic decay of $W$ boson were considered as signal. Consequently, the final-state topology is characterized by the presence of two isolated charged leptons and at least four jets. No evidence for a signal is found and an observed (expected) upper limit on the $t \rightarrow qZ$ branching ratio of $2.9\times10^{-3}$ ($2.7\times10^{-3}$) is set at the 95$\%$ confidence level.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Volpi, Guido
dc:dc.dc:title: A Fast Hardware Tracker for the ATLAS Trigger System
dc:dc.dc:subject: Detectors and Experimental Techniques
dc:dc.dc:description: As the LHC luminosity is ramped up to 3×1034 cm−2 s−1 and beyond, the high rates, multiplicities, and energies of particles seen by the detectors will pose a unique challenge. The current three-level trigger is designed to allow a rate reduction from 40 MHz to about 400 Hz. The Fast Tracker (FTK) is an approved upgrade to the current ATLAS trigger system that will operate at full Level-1 output rates and provide high-quality tracks reconstructed in the entire inner detector by the start of processing in the Level-2 Trigger. This will allow to select signals with high purity selection and reject efficiently fakes from QCD background and therefore will free time in Level-2 farm for more refined selections. FTK solves the combinatorial challenge inherent to tracking by exploiting the massive parallelism of associative memories that can compare inner detector hits to millions of pre-calculated patterns simultaneously. The tracking problem within matched patterns is further simplified by using pre-computed linearized fitting constants and relying on fast DSPs in modern commercial FPGAs. Overall, FTK is able to compute the helix parameters for all tracks in an event and apply quality cuts in less than 100 μs. The system design is defined and the performance presented with respect to high transverse momentum (high-pT) Level-2 objects: b jets, tau jets, and isolated leptons.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Borodin, Mikhail
De, Kaushik

dc:dc.dc:title: Unified system for processing real and simulated data in the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The physics goals of the next Large Hadron Collider run include high precision tests of the Standard Model and searches for new physics. These goals “at the Gates of Nature” require detailed comparison of data with computational models simulating the expected data behavior. To highlight the role which modeling and simulation plays in future scientific discovery, we report on use cases and experience with a unified system built to process both real and simulated data of growing volume and variety.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: DAMDID Full Paper submission deadline is April 30.

dc:dc.dc:title: Summary Report on the Expected Impact of a Large Eta Detector in ATLAS on Standard Model Physics Analyses
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The extension and upgrade of ATLAS sub-detectors (inner tracker system, calorimeters, muon-system) in the forward $\eta$-region between $2.5$ and $4.0$ leads to an improved reconstruction of physics objects and hence leads also to am improvement in physics measurement at the LHC. In this note, we summarize several studies, which estimate the impact of an extended ATLAS detector on physics measurements in the Standard Model group. In particular, the effect of an extend inner tracker system is discussed.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvet, David
dc:dc.dc:title: The Laser calibration of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter during the LHC run 1
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This article describes the Laser calibration system of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter, with details about the stability of its associated readout electronics and about the method developed to compute the calibration constants to correct for the variations of the gain of the calorimeter photomultipliers. The detection and correction of timing mis-configuration of the Tile Calorimeter using the Laser system are also presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The goal is to publish this paper with a Tile list of authors.

Backhaus, Malte
dc:dc.dc:title: Comparison of Number of Bad Pixels between IBL Module Production and IBL Stave Quality Assurance
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Plots for approval showing the comparison of numbers of bad pixel as identified in the IBL module production and after loading in the Stave QA test.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hoecker, Andreas
Murray, Bill
Charlton, Dave
Wengler, Thorsten
Heinemann, Beate
Abramowicz, Halina
de Jong, Paul
Kado, Marumi
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS procedures for the approval of physics results
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document provides guidelines and details of the procedures for the preparation and approval of physics results. It describes the roles of all the individuals and groups involved in the approval process, the purpose of the meetings, and gives a step-by-step guide on the procedures. Papers, conference notes and public notes are described.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Grimm, Kathryn
Pagan Griso, Simone
Prokofiev, Kirill
Meloni, Federico
Rudolph, Matthew Scott
Wildauer, Andreas
Yu, David Ren-hwa
Beringer, Juerg
Piacquadio, Giacinto
dc:dc.dc:title: Vertex Reconstruction in Run 1
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This paper presents primary vertex reconstruction methods and performance in proton- proton collision data recorded by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC. Data was taken during 2012 at a center-of-mass energy of √s = 8 TeV. Vertex reconstruction is studies in both data and Monte Carlo simulation by looking at properties such as track multiplicity and track transverse momentum. Vertex reconstruction efficiency and resolution are also presented. The studies are performed both for single vertex interactions and in the presence of multiple particle interactions. It is found that the effects of increased interactions are well understood and modeled effectively.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: For the purpose of ATLAS circulation, this paper has been re-classified as PHYS. The new CDS entry is located here: ATL-COM-PHYS-2016-263 https://cds.cern.ch/record/2140021

dc:dc.dc:creator: Pirumov, Hayk
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of beam orbit drifts on 2012 van der Meer calibration
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The orbit drift correction for luminosity calibration in the 2012 van der Meer scans using BCM and LUCID detectors is presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Alstaty, Mahmoud
Djama, Fares
Miglioranzi, Silvia
dc:dc.dc:title: Cluster Properties and Lorentz Angle Measurement in the 4-Layer Pixel Detector Using Cosmic Rays
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The 4-layer Pixel Detector with the recently installed innermost layer called IBL saw its first data during the 2014 fall cosmic run. This note shows cluster properties and Lorentz angle fits for IBL sensors as well as old barrel layer sensors.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Tavares Delgado, Ademar
ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Design and performance of the ATLAS jet trigger system
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The CERN Large Hadron Collider is the biggest and most powerful particle collider made by man. It produces 40 million proton-proton collisions per second at unprecedented energies to explore the fundamental laws and properties of Nature. The ATLAS experiment is one of the detectors that analyse and record these collisions. It generates an infeasible large data volume that has to be selected before it can be permanently stored. The event selection is made by the ATLAS trigger system, which reduces the data volume by a factor of 10^5 . The trigger system has to be highly configurable in order to adapt to changing running conditions and maximize the physics output whilst keeping the output rate under control. A particularly interesting pattern generated during collisions consists of a collimated spray of particles, known as hadronic jet. To retain the interesting jets and efficiently reject the overwhelming background, optimal jet energy resolution is needed. Therefore the Jet trigger software requires CPU-intensive reconstruction algorithms. In order to reduce the resources needed for the reconstruction step, a partial detector readout scheme was developed, which effectively suppresses the low activity regions of the calorimeter. In this paper we describe the overall ATLAS trigger software, and the jet trigger in particular, along with the improvements made on the system. We then focus on detailed studies of the algorithm timing and the performance impact of the full and partial calorimeter readout schemes. We conclude with an outlook of the jet trigger plans for the next LHC data-taking period.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Chekanov, Sergei
Paramonov, Alexander
Proudfoot, James
dc:dc.dc:title: Simulation of energies per TileCal PMT for pileup events for the LHC phase 2 upgrade
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: An examination of truth-level energies per photomultiplier (PMT) of the Tile calorimeter (TileCal) using Monte Carlo simulations is presented. The full detector simulation was performed for minimum-bias events and for events with high-$p_T$ jets. We studied different pileup scenarios, assuming the average number of interactions per beam crossing $<\mu>$=23, 30, 140 and 200. The truth-level energy distributions for separate TileCal PMTs discussed in this note are valuable inputs for the phase 2 TileCal upgrade studies.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Grimm, Kathryn
Meloni, Federico
Pagan Griso, Simone
Prokofiev, Kirill
Rudolph, Matthew Scott
Wildauer, Andreas
Yu, David Ren-hwa
dc:dc.dc:title: Reconstruction of primary vertices in Run I proton-proton collisions at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents studies on the reconstruction of primary vertices in high luminosity Run I $pp$ collisions using the ATLAS detector at the LHC. Results include both 7 TeV and 8 TeV collisions, but the focus is on 8 TeV running. During the year $2012$, the peak value of instant luminosity recorded by ATLAS was $8\cdot10^{33}\;{\rm cm}^{-2}{\rm s}^{-1}$. While the average number of events per bunch crossing was near 25 for most of 2012 running, special high-pile up runs recorded as many as 70 events per bunch crossing. In such conditions, correct reconstruction of the signal primary vertex and identification of all pile-up interactions in a bunch crossing represents a significant challenge. In this note we quantify the different processes affecting the efficiency of primary vertex reconstruction in such conditions. The mathematical model of such processes is developed and their importance is studied on both Monte Carlo simulation and data collected by the ATLAS experiment. The efficiency of correct reconstruction and identification of primary vertices are studied in detail for several key physics processes at LHC.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Support note for ATL-COM-INDET-2015-002

dc:dc.dc:creator: Mondragon, Matthew Craig
Cribbs, Wayne Allen
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of 2011 and 2012 cosmic ray muon data in ATLAS hadronic calorimeter TileCal
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Cosmic ray muons provide an means of cross checking the calibration of the ATLAS hadronic calorimeter TileCal. The goal of this study was to present the data in a similar fashion to the cosmic ray studies done for the 2008, 2009, and 2010 data for comparison. Cosmic ray data taken in 2011 and 2012 were analyzed to show the uniformity in cell response in TileCal cells in different layers, modules and regions of the detector.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Grinstein, Sebastian
Puigdengoles, Carles
dc:dc.dc:title: DESIGN AND OPERATION OF A QUAD PCB FOR THE AIDA BEAM TELESCOPE PLANE
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note documents the design and performance of the QUAD PCB that was fabricated at IFAE in the framework of the AIDA project [1] to provide four front-end 3D assembly module to be used as a beam telescope plane.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Oleiro Seabra, Luis Filipe
dc:dc.dc:title: ALFA Detector Control System
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ALFA (Absolute Luminosity For ATLAS) is one of the sub-detectors of ATLAS (A Toroidal LHCApparatus). The ALFA system is composed by four stations installed in the LHC tunnel 240 m away from the ATLAS interaction point. Each station has a vacuum and ventilation system, movement control and all the required electronics for signal processing. The Detector Control System (DCS) provides control and monitoring of several components and ensures the safe operation of the detector contributing to good Data Quality. This paper describes the ALFA DCS system including a detector overview, operation aspects and hardware control through a SCADA system, WinCC OA.
