A token is issued within each deployed form as a random string of characters which must then be matched whenever it is posted. Additionally, once the user is authenticated through CERN's Shibboleth single sign-on, Fence assigns them roles and permissions as stored in the database. Clearance attributes can then be bound to individual inputs within their own JSON description so that whenever they are submitted, the resulting system verifies whether the user has the necessary permissions to edit them. Input validation is primarily carried out on the server side with PHP but, following progressive enhancement guidelines, verification routines may be additionally entrusted to the client side by enabling specific HTML5 data attributes which are then handed over to the jQuery validation plugin. User monitoring is accomplished by logging URL requests along with any POST data. The documentation is automatically published from the source code using the Doxygen tool and made accessible in a web interface. Fence, therefore, speeds up the implementation of Web software products while minimizing maintenance overhead and facilitating the comprehension of embedded rules and requirements.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Catmore, James
dc:dc.dc:title: A New Petabyte-scale Data Derivation Framework for ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: During the Long shutdown of the LHC, the ATLAS collaboration overhauled its analysis model based on experience gained during Run 1. A significant component of the model is a "Derivation Framework" that takes the Petabyte-scale AOD output from ATLAS reconstruction and produces samples, typically Terabytes in size, targeted at specific analyses. The framework incorporates all of the functionality of the core reconstruction software, while producing outputs that are simply configured. Event selections are specified via strings, including support for logical operations. The output content can be highly optimised to minimise disk requirements, while maintaining the same C++ interface. The framework includes an interface to the late-stage physics analysis tools, ensuring that the final outputs are consistent with tool requirements. Finally, the framework allows several outputs to be produced for the same input, providing the possibility to optimise configurations to computing resources.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Panitkin, Sergey
De, Kaushik
Klimentov, Alexei
Oleynik, Danila
Petrosyan, Artem
Schovancova, Jaroslava
Vaniachine, Alexandre
Wenaus, Torre
dc:dc.dc:title: Integration of PanDA workload management system with Titan supercomputer at OLCF
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The PanDA (Production and Distributed Analysis) workload management system (WMS) was developed to meet the scale and complexity of LHC distributed computing for the ATLAS experiment. While PanDA currently uses more than 100,000 cores at well over 100 Grid sites with a peak performance of 0.3 petaFLOPS, next LHC data taking run will require more resources than Grid computing can possibly provide. To alleviate these challenges, ATLAS is engaged in an ambitious program to expand the current computing model to include additional resources such as the opportunistic use of supercomputers. We will describe a project aimed at integration of PanDA WMS with Titan supercomputer at Oak Ridge Leadership Computing Facility (OLCF). Current approach utilizes modified PanDA pilot framework for job submission to Titan's batch queues and local data management, with light-weight MPI wrappers to run single threaded workloads in parallel on Titan's multi-core worker nodes. It also gives PanDA new capability to collect, in real time, information about unused worker nodes on Titan, which allows precisely define the size and duration of jobs submitted to Titan according to available free resources. This capability significantly reduces PanDA job wait time while improving Titan’s utilization efficiency. This implementation was tested with a variety of Monte-Carlo workloads on Titan and is being tested on several other supercomputing platforms.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Slides for the CHEP 2015 (April 13-17, 2015)) oral presentation "Integration of PanDA workload management system with Titan supercomputer at OLCF"

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Tile Collaboration
Reed, Robert
dc:dc.dc:title: The Upgrade of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter Readout Electronics for Phase II
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Large Hadron Collider at CERN is scheduled to undergo a major upgrade, called the Phase II Upgrade, in 2022. The ATLAS Tile Calorimeter community will do major modifications to the sub-detector to account for the increased luminosity. More specifically, a large proportion of the current front and back-end electronics will be upgraded in order to digitize all signals generated in the Calorimeters. A Demonstrator program has been established, which combines the current and future architectures, as a proof of principle. The insertion of the first demonstrator is planned for the end of 2015.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The submission date for the proceedings is the 11th March 2015. I apologize for the short notice. There was a misunderstanding on my side. I thought I submitted through the conference and then notified the committee and later apply the changes.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Biesuz, Nicolo Vladi
Citraro, Saverio
Luciano, Pierluigi
Magalotti, Daniel
Rossi, Enrico
dc:dc.dc:title: The Serial Link Processor for the Fast TracKer (FTK) processor at ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Associative Memory (AM) system of the Fast Tracker (FTK) processor has been designed to perform pattern matching using the hit information of the ATLAS experiment silicon tracker. The AM is the heart of FTK and is mainly based on the use of ASICs (AM chips) designed on purpose to execute pattern matching with a high degree of parallelism. It finds track candidates at low resolution that are seeds for a full resolution track fitting. To solve the very challenging data traffic problems inside FTK, multiple board and chip designs have been performed. The currently proposed solution is named the “Serial Link Processor” and is based on an extremely powerful network of 2 Gb/s serial links. This paper reports on the design of the Serial Link Processor consisting of two types of boards, the Local Associative Memory Board (LAMB), a mezzanine where the AM chips are mounted, and the Associative Memory Board (AMB), a 9U VME board which holds and exercises four LAMBs. We report on the performance of the intermediate prototypes (both hardware and firmware) produced for the global FTK integration, an important milestone to be reached before the FTK production.

dc:dc.dc:creator: De Salvo, Alessandro
Maeno Kataoka, Mayuko
Smirnov, Yuri
Sanchez, Arturo
dc:dc.dc:title: The ATLAS Software Installation System v2: a highly available system to install and validate Grid and Cloud sites via Panda
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS Installation System v2 is the evolution of the original system, used since 2003. The original tool has been completely re-designed in terms of database backend and components, adding support for submission to multiple backends, including the original WMS and the new Panda modules. The database engine has been changed from plain MySQL to Galera/Percona and the table structure has been optimized to allow a full High-Availability (HA) solution over WAN. The servlets, running on each frontend, have been also decoupled from local settings, to allow an easy scalability of the system, including the possibility of an HA system with multiple sites. The clients can also be run in multiple copies and in different geographical locations, and take care of sending the installation and validation jobs to the target Grid or Cloud sites. Moreover, the Installation DB is used as source of parameters by the automatic agents running in CVMFS, in order to install the software and distribute it to the sites. The system is in production for ATLAS since 2013, having as main sites in HA the INFN Roma T2 and CERN AI. The LJSFi2 engine is directly interfacing with Panda for the Job Management, AGIS for the site parameter configurations, and CVMFS for both core components and the installation of the software itself. LJSFi2 is also able to use other plugins, and is essentially VO-agnostic, so can be directly used and extended to cope with the requirements of any Grid or Cloud enabled VO. In this work we'll present the architecture, performance, status and possible evolutions to the system for the LHC Run2 and beyond.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: CHEP 2015 Start Date: 13/04/2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor, Ryan P.
Berghaus, Frank
Love, Peter
Leblanc, Matthew Edgar
Di Girolamo, Alessandro
Paterson, Michael
Gable, Ian
Sobie, Randall
Field, Laurence
dc:dc.dc:title: The Evolution of Cloud Computing in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS experiment has successfully incorporated cloud computing technology and cloud resources into its primarily grid-based model of distributed computing. Cloud R&D activities continue to mature and transition into stable production systems, while ongoing evolutionary changes are still needed to adapt and refine the approaches used, in response to changes in prevailing cloud technology. In addition, completely new developments are needed to handle emerging requirements. This work will describe the overall evolution of cloud computing in ATLAS. The current status of the VM management systems used for harnessing IAAS resources will be discussed. Monitoring and accounting systems tailored for clouds are needed to complete the integration of cloud resources within ATLAS' distributed computing framework. We are developing and deploying new solutions to address the challenge of operation in a geographically distributed multi-cloud scenario, including a system for managing VM images across multiple clouds, a system for dynamic location-based discovery of caching proxy servers, and the usage of a data federation to unify the worldwide grid of storage elements into a single namespace and access point. The usage of the experiment's HLT farm for Monte Carlo production, in a specialized cloud environment, will be presented. Finally, we evaluate commercial clouds, and have conducted a study assessing cost vs. benchmark performance.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Salzburger, Andreas
dc:dc.dc:title: Optimisation of the ATLAS Track Reconstruction Software for Run-2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Track reconstruction is one of the most complex element of the reconstruction of events recorded by ATLAS from collisions delivered by the LHC. It is the most time consuming reconstruction component in high luminosity environments. The flat budget projections for computing resources for Run-2 of the LHC together with the demands of reconstructing higher pile-up collision data at rates more than double those in Run-1 (an increase from 400 Hz to 1 kHz in trigger output) have put stringent requirements on the track reconstruction software. The ATLAS experiment has performed a two year long software campaign which aimed to reduce the reconstruction rate by a factor of three to meet the resource limitations for Run-2: the majority of the changes to achieve this were improvements to the track reconstruction software. The CPU processing time of ATLAS track reconstruction was reduced by more than a factor of three during this campaign without any loss of output information of the track reconstruction. We present the methods used for analysing the tracking software setup, the code evolution and revolutionary methods implemented and the major changes applied. Although most improvements were obtained without dedicated targetting concurrency strategies, the major parts of the ATLAS tracking software, which were updated to allow for future improvements based on parallelism will also be discussed.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: CHEP - Apr 13 - 2015, this is the revision after inclusion of all comments

dc:dc.dc:creator: Formica, Andrea
Barberis, Dario
Gallas, Elizabeth
Govi, Giacomo
Lehmann Miotto, Giovanna
Pfeiffer, Andreas
dc:dc.dc:title: Designing a future Conditions Database based on LHC experience
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS and CMS Conditions Database infrastructures have served each of the respective experiments well through LHC Run 1, providing efficient access to a wide variety of conditions information needed in online data taking and offline processing and analysis. During the long shutdown between Run 1 and Run 2, we have taken various measures to improve our systems for Run 2. In some cases, a drastic change was not possible because of the relatively short time scale to prepare for Run 2. In this process, and in the process of comparing to the systems used by other experiments, we realized that for Run 3, we should consider more fundamental changes and possibilities. We seek changes which would streamline conditions data management, improve monitoring tools, better integrate the use of metadata, incorporate analytics to better understand conditions usage, as well as investigate fundamental changes in the storage technology, which might be more efficient while minimizing maintenance of the data as well as simplify the access to it. This contribution will describe architectures we are evaluating and testing which we think will address the problematic areas while providing improved services.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: CHEP2015: April 2015.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Henriques Correia, Ana Maria
Ishino, Masaya
Paramonov, Alexander
dc:dc.dc:title: Public plots: “The potential of using the ATLAS Tile calorimeter in Phase-II for the Level-0 muon trigger”
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: These figures illustrate the potential of the hadronic (Tile) calorimeter to register muons for the Level-0 muon trigger. The calorimeter can be used in combination with MDT, RPC, and TGC chambers to enable high-efficiency and high-coverage Level-0 triggers for single muons with $p_{\rm T}>15$ GeV or for two-lepton signatures with a lower threshold. The Level-0 muon trigger is intended for the Phase-II of the LHC operations program. Performance of a coincidence requirement applied to energy deposited in the calorimeter and L1_MU10 and L1_MU15 muon triggers was evaluated as a benchmark. The calorimeter provides nearly hermetic coverage for muon detection within $|\eta|<1.4$. The overall efficiency for detection of a muon with $p_{\rm T}>10$ GeV is expected to be better than 98% when the fake rate is less than 13%. Some of the inefficiency observed in Run-I is caused by disabled channels and other intermittent issues affecting the calorimeter. None of those are expected to remain in the Phase-2 since the readout electronic system of the calorimeter is going to be upgraded. The new system is expected to feature smaller noise and all-digital readout for the Level-0 triggers. The outermost layer of the calorimeter, D-layer, is used to make the muon detection robust against pileup $pp$ collisions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Lange Ramos, Bruno
Maidantchik, Carmen
Pommes, Kathy
Pavani Neto, Varlen
Vieira Arosa, Breno
dc:dc.dc:title: An object-oriented approach to deploying highly configurable web interfaces for the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: In order to manage a heterogeneous and worldwide collaboration, the ATLAS experiment develops web systems that range from supporting the process of publishing scientific papers to monitoring equipment radiation levels. These systems are vastly supported by Glance, a technology that was set forward in 2004 to create an abstraction layer on top of varied databases that automatically recognizes their modeling and generate web search interfaces. Fence (Front ENd ENgine for glaNCE) assembles classes to build applications by making extensive use of configuration files. It produces templates of the core JSON files on top of which it is possible to create Glance-compliant search interfaces. Once the database, its schemas and tables are defined using Glance, its records can be incorporated into the templates by escaping the returned values with a reference to the column identifier wrapped around double enclosing brackets. The developer may also expand on available configuration files to create HTML forms and securely interact with the database. A token is issued within each deployed form as a random string of characters which must then be matched whenever it is posted. Additionally, once the user is authenticated through CERN's Shibboleth single sign-on, Fence assigns them roles and permissions as stored in the database. Clearance attributes can then be bound to individual inputs within their own JSON description so that whenever they are submitted, the resulting system verifies whether the user has the necessary permissions to edit them. Input validation is primarily carried out on the server side with PHP but, following progressive enhancement guidelines, verification routines may be additionally entrusted to the client side by enabling specific HTML5 data attributes which are then handed over to the jQuery validation plugin. User monitoring is accomplished by logging URL requests along with any POST data. The documentation is automatically published from the source code using the Doxygen tool and made accessible in a web interface. Fence, therefore, speeds up the implementation of Web software products while minimizing maintenance overhead and facilitating the comprehension of embedded rules and requirements.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: April 13th, 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Fassi, Farida
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Distributed Data Analysis: challenges and performance
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: In the LHC operations era the key goal is to analyse the results of the collisions of high-energy particles as a way of probing the fundamental forces of nature. The ATLAS experiment at the LHC at CERN is recording and simulating several 10's of PetaBytes of data per year. The ATLAS Computing Model was designed around the concepts of Grid Computing. Large data volumes from the detectors and simulations require a large number of CPUs and storage space for data processing. To cope with this challenge a global network known as the Worldwide LHC Computing Grid (WLCG) was built. This is the most sophisticated data taking and analysis system ever built. ATLAS accumulated more than 140 PB of data between 2009 and 2014. To analyse these data ATLAS developed, deployed and now operates a mature and stable distributed analysis (DA) service on the WLCG. The service is actively used: more than half a million user jobs run daily on DA resources, submitted by more than 1500 ATLAS physicists. A significant reliability of the DA system during the first run and the following shutdown period has been reached due to the continuous automatic validation of the grid sites against a set of standard tests, and a dedicated team of expert shifters who provide user support and communicate user problems to the sites in a more efficient way. In this report we review the state of the DA system, emphasis will be put on the DA infrastructure changes to cope with the second LHC run challenges (starting in 2015) to improve the analysis workflows, including a new analysis model. A special care will be devoted to discuss the ATLAS Distributed Analysis support facility (DAST).
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: March 25th 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Leggett, Charles
Calafiura, Paolo
Lampl, Walter
Malon, David
Stewart, Graeme
Wynne, Benjamin
dc:dc.dc:title: Development of a Next Generation Concurrent Framework for the ATLAS Experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS experiment has successfully used its Gaudi/Athena software framework for data taking and analysis during the first LHC run, with billions of events successfully processed. However, the design of Gaudi/Athena dates from early 2000 and the software and the physics code has been written using a single threaded, serial design. This programming model has increasing difficulty in exploiting the potential of current CPUs, which offer their best performance only through taking full advantage of multiple cores and wide vector registers. Future CPU evolution will intensify this trend, with core counts increasing and memory per core falling. With current memory consumption for 64 bit ATLAS reconstruction in a high luminosity environment approaching 4GB, it will become impossible to fully occupy all cores in a machine without exhausting available memory. However, since maximising performance per watt will be a key metric, a mechanism must be found to use all cores as efficiently as possible. In this paper we report on our progress with a practical demonstration of the use of multi-threading in the ATLAS reconstruction software, using the GaudiHive framework. We have expanded support to Calorimeter, Inner Detector, and Tracking code, discussing what changes were necessary in order to allow the serially designed ATLAS code to run, both to the framework and to the tools and algorithms used. We report on both the performance gains, and what general lessons were learned about the code patterns that had been employed in the software and which patterns were identified as particularly problematic for multi-threading. We also present our findings on implementing a hybrid multi-threaded / multi-process framework, to take advantage of the strengths of each type of concurrency, while avoiding some of their corresponding limitations.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Filipcic, Andrej
Cameron, David
Nilsen, Jon Kerr
dc:dc.dc:title: CHEP2015: Dynamic Resource Allocation with arcControlTower
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Distributed computing resources available for high-energy physics research are becoming less dedicated to one type of workflow and researchers’ workloads are increasingly exploiting modern computing technologies such as parallelism. The current pilot job management model used by many experiments relies on static dedicated resources and cannot easily adapt to these changes. The model used for ATLAS in Nordic countries and some other places enables a flexible job management system based on dynamic resources allocation. Rather than a fixed set of resources managed centrally, the model allows resources to be requested on the fly. The ARC Computing Element (ARC-CE) and ARC Control Tower (aCT) are the key components of the model. The aCT requests jobs from the ATLAS job mangement system (Panda) and submits a fully-formed job description to ARC-CEs. ARC-CE can then dynamically request the required resources from the underlying batch system. In this paper we describe the architecture of the model and the experience of running many millions of ATLAS jobs on it.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: CHEP2015, starting 13.4.2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gwilliam, Carl
Hurwitz, Martina
Kozanecki, Witold
Shaw, Kate
dc:dc.dc:title: Length scale calibration during the January 2013 scans with p-Pb collisions at √s = 5.02 TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This supporting note describes the calibration of the distance scale of the beam-separation closed orbit bumps at the ATLAS Interaction Point (IP), which was performed with a dedicated scan at a nominal β∗ = 0.8 m on 29th January 2013. The calibration provides an evaluation of the beam-displacement scale in the measurement of the horizontal and vertical convolved beam sizes (Σx and Σy respectively), a key ingredient to the absolute luminosity calibration. In the linear approximation the deviation from unity of the resultant scale factors is 1.14% and 0.93% in the horizontal and vertical plane. The product of these beam-displacement scales diﬀers from unity by 2.06±0.40%.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Vazeille, Francois
Theveneaux-Pelzer, Timothee
Drake, Gary
Bonnefoy, Romeo
Sahuc, Eric
dc:dc.dc:title: NIEL and TID certifications of the active dividers of the Tile Calorimeter of the ATLAS detector for the Phase II upgrade
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: By following the ATLAS radiation safety rules, the active dividers of the Tile Calorimeter of the ATLAS detector have been certified to NIEL and TID radiations at, respectively, Valduc (France) for neutrons and Brookhaven (USA) for photons. They match the requested radiation criteria entirely.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Quality, Data
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Data Quality Operations in 2012
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note summarizes the data quality performance of the ATLAS subdetectors during the 2012 data taking period, corresponding to 22.7 fb−1 of data recorded by the ATLAS detector. It also contains a summary of the data quality operation and organization within each subdetector group.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kroha, Hubert
dc:dc.dc:title: Proposal for the Improvement of the ATLAS Muon Spectrometer Momentum Resolution in Barrel Sectors 12 and 14
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Proposal for the installation of new BMG sMDT Chambers in the ATLAS Barrel muon spectrometer in the feet regions in sectors 12 and 14 in order to improve the muon momentum resolution in these regions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hoecker, Andreas
Murray, Bill
Charlton, Dave
Wengler, Thorsten
Heinemann, Beate
Abramowicz, Halina
de Jong, Paul
Kado, Marumi
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS procedures for the approval of physics results
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document provides guidelines and details of the procedures for the preparation and approval of physics results. It describes the roles of all the individuals and groups involved in the approval process, the purpose of the meetings, and gives a step-by-step guide on the procedures. Papers, conference notes and public notes are described.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Molander, S
dc:dc.dc:title: Studies of Non-iterative Optimal Filtering Using the Athena Pulse Simulator
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A pulse simulator for generating samples similar to pulses from the ATLAS TILE calorimeter is presented and its functionality and usage explained. An investigation of out-of-time pile-up effects on non-iterative optimal filtering reconstruction is presented, using the pulse simulator tool. The investigation is done using both ideal pulses and effects of noise, time jitter and pulse shape imperfections. A scan of different out-of-time pile-up scenarios shows that it is a possibility that pile-up leads to incorrect energy reconstruction. However, a second part of the investigation using a more likely pile-up distribution shows that such high pile-up scenarios are not common.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dano Hoffmann, Maria
Jakobsen, Sune
dc:dc.dc:title: Determination of Light Yield of an ATLAS Minimum Bias Trigger Scintillator for LHC Run II with Cosmic Radiation
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We report on measurements of the light yield of an ATLAS Minimum Bias Trigger Scintillator (MBTS) to be used in Run II. The measurements were performed before integration in ATLAS in a dedicated cosmic stand. At first we report on the estimation of the attenuation of the clear optical fibers used for light transport. Subsequently, the yield from the outer sector of the MBTS counter is determined with both 4 and 8 wave-length shifters. Furthermore, a direct comparison of the light yield from the inner and outer sector is performed.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Miucci, Antonio
dc:dc.dc:title: IBL Thermal stability during M9 runs
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: IBL Modules and Cooling Pipes temperature stability

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bonnefoy, Romeo
Chadelas, Robert
Lambert, Daniel
Madar, Romain
Sahuc, Eric
Vazeille, Francois
dc:dc.dc:title: Performances of a Remote High Voltage Power Supply for the Phase II Upgrade of the ATLAS Tile Calorimeter
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The experience gained in the working of the present High Voltage system of the Tile calorimeter and the new HL-LHC constraints, in particular the increase of the radiations, lead to the proposal of moving the embedded regulation system to a remote system in the USA15 room, by adding easily new functionalities. This system is using the same regulation scheme as the present one and distributes the individual HVs with multi-conductor cables. The tests show that it reaches the same performances in terms of regulation stability and noise, with a full working reliability of every channel.

dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Large eta task force report
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document summarises the Large eta task force activity and recommendations on the detector, performance and physics areas

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cetin, Serkant Ali
Romaniouk, Anatoli
Sasmaz, Uygar
dc:dc.dc:title: Induced Radioactivity of Argon and Krypton as Active Gas in ATLAS-ID-TRT
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Estimates of the radioactivity levels of the TRT gas system with alternative gas options of Argon and Krypton activated during LHC operation are presented. Activity and dose rate calculations for these gases are evaluated and compared with the original active gas which is Xenon. Finally the results are discussed in view of CERN safety limits.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Isaev, Alexander
Karyukhin, Andrey
Shalanda, Nikolay
Solodkov, Alexander
Solovyanov, Oleg
Starchenko, Evgeny
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS Tile Calorimeter special cells properties
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The optical properties of the ATLAS hadronic Tile calorimeter non-standard scintillating tiles have been studied using point like Sr90 radioactive source. A side by side comparison of the results with those of standard tiles, including the response to the Cs137 source, helps to transfer the overall properties of the standard tiles to the cut ones. Acquired response distributions and ratios, supported by MC studies, might be used for precise calibration of special cells of the Tile calorimeter.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Viazlo, Oleksandr
ATLAS LUCID Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: The LUCID detector

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gaudiello, Andrea
dc:dc.dc:title: Pixel dE/dx plots in Run 2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS Pixel detector can measure the charge released by particle crossing the sensors with good resolution. An algorithm to provide a track Pixel dE/dx was developped in Run1. A new algorithm that exploits the new layer added in Run 2 (IBL) has been deployed and performance is shown in these plots.

dc:dc.dc:title: The average hit occupancies and the average fraction of modules with synchronization errors at Pixel/IBL in Run2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The average hit occupancy at IBL and B-Layer as a function of the average number of pile-up in luminosity block units (one luminosity block corresponds approximately to one minute of data-taking) in Run1 and Run2 are shown. The average fraction of modules with synchronization errors for each run of the data-taking at IBL and Pixel barrel layers in Run2 are shown.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Henriques Correia, Ana Maria
Ishino, Masaya
Paramonov, Alexander
dc:dc.dc:title: The potential of using the ATLAS Tile calorimeter in Phase-II for the Level-0 muon trigger
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document describes the potential of the hadronic (Tile) calorimeter to register muons for the Level-0 muon trigger. The calorimeter can be used in combination with MDT, RPC, and TGC chambers to enable high-efficiency and high-coverage Level-0 triggers for single muons with $p_{\rm T}>15$ GeV or for two-lepton signatures with a lower threshold. The Level-0 muon trigger is intended for the Phase-II of the LHC operations program. Performance of a coincidence requirement applied to energy deposited in the calorimeter and L1_MU10 and L1_MU15 muon triggers was evaluated as a benchmark. The calorimeter provides nearly hermetic coverage for muon detection within $|\eta|<1.4$. The overall efficiency for detection of a muon with $p_{\rm T}>10$ GeV is expected to be better than 98% when the fake rate is less than 13%. Some of the inefficiency observed in Run-I is caused by disabled channels and other intermittent issues affecting the calorimeter. None of those are expected to remain in the Phase-2 since the readout electronic system of the calorimeter is going to be upgraded. The new system is expected to feature smaller noise and all-digital readout for the Level-0 triggers. Time of a muon crossing a cell is measured with accuracy of 4-5 ns. The spacial resolution in $\phi$ is $\pi/32$ and the resolution in $\eta$ is about 0.2. The outermost layer of the calorimeter, D-layer, is used to make the muon detection robust against pileup $pp$ collisions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Aaboud, Morad
Santoni, Claudio
dc:dc.dc:title: Response of the gap/crack scintillator counters in Run 1
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Isolated muons measurements were used to check a) the uniformity, b) the stability and c) the energy scale of the gap/crack scintillator counters response. Data collected in 2010, 2011 and 2012 were analyzed. No clear evidence of miss calibrated cell was detected. The response of the E1, E2, and E3 cells in the three years and of the E4 cells in 2011 and 2012 is stable and equalized inside few percent. In 2010 the response of the E4 cell shows a deviation of about -8% corresponding to 3 sigmas with the respect to the mean observed in the following years. The data show that the EM scale used in ATLAS to measure the jet energy deposited in the gap/crack scintillator counters deviate from the value obtained using electrons at test beam by about 5%.

dc:dc.dc:creator: O'Rourke, Abigail Alexandra
dc:dc.dc:title: Software for the Sonar project
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Sonar project uses custom ultrasonic instruments in the ATLAS experiment to measure gas flow and analyse binary gas mixtures. These parameters are determined from measurements of sound velocity within the gas, by transmitting and detecting ultrasound pulses. Five instru- ments are integrated into the ATLAS detector control system. Three monitor coolant leakage within the ATLAS silicon tracker while two are integrated into the external plant. Software to control and monitor these systems has been developed using Siemens SIMATIC WinCC.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Yamaguchi, Daiki
dc:dc.dc:title: Pixel/IBL offline monitoring plots in Run2
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment

dc:dc.dc:creator: Biedermann, Dustin
Grancagnolo, Sergio
dc:dc.dc:title: Assessing the quality of Lorentz angle measurement in the ATLAS SCT subdetector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Lorentz angle might evolve during data taking periods, and a procedure has been developed to establish the quality of its measurement. After applying various scaling factors, a full reconstruction was performed and residuals were recalculated. On a sample of express stream data collected in September 2012, it has been verified that the optimal correction is currently in place. The same procedure can be used in the future to find out when any adjustment will be required.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Mortensen, Simon Stark
Jakobsen, Sune
Guerrero Llorente, Alonso
dc:dc.dc:title: Trigger efficiency for the ALFA detector at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, $\beta^{*}$ = 90 m
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The trigger efficiency of the ATLAS subdetector ALFA is investigated for elastic like events in $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, $\beta^*=90$ m data. The calibration stream is used to find the efficiency of an elastic event and the result is normalized to the physics stream. The efficiency for the CTP trigger items aimed for physics analysis (L1\_ELAST15 and L1\_ELAST18) is found to be $99.912\pm0.002\%$. The trigger efficiency for the individual ALFA detector is found in three ways: Using the trigger tiles, using the CTP items, and using the CTP items with a random event selection. The efficiency in all three cases is above $99\%$ except for detector B7L1U where one of the trigger tiles might have a problem.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Koi, Tatsumi
Marley, Daniel Edison
Morinaga, Masahiro
Weber, Stefan Wolf
Young, Charles
dc:dc.dc:title: New SmallWheel Background Studies
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The SmallWheel in theMuon Spectrometer will be replaced by the New SmallWheel as part of the Phase-I upgrade, and its shielding will have to be modified accordingly. This Note summarizes the shieldiong studies leading up to the final design of the New Small Wheel, and reports on the expected background in this new geometry. There is a substantial increase in rate relative to the Run 2 geometry: up to a factor of 2 in the small radius region of the New Small Wheel, and ' 50% at the high jzj region of the innermost barrel muon chamber. Additional cladding around the New Small Wheel support can reduce this background.

dc:dc.dc:title: The ATLAS Jet Trigger for Initial LHC Run II
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note gives an overview of the jet trigger running in the ATLAS High Level Trigger for initial LHC Run-2 data taking. It gives details of the jet trigger menu, explaining its design, gives a description of the most important components of the online selection software, describes the validation and monitoring infrastructures developed to allow its operation, and concludes with an account of early jet trigger commissioning.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kaplan, Benjamin
Haas, Andy
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Higgs bosons decaying to $aa$ in the $\mu\mu\tau\tau$ final state in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = $8 TeV with the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the the decay to a pair of new particles of either the Standard-Model-like Higgs boson ($h$), or a second CP-even Higgs boson ($H$) is presented. The dataset used is 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $\sqrt{s}=$ 8 TeV $pp$ collisions recorded by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC in 2012. The search was done in the context of the next-to-minimal supersymmetric standard model, in which the new particles are the lightest neutral pseudoscalar Higgs bosons ($a$). One of the two $a$ bosons is required to decay to two muons while the other is required to decay to two $\tau$-leptons. No significant excess is observed above the expected backgrounds in the $m_\mu\mu$ range from 3.7 GeV to 50 GeV. Upper limits are placed on the production of $h\rightarrow{aa}$ relative to the Standard Model $gg\rightarrow{h}$ production, assuming no coupling of the $a$ boson to quarks. The most stringent limit is placed at 3.5 % for $m_a = 3.75$ GeV. Upper limits are also placed on the production rate of $H\rightarrow{aa}$ from 2.33 pb to 0.72 pb, for fixed $m_a = 5$ GeV with $m_H$ ranging from 100 GeV to 500 GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hawkings, Richard
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of lepton differential distributions in $t\bar{t}$ production in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using $e\mu$ events with $b$-tagged jets
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes measurements of the differential distributions of leptons and lepton paris produced in dileptonic $t\bar{t}$ events with an opposite sign $e\mu$ pair, using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV recorded with the ATLAS detector at the LHC. The events were selected using the leptons, and jets tagged as being likely to originate from $b$-quarks using the MV1 tagging algorithm. Absolute and normalised differential cross-sections were measured as a function of single lepton transverse momentum and rapidity, the difference in azimuthal angles of the two leptons, and various kinematic variables related to the dilepton system. The results are compared to the predictions of various $t\bar{t}$ Monte Carlo event generators.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Lister, Alison
Owen, Mark
Kind, Oliver
Costa, Maria Jose
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS and CMS summary plot for single top production cross section (TopLHCWG)
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Summary of the ATLAS and CMS measurements of the single top production cross-sections in the t-, s- and Wt-channels as a function of center of mass energy. For the s-channel only an upper limit is shown. The measurements are compared to theoretical calculations based on: NLO QCD, NLO QCD complemented with NNLL resummation and NNLO QCD (t-channel only).

dc:dc.dc:creator: Pleskot, Vojtech
dc:dc.dc:title: Studies of azimuthal decorrelation of dijets with a jet veto with ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Measurements of di-jet systems with a veto on additional jets, probe QCD radiation effects. The two jets in each event with the highest transverse momentum are taken as the dijet system and a rapidity interval is defined as the region in rapidity between the centroids of these two jets. The fraction of dijet events without an additional jet in this rapidity interval and the mean jet multiplicity in the interval are presented as a function of the mean transverse momentum of the dijets and of the rapidity interval size. Correlations between the azimuthal angles of the dijets are studied both with and without a veto on additional jet activity in the rapidity interval between the jets. This study probes different approaches to the resummation of large logarithms when performing QCD calculations.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Borodin, Mikhail
De, Kaushik
Garc\xc3\xada Navarro, Jos\xc3\xa9 Enrique
Golubkov, Dmitry
Klimentov, Alexei
Maeno, Tadashi
South, David
Vaniachine, Alexandre
dc:dc.dc:title: Unified system for processing real and simulated data in the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The physics goals of the next Large Hadron Collider run include high precision tests of the Standard Model and searches for new physics. These goals “at the Gates of Nature” require detailed comparison of data with computational models simulating the expected data behavior. To highlight the role which modeling and simulation plays in future scientific discovery, we report on use cases and experience with a unified system built to process both real and simulated data of growing volume and variety.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: ICCS Full Paper submission deadline is January 15.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Jia, Jiangyong
Mohapatra, Soumya
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the correlation between flow harmonics of different order in lead--lead collisions at $\sqrt{s_{_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$=2.76 Te
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Correlations between the elliptic or triangular flow coefficients, $v_m$ ($m=2$ or 3), and other flow harmonics, $v_n$ for $n=2$ to 5 are measured using 7 $\mu$b$^{-1}$ of Pb+Pb collision data at $\sqrt{s_{_{\mathrm{NN}}}}=2.76$ TeV collected by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC. The $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations are measured as a function of centrality, and, for events within the same centrality interval, also as a function of event ellipticity or triangularity. The $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations for a fixed centrality interval are very different from the correlations as a function of centrality. For events within the same centrality interval, $v_3$ is found to be anti-correlated with $v_2$ and this anti-correlation is compatible with similar anti-correlations between the corresponding eccentricities $\epsilon_2$ and $\epsilon_3$. On the other hand, it is observed that $v_4$ increases strongly with $v_2$, and $v_5$ increases strongly with both $v_2$ and $v_3$. The trend and strength of the $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations for $n=4$ and 5 are found to disagree with $\epsilon_m$-$\epsilon_n$ correlations predicted by initial geometry models. Instead, these correlations are found to be consistent with the combined effects of a linear contribution to $v_n$ and non-linear term that is a function of $v_2^2$ or of $v_2v_3$, as predicted by hydrodynamic models. A simple two-component fit is used to separate these two contributions. The magnitudes of the linear and non-linear contributions to $v_4$ and $v_5$ are found to be consistent with previously measured event-plane correlations.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: This is a paper converted from confnote https://atlas.web.cern.ch/Atlas/GROUPS/PHYSICS/CONFNOTES/ATLAS-CONF-2014-022/

Vazquez Schroeder, Tamara
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for the Standard Model Higgs boson produced in association with top quarks and decaying into $\boldsymbol{b\bar{b}}$ in $\boldsymbol{pp}$ collisions at $\sqrt{\bf s} ~{\bf=}$ $\boldsymbol{8 TeV}$ with the ATLAS detector at the LHC}
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the Standard Model Higgs boson produced in association with a pair of top quarks, $t\bar{t}H$, is presented. The analysis uses 20.3~\ifb~of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8 $ TeV, collected with the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider during 2012. The search is designed for the $H \to b\bar{b}$ decay mode and uses events containing one or two electrons or muons. %or one electron or muon with a hadronically decaying tau. The Higgs boson is assumed to have a mass of 125 GeV. In order to improve the sensitivity of the search, events are categorised according to their jet and $b$-tagged jet multiplicities. A multivariate technique is used to discriminate between signal and background events, which are dominated by $t\bar{t}$+jets production. In the single lepton channel, a matrix element technique is employed. No significant excess of events above the background expectation is found and an observed (expected) 95 % confidence-level limit of 3.4 (2.2) times the Standard Model cross section is obtained. By performing a fit allowing for an arbitrary Higgs boson signal strength, the ratio of the measured signal strength to the Standard Model expectation is found to be $\mu = 1.5 \pm 1.1$.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: paper draft

dc:dc.dc:creator: Spousta, Martin
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet fragmentation and multijet studies in heavy ion collisions at ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We report on two measurements done by ATLAS in a context of exploring the jet quenching physics at LHC: the jet fragmentation measurement and the measurement of \nearby jet production. Both of these measurements were done using the data collected in 2011 Pb+Pb run providing Pb+Pb collisions at $\sqrt{s_{NN}} = 2.76~$TeV. These measurements are expected to provide an insight into the modifications of jets initiated by partons passing through hot and dense QCD matter created in heavy ion collisions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Lundberg, Olof
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for Dark Matter with the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ATLAS is a multi-purpose detector aimed at fully exploiting the discovery potential of the proton-proton collisions at a center of mass energy of 8-14 TeV provided by CERN Large Hadron Collider. It is able to precisely identify and measure the properties of electrons, muons, photons, taus and hadronic jets. Thanks to an excellent hermeticity it is able to infer the production of neutrinos and dark matter particles from conservation of momentum using the missing energy observable. This talk will focus on the results of several dedicated searches for WIMP Dark Matter using the ATLAS detector. Among these searches are the so called "Mono-X" searches looking for signatures with large missing momentum recoiling against a gauge boson. We also present searches for decays of the Higgs boson into invisible states and searches for final states with missing transverse energy and third generation quarks. The results are interpreted in terms of Effective Field Theories as well as Simplified Models, and limits on nucleon-WIMP cross sections are inferred for both spin-dependent and spin-independent scenarios. Finally some prospects for the upcoming LHC Run 2 with collisions at the unprecedented 13-14 TeV center-of-mass energies will be presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: January 25, 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Van Den Wollenberg, Wouter
Kagan, Michael
Thompson, Emily
Zhou, Lei
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the Track-Jet $b$-Tagging Efficiency of the MV1 algorithm in $pp$ Collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using $e\mu$ Dilepton $t\bar{t}$ events
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes a measurement of the $b$-tagging efficiency of the MV1 $b$-tagging algorithm for $R=0.4$ and $R=0.3$ track jets built from inner detector tracks in the complete 2012 ATLAS $pp$ collision dataset at $\sqrt{s} = 8$~\TeV, using dilepton $t\bar{t}$ events with an opposite-sign $e\mu$ pair in the final state. This analysis follows the technique previously used for the calibration of the calorimeter jet $b$-tagging efficiency, and as such uses a tag-and-probe based method to extract an unbiased estimate of the $b$-tagging efficiency using events with exactly two jet. The $b$-tagging efficiency is measured as a function of track jet $p_{T}$ in the range $7 < p_{T} < 250$~\GeV and as a function of $|\eta|$. The Monte Carlo Simulation is found to describe the $b$-tagging efficiency observed in data well. Results of the calibration to correct any differences between the Monte Carlo Simulation and the data in the form of scale factors, derived from the data to Monte Carlo Simulation ratio, are presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Duda, Dominik
Maettig, Peter
Scanlon, Timothy Paul
Piacquadio, Giacinto
Duda, Dominik
dc:dc.dc:title: Calibration of ATLAS $b$-tagging algorithms in dense jet environments
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note describes the calibration of various ATLAS $b$-tagging algorithms using reconstructed $t\bar{t}$ candidate events in the final state of one charged lepton, missing transverse momentum, and at least four jets, in the ATLAS $\sqrt{s}=8 \TeV$ $pp$ collision data sample. Expanding on previous $b$-tagging calibration studies, the $b$-tagging efficiencies are measured not only as a function of the transverse momentum or the pseudorapidity of the jets, but also as a function of quantities that are sensitive to close-by jet activity. The results measured in data are in good agreement with the predictions from simulation.

dc:dc.dc:title: Re-interpretations and combinations of electroweak limits in 20.3 fb−1 pp collisions at √s = 8 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This INT note contains all supporting material for re-interpretations and combinations of the EWK analyses using the full 8TeV dataset.

dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the total and differential Higgs boson production cross sections using the $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ ^{*}\rightarrow 4\ell$ channels at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the total and differential cross sections of Higgs boson production is performed using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions produced by the Large Hadron Collider at a centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV and recorded by the ATLAS detector. Cross sections measured in the $H \rightarrow \gamma \gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^* \rightarrow 4\ell$ decay channels are extrapolated to the inclusive phase space, combined, and compared to state-of-the-art predictions. Differential cross sections are reported as a function of Higgs boson transverse momentum, Higgs boson rapidity, number of jets in the event, and transverse momentum of the leading jet. The total production cross section is determined to be $\sigma_{pp \to H} = 33.0 \pm 5.3 \mathrm{(stat)} \pm 1.5 \mathrm{(sys)}$.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: CDS entry for supporting note: https://cds.cern.ch/record/1757268

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dolezal, Zdenek
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS studies of spectroscopy and B-decays
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ATLAS has a wide programme to study the production cross section and decay properties of particles with beauty, as well as charmonium and bottomonium states. This presentation will cover the latest ATLAS results, including searches for excited b-hadrons, new decay modes of b-hadrons, indirect New Physics searches in rare B-hadron decays, as well as sthe study of mixing and CP violation in the Bs system. We will also review the results in the domain of charmonium production, including J/psi, psi(2s) and chi_c states, associated vector boson + J/psi production and search for hidden-beauty state Xb, the bottomonium counterpart of X(3876) in the Upsilon pi pi channel.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dolezal, Zdenek
dc:dc.dc:title: ATLAS studies of spectroscopy and B-decays
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: ATLAS has a wide programme to study the production cross section and decay properties of particles with beauty, as well as charmonium and bottomonium states. This presentation will cover the latest ATLAS results, including searches for excited b-hadrons, new decay modes of b-hadrons, indirect New Physics searches in rare B-hadron decays, as well as sthe study of mixing and CP violation in the Bs system and parity violating asymmetry parameter alpha_b in Lambda_b -> Lambda J/psi decays. We will also review the results in the domain of charmonium production, including J/psi, psi(2s) and chi_c states, associated vector boson + J/psi production and search for hidden-beauty state Xb, the bottomonium counterpart of X(3876) in the Upsilon pi pi channel.

dc:dc.dc:title: Review of ATLAS Results

dc:dc.dc:creator: Rossi, Leonardo Paolo
Gemme, Claudia
Guido, Elisa
Passaggio, Stefano
Favareto, Andrea
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for metastable heavy charged particles with the ATLAS detector in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Many extensions of the Standard Model predict the existence of charged and heavy long-lived particles, such as $R$-hadrons or charginos. These particles, if produced at the Large Hadron Collider, should be moving non-relativistically and are therefore identifiable through the measurement of an anomalously large specific energy loss in the ATLAS pixel detector. Measuring heavy long-lived particles through their track parameters in the vicinity of the interaction vertex allows sensitivity to metastable particles with lifetimes from 0.6 ns to 30 ns. A search for such particles with the ATLAS}detector at the LHC is presented, based on a data sample corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 18.4 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV. No significant deviation from Standard Model background expectation is observed, and lifetime dependent upper limits on $R$-hadrons and chargino production cross sections and masses are set. Gluino $R$-hadrons with 10 ns lifetime and masses up to 1185 GeV are excluded at 95\% confidence level as well as charginos with 15 ns lifetime and masses up to 482 GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cortiana, Giorgio
Nisius, Richard
Compostella, Gabriele
Maier, Andreas Alexander
Balli, Fabrice
Schwindling, Jerome
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the top quark mass in the $t\bar t \to {\rm lepton+jets}$ and $t\bar t \to {\rm di-lepton}$ channels using $\sqrt{s}=7$ TeV ATLAS data: Paper Draft
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The top quark mass was measured in the channels $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{lepton+jets}$ and $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{dilepton}$ ($e, \mu$) based on ATLAS data recorded in 2011. The data were taken at the LHC with a proton--proton centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s}=7$ TeV and correspond to an integrated luminosity of 4.6fb$^{-1}$. The $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{lepton+jets}$ analysis uses a three-dimensional template technique which determines the top quark mass together with a global jet energy scale factor, and a relative $b$-to-light-jet energy scale factor, where the terms $b$-jets and light-jets refer to jets originating from $b$-quarks and $u, d, c, s$-quarks or gluons, respectively. The analysis of the $t\bar{t} \to \mathrm{dilepton}$ channel exploits a one-dimensional template method using the $m_{\ell b}$ observable, defined as the average invariant mass of the two lepton+$b$-jet pairs in each event. The top quark mass is measured to be $172.33\pm 0.75(\rm {stat}) \pm 1.02(\rm {syst})$ GeV, and $173.79 \pm 0.54({\rm stat}) \pm 1.30({\rm syst})$ GeV in the $t\bar{t} \to lepton+jets$ and $t\bar{t} \to dilepton$ channels, respectively. The combination of the two results yields $m_{\mathrm top} = 172.99 \pm 0.48({\rm stat}) \pm 0.78({\rm syst})$ GeV, with a total uncertainty of $0.91$ GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kosek, Tomas
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent Results on Hard Probes of the Quark-Gluon Plasma with the ATLAS Experiment at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Jets provide a powerful tool for probing the dynamics of the quark-gluon plasma created in Pb+Pb collisions at the LHC. The modification of high-pT parton showers as they propagate in the quark-gluon plasma, often referred to as "jet quenching", provides insight on the short-distance dynamics of the plasma. Jet quenching has been observed in a variety of single jet, dijet, and photon-jet measurements at the LHC as well as in measurements of modified production of charged-particle These results will be presented along with a survey of results of control measurements in Pb+Pb and p+Pb collisions including electroweak final states.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date is 26 January 2015

dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Short wishlist for the PDF4LHC group for further recommendation of evaluating systematic uncertainties of parton distribution functions, in particularly for analyses using MVA techniques.

Fedorko, Woiciech

Savage, Graham

Solovyev, Victor
Long, Brian Alexander
Tsirintanis, Nikolaos
dc:dc.dc:title: Model-Independent Reinterpretation of the ATLAS 8 TeV Z’->ll and W’->lnu Run 2 results
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Heavy gauge bosons giving sizable signals with Standard Model leptons in the final state can appear in one of two possible multiplets: a) Triplets, which contain a Z' and a W', and have only 2 independent couplings or 2) Singlets, which contain just a Z' particle, and have 5 independent couplings to fermions. This note presents a first attempt to combine existing W'->lnu and Z'->ll 8TeV analysis results and to present the resulting limits in terms of couplings.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Other Authors: Manuel Perez-Victoria and Javier Lizana

dc:dc.dc:creator: Metcalfe, Jessica
Valencic, Nika
Pleier, Marc-Andre
Schnoor, Ulrike
Schott, Matthias
Gumpert, Christian
Vest, Anja Simone
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of an Extended Tracker on Same Sign WW at 14 TeV for HL-LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The impact of an extended tracker in a future upgraded ATLAS detector is evaluated for the process of same-electric-charge $WW$ scattering ($W^\pm W^\pm jj$) at a High-Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) at $\sqrt{s} = 14$ TeV. Pileup suppression and identification of jets and leptons are evaluated for their impact on the significance of the $W^\pm W^\pm jj$ signal. An extension of the forward tracking system from pseudorapidities $|\eta|\le 2.5$ to $|\eta|\le 4.0$ has the potential to improve the significance of the $W^\pm W^\pm jj$ measurement by approximately 80% with mean number of $pp$ interactions per bunch crossing $\langle \mu \rangle$ = 140. The discovery potential for new physics is also evaluated in an effective field theory framework for the anomalous gauge boson coupling parameter $f_{T,1}$.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for invisible decays of the Higgs boson produced in association with a hadronically decaying vector boson in pp collisions at √s = 8 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the Higgs boson decay to invisible (weakly interacting) particles is performed using 20.3 fb-1 of pp collision data at a centre-of-mass energy of 8 TeV recorded by the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider. The process considered is the Higgs boson production in association with a vector boson (W or Z) that decays hadronically, resulting in events of two or more jets with large missing tranverse momentum. No excess of candidates is observed in the data beyond the background expectation. The null result leads to an upper limit of XX at the 95% confidence level on the decay branching ratio of the Higgs boson to invisible particles.

Battaglia, Marco
Dao, Valerio
Debenedetti, Chiara
Duffield, Emily Marie
Facini, Gabriel John
Gavrilenko, Igor
Pagan Griso, Simone
Jansky, Roland Wolfgang
Milesi, Marco
Morley, Anthony Keith
Shapiro, Marjorie
Ungaro, Francesca
Zaidan, Remi
dc:dc.dc:title: The Optimization of ATLAS Track Reconstruction in Dense Environments
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents recent changes in the ATLAS track reconstruction chain derived from detailed studies of track reconstruction in dense environments. The cores of high $p_{T}$ jets and $\tau$-leptons are characterized by charged particle distances comparable to the inner detector sensor dimensions. The ambiguity processor stage of the reconstruction chain was over-halled including an improvement of the usage of a NN based approach to identify clusters created by multiple charge particles. Single particle samples are used to demonstrate the alteration in a simple environment. The impact of these changes on tracks in high $p_{T}$ jets are shown to result in more pixel hits on track, a more meaningful split hit definition, and improved track parameter estimation. A 10% increase in b-jet identification for an equal fake rate has been shown.

dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search - Appendices

dc:dc.dc:title: {Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search - Appendices
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves as support for the note ``Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I \wh~search'', holding an extended selection of plots as an Appendix.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: An a posteriori support note for the Run I WH analysis and its paper, focusing on the b-jet energy corrections for the dijet invariant mass distribution. Several potential corrections are also discussed and a recommendation is made for the Run II analysis.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Amaral Coutinho, Yara
Buzatu, Adrian
Nunes De Moura Junior, Natanael
Mullen, Paul
Ravenscroft, Thomas
Robson, Aidan
Seixas, Jose
dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of jet-energy corrections on the ATLAS Run I $WH\rightarrow l\nu b\bar{b}$ search
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note serves both as \emph{a posteriori} support for the Run I \vh~search paper, and investigates several potential $b$-jet energy corrections, proposing one of them for the Run II analysis. Since the di-$b$-jet invariant mass (\mbb) is the best known signal to background discriminant, the search sensitivity increases when the \mbb~resolution improves. We reproduce the 2-jet 2-$b$-tag \wh~sample. After the $b$-jet reconstruction and event selection are reviewed, the four consecutive jet energy corrections are studied and confirmed to be beneficial to the \wh~search. We further show that a transverse momentum (Pt) correction derived in the \wh~sample gives consistent results with the one used, derived in the \zhll~sample. In 12\% of cases where the $b$ quark decays semileptonically through a muon and a neutrino, even after the muon-in-jet (Mu) correction, the jet energy response is about 10\% smaller due to the unaccounted neutrino. 78.7\%, 20.1\% and 1.2\% of events have zero, one or two jets with muons, respectively. Relative to the generated \mbb~peak, the reconstructed peak is 0.7\% higher, 3.4\% lower and 5.9\% lower, respectively. This is improved to 0.4\% lower, 0.3\% higher and 2.2\% higher, respectively, and the total \mbb~width is improved by 1.5\%, from 12.9 GeV to 12.7 GeV, when two different Pt corrections are used, depending on whether the jet contains or not a muon. We therefore recommend that, at a minimum, this approach is taken for the Run II analysis. We also investigate corrections based on regressions using artificial neural networks. We show that using the Pt as sole input is equivalent to the existing Pt correction, and adding the change in Pt due to the Mu correction as a second input is equivalent with two Pt corrections depending on whether there is a muon or not. Several other further potential improvements are outlined for future study.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: An a posteriori support note for the Run I WH analysis and its paper, focusing on the b-jet energy corrections for the dijet invariant mass distribution. Several potential corrections are also discussed and a recommendation is made for the Run II analysis. This is the main note, while the previous one is supporting this note with many plots in Appendix style.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for direct top-squark pair production in final states with two $\tau$ leptons in \boldmath{pp} collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$~TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for direct pair production of supersymmetric partners of the top quark decaying via a $\tau$ slepton to a light weakly interacting particle has been performed using 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$~TeV, collected by the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider in 2012. Top squark candidates are identified in events with two oppositely charged leptons, including one or two hadronically decaying $\tau$ leptons. No excess over the Standard Model expectation is found ({\em or maybe it is...}). Exclusion limits at 95\% confidence level are set as a function of the top squark and $\tau$ slepton masses. Depending on the $\tau$ slepton mass, lower limits between xxx~GeV and yyy~GeV are placed on the top squark mass.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: paper draft

dc:dc.dc:title: Setting Limits on the Higgs width using interference information in the di-photon channel with √s = 8 TeV data
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This support note documents limits on the Higgs boson decay width extracted using interferometry in the di-photon channel, as well as the expected impact from interferometry on the Higgs mass measurement in the H \to \gamma\gamma channel.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cooper, Ben

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for di-Higgs production in the 4b final state from pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for $pp\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm} hh\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm} b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ has been performed in 19.5 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, which were recorded by ATLAS in 2012. The decay of each Higgs boson is reconstructed as a high-$p_{T}$ $b\bar{b}$ system with either a pair of small-radius jets or a single large-radius jet, the latter exploiting jet substructure techniques and associated $b$-tagged track jets for the first time in ATLAS. No evidence for resonant or non-resonant Higgs pair production is observed. Using a bulk Randall-Sundrum Kaluza-Klein graviton with $k/M_{Pl} = 1.0$ as a benchmark resonant signal, a 95$\%$ confidence level upper limit on $\sigma\left(pp\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm}G^{*}_{KK}\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm}hh\hspace{-1mm}\to\hspace{-1mm}b\bar{b}b\bar{b}\right)$ of 3 (5) fb is set for $m_{G^*_{KK}} = 1.0$ (1.5) TeV. For this model, gravitons with $500 < m_{G*} < 720$ GeV are excluded at the 95$\%$ confidence level. The search for non-resonant SM $hh$ production sets an observed 95\% confidence level upper limit on $\sigma(pp\hspace{-1mm}\rightarrow\hspace{-1mm}hh\hspace{-1mm}\rightarrow\hspace{-1mm}b\bar{b}b\bar{b})$ of 198 fb, which corresponds to $\mu = \sigma/\sigma_{\rm{SM}} = 57^{+8}_{-6}$, a significant improvement on the previous best limit of $\mu = 205^{+29}_{-22}$

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gross, Eilam
Adye, Tim
Yang, Hongtao
dc:dc.dc:title: Combined measurement of the Higgs boson mass from the $H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^{(*)}\rightarrow \ell\ell\ell\ell$ channels with Run I $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=7$~TeV and $8$~TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A combined measurement of the mass of the Higgs boson by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at the CERN Large Hadron Collider is presented. The measurement is derived from a combined fit to the reconstructed invariant mass spectra of the decay channels $H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^{(*)}\rightarrow \ell\ell\ell\ell$. The dataset used corresponds to an integrated luminosity per experiment ranging from 4.5 to 5.1 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions recorded at center-of-mass energy of 7 TeV, and 19.7 to 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ recorded at 8 TeV. The measured value of the Higgs boson mass is $m_{H} =125.09\pm0.21\mathrm{(stat.)}\pm0.11\mathrm{(syst.)}~\mathrm{GeV}$. The consistency between the mass value measurements from individual decay channels and from individual experiments is within 1$\sigma$.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Canepa, Anadi
dc:dc.dc:title: Selected Highlights from the LHC and HL-LHC Physics Program
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Selected Highlights from the LHC and HL-LHC Physics Program
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: January 26th, 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bawa, Harinder Singh
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent results from Beyond Standard Model (BSM) searches at LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We present the results and prospects for searches beyond the Standard Model (SM) at the LHC by the ATLAS and CMS collaborations. The minimal supersymmetric extension of the SM has been investigated in various configurations at 8TeV center of mass energy at LHC and lower limits are set on the s-particle masses. The searches for other scenarios of physics beyond the SM are also presented. The data are found to be consistent with the Standard Model. The non-observation of a signal is converted to limits at the 95% confidence level(C.L) on the production cross section times branching ratio and on the masses of the hypothesized new particles for appropriate benchmark models (new heavy gauge bosons, extra-dimensions, compositeness or dark matter).
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: I manually added conference name into form above. This is X SILAFAE Conf. held in Medellin, Colombia from Nov 24-28, 2014
