dc:dc.dc:creator: Perepelitsa, Dennis
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet quenching measurements in lead-lead collisions at 2.76 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Measurements of jets from highly energetic partons are considered to be one of the most direct probes of the hot and dense QCD medium produced in ultrarelativistic collisions of large nuclei. These fast partons suffer energy loss and the modification of their parton shower though interactions with the traversed medium. This phenomenon, known as jet quenching, may be experimentally investigated in a variety of ways, such as through measurements of the nuclear modification factor and modifications to the fragmentation function for inclusive high-pT reconstructed jets, or through the angular correlations of jets in multijet production. In this talk, the latest results from measurements of jet quenching in 2.76 TeV lead-lead collisions with the ATLAS detector at the LHC will be presented. The centrality of these collisions is characterized using the total transverse energy in the forward calorimeters, situated at 3.1 < |eta| < 4.9. Jets are reconstructed within the hermetic, large acceptance ATLAS hadronic calorimeter, allowing for a detailed probe of jet quenching phenomena over a wide kinematic range in transverse momentum and rapidity.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: conference start date is 2 February 2015 (but the talk is not until 4 February 2015)

dc:dc.dc:creator: Chen, Chunhui
De Lorenzi, Francesco
Prell, Soeren
Pluth, Daniel
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Type III Seesaw heavy leptons in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS Detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search is presented for production of heavy leptons predicted by the Type III seesaw theory in order to explain the origin of the small neutrino masses. The analysis is performed using the final state that contains two leptons (electron or muon), two jets from a hadronically decaying $W$ boson and large missing transverse momentum. The data used in the measurement corresponds to an integrated luminosity of 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV collected by the ATLAS detector at the LHC. No evidence of heavy lepton production is observed. Depending on the considered theoretical scenarios, heavy leptons with masses below 320-450~GeV are excluded at 95\% confidence level.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Marchiori, Giovanni
dc:dc.dc:title: Prospects for the measurement of the rare Higgs boson decay $H\to\mu\mu$ with 3000 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collisions collected at $\sqrt{s} = 14$ TeV by the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents an updated study of the prospects for the measurement of the rare decay $H\to \mu\mu$ using 3000 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=14$~TeV recorded with the ATLAS detector at the high-luminosity (HL) LHC. Generated samples of the main signal and background processes, combined with parametrisations of the detector performances (efficiencies and resolutions) are used to estimate the expected signal and background yields after a selection similar to the analysis performed in Run 1. The sensitivity of the analysis is improved by classifying events in categories with different $S/B$. A fit to the distribution of the di-muon invariant mass of the selected candidates is used to perform the final discrimination between signal and background, to estimate the significance of the signal yield, to extract the $H\to\mu\mu$ branching ratio and compare it to the Standard Model prediction. For an Asimov dataset generated at 3000 fb$^{-1}$, the fitted signal strength is $\mu = 0.98 \pm 0.13$ and the significance of the signal, estimated from the profile of the likelihood vs $\mu$ upon maximisation of the other nuisance parameters is around $7.7\sigma$ neglecting all systematic uncertainties (including theoretical ones).
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: other author: Charles Delporte (UPMC, Paris)

dc:dc.dc:creator: Brosamer, Jacquelyn
Shapiro, Marjorie
Cooke, Mark
Hinchliffe, Ian
Tibbetts, Mark James
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of jets produced in top quark events using the $e\mu$ final state with 2 $b$-tagged jets in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The transverse momentum $p_T$ and multiplicity of jets produced in top quark events are measured using 20.3fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at a center-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV. Jets are selected from top events requiring an opposite-charge $e\mu$ pair and two $b$-tagged jets in the final state. The data are corrected to obtain the particle-level fiducial cross section $\frac{1}{\sigma_{e\mu+2~b-\textrm{jets}}} \frac{d\sigma_{\mathrm{jet}}}{dp_T}$for additional jets rank 1-4, where rank=1 is the leading additional jet. These distributions are used to obtain the extra jet multiplicity as a function of minimum jet $p_T$ threshold. The $p_T$ distribution of the $b$-jets are also presented.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bertsche, Carolyn
Hawkings, Richard
Strauss, Michael
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of $t\bar t$ production with a veto on additional central jet activity in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This note presents a measurement of the amount of QCD radiation in top quark pair-production ($t\bar t$) events, using dilepton $t\bar t$ events that have an opposite-sign $e\mu$ pair and two $b$-tagged jets in the final state. The measurement includes the complete 2012 ATLAS data sample of 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ integrated luminosity of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8$~\tev{}, and identifies jets containing $b$-quarks with the MV1 tagging algorithm, which leverages the long lifetime, high decay multiplicity, and high mass of $b$-hadrons. The fraction of signal events that does not contain additional jet activity in a central rapidity region is measured as a function of (a) the minimum transverse momentum of any additional jet in the event, and (b) the minimum scalar transverse momentum sum of all additional jets in the event, and the results shown for four central rapidity regions and four invariant mass regions. Compensation for detector effects is applied to the experimental measurement and the results compared at the particle level to simulations by several next-to-leading order (NLO) and leading order (LO) Monte Carlo generators. The resulting gap fraction measurements, in comparison with simulation, can be used to tune Monte Carlo modeling of QCD radiation, which is influenced by parameters such as the choice of renormalisation/factorisation scales, the parton shower matching procedure, and initial and final state radiation simulation. The results may also reduce associated modeling uncertainties for ATLAS top quark physics measurements.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gabaldon, Carolina
Schwienhorst, Reinhard
dc:dc.dc:title: Study of correlation of PDF uncertainty in single top and top pair production at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The incomplete knowledge of parton distribution functions is an important source of systematic uncertainty for top-quark measurements, including top-quark pair and single top-quark production cross sections, as well as for analyses that have a large background from these processes. The correlation of the parton-distribution-function uncertainty is studied for top-quark pair production and single top-quark production in association with a W boson, in final states with two reconstructed leptons. Four types of correlation are studied: between total production cross-sections, between cross-section and acceptance correction, between the two processes for common selection requirements, and between different jet multiplicity requirements. The uncertainty correlation is evaluated for several sets of parton distribution functions using simulated samples of top-quark pair and single top-quark events.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Malek, Fairouz
dc:dc.dc:title: Non-SUSY Beyond Standard Model Searches: Recent Results from ATLAS and CMS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The Standard Model of particle physics is a sensational success, especially since the discovery of the 125 GeV Higgs boson. However, there are still numerous unanswered questions. Why is the Higgs so light? Do the interactions couplings unify and how can gravity be included? Why three fermion generations? What is dark matter? Theories Beyond the Standard Model (BSM), such as Grand Unified Theories, Extra Dimensions or Technicolour are trying to answer these questions. In this proceedings, we will focus on the most recent results obtained by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at the LHC for BSM searches, excluding Higgs and supersymmetry searches. New results on Dark matter, heavy narrow bosons, new heavy quarks and third generation leptoquarks are presented. A summary of the prospects at 14 TeV and at the High Luminosity LHC period is given.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: THE DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 27 2015 Page allocation: Parallel-session talks: 10 – 15 pages

dc:dc.dc:creator: Savage, Graham
dc:dc.dc:title: 8 TeV Non-Resonant Dilepton Search at ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search is conducted for non-resonant new phenomena in dielectron and dimuon final states, originating from either contact interactions or large extra spatial dimensions. The full LHC 2012 proton-proton collision dataset recorded by the ATLAS detector is used, corresponding to 20 fb-1 at √s = 8 TeV. The invariant mass spectrum is used as a discriminating variable alongside forward-backward asymmetry where relevant to increase the search sensitivity. A Bayesian approach is used to set lower limits on the new physics parameters of interest at the 95% credibility level.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The conference starts on the 15th of February 2015.

Demarco, David

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for the associated production of the Higgs boson with a top quark pair in multi-lepton final states with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the associated production of the Higgs boson with a top quark pair is performed in multi-lepton final states using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of proton-proton collision data recorded by the ATLAS experiment at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV at the Large Hadron Collider. Five final states are examined for the presence of the Standard Model Higgs boson with a mass of 125 GeV: two same-charged light leptons ($e$ or $\mu$) without an additional hadronically decaying tau, three light leptons, two same-charged light leptons with an additional hadronically decaying tau, four light leptons, and one light lepton and two hadronically decaying taus. No significant excess of events is observed above the background expectation. The best fit for the $t\bar t H$ production cross section is $2.2 ^{+1.4}_{-1.2}$ times the Standard Model expectation, and the observed (expected) upper limit at the 95% confidence level is 4.6 (2.3) times the Standard Model rate.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Glaysher, Paul
dc:dc.dc:title: A study of VH->Vbb for High Luminosity LHC Running
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: For Standard Model Higgs boson production in the decay mode H -> bb in association with a W or Z boson for High Luminosity LHC Running, the expected signal significance and signal strength is presented for 300 fb-1 and 3000 fb-1 with an average pile-up of <µ>=60 and <µ>=140 respectively.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Sun, Xiaohu
Fang, Yaquan
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for the Heavy Higgs Scalar in 8 TeV $pp$ collisions using the ATLAS detector with the combination of $b\bar{b}\gamma\gamma$, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$, $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ and $b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ final states
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for the Higgs pair using $20~fb^{-1}$ collected by the ATLAS detector in 8 TeV $pp$ collisions is presented. With the combination of $b\bar{b}\gamma\gamma$, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$, $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ and $b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ final states, a 95% confidence level upper limit on the cross section times branching ratio of the non-resonant production is set at XXX pb, while the expected limit is XXX pb. For the resonant production with the mass below 500 GeV, where $b\bar{b}\gamma\gamma$, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$ and $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ are taken into account in the combination, the observed limit ranges between XXX and XXX as a function of heavy higgs mass. For the mass region higer than 500 GeV, $b\bar{b}\tau\tau$, $W^{+}W^{-}\gamma\gamma$ and $b\bar{b}b\bar{b}$ are considered and the observed limit are from XXX and XXX.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bernard, Nathan Rogers
Blackburn, Daniel
Brau, Benjamin
Coccaro, Andrea
Iuppa, Roberto
Lubatti, Henry
Pais, Preema
Russell, Heather Lynn
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for long-lived, weakly-interacting particles that decay to displaced hadronic jets in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search in the ATLAS detector for the decay of neutral, weakly-interacting, long-lived particles in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV in the data recorded in 2012 at the LHC is presented. The search employs techniques for reconstructing decay vertices of long-lived particles decaying to jets in the ATLAS inner tracking detector and muon spectrometer. No significant excess of events is found, and limits are reported for the decay of the Higgs or a scalar boson to long-lived particles and for Hidden Valley and Stealth SUSY benchmark models. The first search results for displaced heavy $Z'$ and Stealth SUSY decays are presented. The upper bound of the exclusion limits are the most stringent to date.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Balek, Petr
Milov, Alexander
dc:dc.dc:title: Data points for ATLAS-HION-2011-03
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Data points for the figures presented in ``Measurement of charged particle spectra in Pb+Pb collisions at $\sqrt{{s}_\mathsf{{NN}}} = {}$2.76TeV with the ATLAS detector at the LHC", https://cds.cern.ch/record/1697487

dc:dc.dc:creator: Whiteson, Daniel
Akesson, Torsten Paul Ake
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for new phenomena in dijet angular distributions in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$~TeV measured with the ATLAS Detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for new phenomena produced in LHC proton-proton collisions at center-of-mass energy $\sqrt{s}=8$~TeV has been performed with the ATLAS detector using an integrated luminosity of 17.3/f. The angular distributions are studied in events with two jets, including dijet masses up to ~5.5 ~TeV. All angular distributions are consistent with the predictions of the Standard Model. In a benchmark model of quark contact interactions, a compositeness scale below XX (YY)~TeV in a destructive (constructive) interference scenario have been set at 95\% CL.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Metcalfe, Jessica
Valencic, Nika
Pleier, Marc-Andre
dc:dc.dc:title: Same-sign WW Scattering Performance Studies with Delphes for the Large Eta Task Force
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The impact of an extended tracker for the future Upgraded ATLAS detector was evaluated for the same sign $WW$ electroweak vector boson scattering process for runs at the high luminosity Large Hadron Collider at $\sqrt{s}$ = 14 TeV. The performance of pileup, jets, and leptons was evaluated and found to have a large impact on the significance of the measurement of ssWW. A silicon tracker extended out to $|\eta|$ $\le$ 4 compared to $|\eta|$ $\le$ 2.5 has the potential to improve the significance of the ssWW measurement by 82\% in a low pileup scenario, $<\mu>$ = 80, or 174\% given $<\mu>$ = 140. The potential discovery of new physics was also evaluated for the gauge boson coupling parameter, $f_{T1}$, in an effective field theory framework.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: supporting note for ATL-COM-PHYS-2015-022

dc:dc.dc:creator: Martin, Tim
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent soft QCD and jet physics results from ATLAS

dc:dc.dc:creator: Limosani, Antonio
Zhou, Chen
Kruse, Mark
Finelli, Kevin Daniel
Paramonov, Alexander
Benjamin, Douglas
Rifki, Othmane
Saavedra, Aldo
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t\bar{t}W$ production cross-section using events with same-sign leptons from $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This document summarizes a measurement of the $t\bar{t}W$ cross-section using a combined likelihood fit to the distribution of $E_T^{\mathrm{miss}}$ and $N_{\mathrm{jets}}$. The measurement uses $20.3\,\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of data from proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}$=8 TeV observed by the ATLAS experiment at CERN. This document is focused on the two same-sign lepton channel intended to improve the accuracy of the cross-section for $t\bar{t}W$ in a multi-channel combination. The measured cross-section of $t\bar{t}W$ production using only the same-sign channels described in this note is $429\pm100$ fb using the 1 and 2 $b$-tagged jets samples. Using only the 2 $b$-tagged jet sample, the cross-section is measured to be $490\pm128$ fb for $t\bar{t}W$ These measurements correspond to $t\bar{t}W$ signal significances of $5.1\sigma$ and $5.0\sigma$, respectively.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: One of five supporting notes (2LOS, 2LSS, 3L, 4L, combination) for the paper TOPQ-2013-05, “Measurement of the tt¯W and tt¯Z production cross sections in pp collisions at s√=8 TeV with the ATLAS detector” submitted on 2015/09/17 to JHEP

dc:dc.dc:creator: Ferrari, Arnaud
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for Higgs bosons beyond the Standard Model using the ATLAS experiment
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Two searches for additional charged and neutral Higgs bosons, as predicted by Two-Higgs-Doublet Models, are presented. These analyses are based on the 2012 pp collision dataset collected by ATLAS at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV. Upper limits are presented, as well as their interpretation in CP-conserving 2HDMs.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: LLWI 2015 starts on February 15th.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cooper-Sarkar, Amanda
dc:dc.dc:title: PDF uncertainties in precision electroweak measurements, including the W mass, in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Now that the Higgs mass is known all the parameters of the SM are known- but with what accuracy? Precision EW measurements test the self-consistency of the SM- and thus can give hints of BSM physics. Precision measurements of $sin^2\theta _W$ and the W mass are limited by PDF uncertainties This contribution discusses these uncertainties and what can be done to improve them.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date 16th february

dc:dc.dc:creator: Pozdnyakov, Valery
Vertogradova, Iuliia
dc:dc.dc:title: Luminosity determination from two-photon production of di-muon pairs in PbPb collisions at sqrt(s) = 2.76 TeV using the ATLAS detector in 2011
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The note describes the measurement of the integrated luminosity collected by the ATLAS experiment during 2011 heavy ion run. The measurement was done with muon pairs produced in well-calculable, purely electromagnetic two-photon interactions. The analysis was performed with the data taken by the ATLAS experiment during LHC Pb-Pb run in 2011 at the beam energy of 1.38 TeV per nucleon

dc:dc.dc:creator: Spagnolo, Stefania
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of vector boson with associated jet production with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Productions of light and heavy-flavour jets in association with a W or a Z boson in proton-proton collisions are important processes to study QCD in multi-scale environments and the proton parton content. Cross sections, differential in several kinematics variables, have been measured with the ATLAS detector in 7 TeV proton-proton collisions and compared to high-order QCD calculations and Monte Carlo simulations. The production of heavy flavour in association with a W or Z boson is sensitive to parton density functions and the modelling of heavy-quark flavour production mechanisms.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Slides for talk at LLWI2015 Conference start date 15 Feb 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Jansky, Roland Wolfgang
dc:dc.dc:title: Novel methods and expected run II performance of ATLAS track reconstruction in dense environments
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Detailed understanding and optimal track reconstruction performance of ATLAS in the core of high pT objects is paramount for a number of techniques such as jet energy and mass calibration, jet flavour tagging, and hadronic tau identification as well as measurements of physics quantities like jet fragmentation functions. These dense environments are characterized by charged particle separations on the order of the granularity of ATLAS’s inner detector. With the insertion of a new innermost layer in this tracking detector, which allows measurements closer to the interaction point, and an increase in the centre of mass energy, these difficult environments will become even more relevant in Run II, such as in searches for heavy resonances. Novel algorithmic developments to the ATLAS track reconstruction software targeting these topologies as well as the expected improved performance will be presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: LLWI15 start date: 16 February

dc:dc.dc:creator: Cheatham, Susan
dc:dc.dc:title: Overview of PDF-sensitive measurements from Run I in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Slides for PDF 15, 15-21 February 2015
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: 16 February

dc:dc.dc:creator: Jakoubek, Tomas
dc:dc.dc:title: Flavour-tagged time-dependent angular analysis of the $B_s^0 \rightarrow J/\psi(\mu^+\mu^-)\Phi(K^+K^-)$ decay with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: We present a flavour tagged time dependent angular analysis of the $B_s \rightarrow J/\psi\phi$ decay, using 4.9 fb$^{−1}$ of integrated luminosity collected by the ATLAS detector from 7 TeV proton-proton collisions recorded in 2011. CP violation in this channel is described by a weak phase $\phi_s$, which is sensitive to new physics contributions. The measured value is $\phi_s$ = 0.12 $\pm$ 0.25 (stat.) $\pm$ 0.05 (syst.) rad, which is in good agreement with Standard Model expectations. Also other measured parameters are consistent with the world average.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date: 15/02/2015

dc:dc.dc:title: Electroweak Measurements with the ATLAS Detector

dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Exotic Decays of the Higgs Boson with the ATLAS Detector

dc:dc.dc:creator: Wildauer, Andreas
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent top-physics results from ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The top quark is the heaviest known fundamental particle. As it is the only quark that decays before it hadronizes, it gives a unique opportunity to probe the properties of bare quarks. This talk will focus on a few recent precision measurements by the ATLAS Collaboration of the top quark: fiducial top pair and single top production cross sections including differential distributions will be presented, alongside measurements of top quark properties. Interpretations in terms of limits on beyond the Standard Model physics using top quarks will also be presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Lake Louise Winter Institute, Start 15.02.2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dao, Valerio
Guindon, Stefan
Shabalina, Elizaveta
Vazquez Schroeder, Tamara
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the associated production of a vector boson (W, Z) and top quark pair in the opposite sign dilepton channel with $\boldsymbol{pp}$ collisions at $\boldsymbol{\sqrt{s} = 8}$ TeV with the ATLAS detector at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the production of vector bosons (W, Z) in association with a pair of top quarks ($t\bar{t}V$) is presented. The analysis uses 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at $\sqrt{s}=8TeV$, collected with the ATLAS detector of the Large Hadron Collider. The search focuses on final states containing two opposite-sign leptons, electrons or muons. A $t\bar{t}V$ signal strength $\hat{\mu} = 0.63^{+0.64}_{-0.58}$ times the Standard Model value is obtained, with an observed significance of 1.09 $\sigma$. Additionally, a model-independent two-dimensional fit is performed to measure the signal strength of both $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ processes.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: One of five supporting notes (2LOS, 2LSS, 3L, 4L, combination) for the paper TOPQ-2013-05, “Measurement of the tt¯W and tt¯Z production cross sections in pp collisions at s√=8 TeV with the ATLAS detector” submitted on 2015/09/17 to JHEP

dc:dc.dc:creator: Gignac, Matthew
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for direct pair production of a chargino and a neutralino decaying to the 125 GeV Higgs boson with 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of 8 TeV pp collisions using the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search is presented for the direct pair production of a chargino and a neutralino $pp$ $\rightarrow$ $\tilde{\chi}^{\pm}_{1}$$\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{2}$, where the chargino decays to the lightest neutralino and the $W$ boson, $\tilde{\chi}^{\pm}_{1}$ $\rightarrow$ $\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{1}$ $(W^{\pm}\to\ell^{\pm}\nu)$, while the neutralino decays to the lightest neutralino and the 125~GeV Higgs boson, $\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{2}$ $\rightarrow$ $\tilde{\chi}^{0}_{1}$ $(h\to bb/\gamma\gamma/\ell^{\pm}\nu qq)$. The final states considered for the search have large missing transverse momentum, an isolated electron or muon, and one of the following: either two jets identified as originating from bottom quarks, or two photons, or a second electron or muon with the same electric charge. The analysis is based on 20.3fb$^{-1}$ of $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV proton$-$proton collision data delivered by the Large Hadron Collider and recorded with the ATLAS detector. Observations are consistent with the Standard Model expectations, and limits are set in the context of a simplified supersymmetric model.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date: February 15th 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Santoyo Castillo, Itzebelt
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for electroweak production of supersymmetry, supersymmetry in resonance production, R-parity violating signatures and events with long-lived particles with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This talk summarises the latest ATLAS results in the context of searches for electroweak production of supersymmetric particles, R-Parity violating/conserving SUSY scenarios, and long-lived supersymmetric particles using the full 2012 data corresponding to 20.3~fb^{-1} at \sqrt{s} = 8~TeV of p-p collisions collected by the ATLAS.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Start date 15/02/2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: Sawyer, Craig
Young, Christopher John
Issever, Cigdem
Lopez Mateos, David
dc:dc.dc:title: Monte Carlo Calibration and Combination of In-situ Measurements of Jets in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The stages in the final Run-1 jet energy scale calibration in the ATLAS detector are described. The Monte Carlo based calibration is discussed for both small and large radius jets and the final combination of various in-situ measurements and the resultant jet energy scale uncertainty is presented. Finally the combination of in-situ measurements of the jet energy resolution and associated uncertainties is discussed.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet global sequential corrections with the ATLAS detector in proton-proton collisions at sqrt(s) = 8 TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The determination of the jet energy scale and the achievement of the optimal performance in terms of jet energy resolution are of key importance to many LHC physics analyses. This note describes sequential jet corrections, derived from Monte Carlo simulated events and using global properties of the jet, which improves the performance of the existing calibration schemes used in ATLAS. Performance improvements are achieved by using tracking, calorimeter energy deposit, and muon spectrometer information. The performance of the GS corrections using Monte Carlo simulated events, and the validation on data using the 2012 dataset at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV, are presented. The corrections have been derived in the full pseudorapidity ($\eta$) and transverse momentum ($p_{\rm T}$) ranges considered in ATLAS analyses. The relative improvement in resolution increases with the $p_{\rm T}$ and can go up to 35%, depending on the $\eta$ of the jet and the initial calibration applied. The fragmentation differences between jets initiated by a quark and jets initiated by a gluon lead to a flavour dependence in the jet energy scale. The relative improvement in the flavour dependence after applying the global sequential corrections ranges typically between 20% (80%) at low (high) $p_{\rm T}$, depending also on the $\eta$ of the jet and the initial calibration applied.

dc:dc.dc:title: Higgs Boson Coupling Measurements from the Combination of All Decay Channels
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment

dc:dc.dc:creator: Zimmermann, Christoph
Schott, Matthias
Karnevskiy, Mikhail
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of mW at 7 TeV : Muon efficiency corrections and uncertainties
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The muon reconstruction and isolation-cut efficiency impacts significantly the predicted shape of the lepton $p_T$ in $W\rightarrow\mu\nu$ events and plays therefore a crucial role in the W boson mass measurement. A correct modeling of these quantities in Monte Carlo simulations is therefore from high relevance. We reestimate these correction factors also in various dependencies and estimate systematic uncertainties that are specifically targeted to a propagation from Z- to W-boson samples, which are based on the same MC-generator.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Adye, Tim
Gadatsch, Stefan
Gross, Eilam
Yang, Hongtao
dc:dc.dc:title: Combined measurement of the Higgs boson mass in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 7 TeV and 8 TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The measurement of the Higgs boson mass using the combined datasets collected by ATLAS and CMS in the decay channels $H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma$ and $H \rightarrow ZZ^{(*)}\rightarrow \ell\ell\ell\ell$ is presented. The results are obtained from the simultaneous determination of the position of the reconstructed invariant mass peaks in the two channels of the two experiments. The measured value of the Higgs boson mass is $m_{H} =125.09\pm0.21\mathrm{(stat.)}\pm0.11\mathrm{(syst.)}~\mathrm{GeV}$. All results in the individual channels are found to be consistent among themselves and with the combined measurement. Up to date, this is the most precise measurement of the last experimentally accessed fundamental parameter of the standard model.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kalderon, Charles William
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for squarks and gluinos with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Recent searches for squarks and gluinos at ATLAS are described, notably 1/2 leptons + jets + ETmiss, monophoton + ETmiss and Scalar charm.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Conference start date: 16/02/15 Talk date: 17/02/15 (18/02 CET...)

dc:dc.dc:creator: Hance, Michael
Yu, David Ren-hwa
Heinemann, Beate
Wiik, Liv Antje Mari
Dingfelder, Jochen
Winter, Benedict Tobias
Urquijo, Phillip
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for heavy leptons producing trilepton resonances in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for trilepton resonances decaying to a Z boson and an electron or muon is presented. The search is based on of pp collision data taken at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV and correspond to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{−1}$, collected by the ATLAS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider. Three high-momentum electrons or muons are selected, with two of them required to be consistent with coming from a Z boson decay. The events are categorized based on the presence or absence of additional leptons or dijet pairs in the event consistent with the decay products of a heavy lepton. No significant excess above Standard Model predictions is observed, and 95% confidence level limits on the production of trilepton resonances beyond the Standard Model are derived. The results are interpreted in the context of two models of new heavy leptons decaying to three charged leptons. In the vector-like lepton model, masses of new heavy charged leptons are constrained to be greater than xxx GeV, while in the type-III Seesaw scenario, the heavy leptons are constrained to have masses greater than xxx GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bessidskaia Bylund, Olga
Khandanyan, Hovhannes
Mcfayden, Joshua Angus
Sjoelin, Joergen
Suruliz, Kerim
Gellerstedt, Karl
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the $t \bar t Z$ and $t \bar t W$ production cross sections in final states with three leptons or two same-sign muons with 20.3 $\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ of $\sqrt s = 8$ TeV $pp$ collision data collected by the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ production at the ATLAS detector at the LHC is presented. The search is performed on $20.3 \, {\rm fb}^{-1}$ of data collected by the ATLAS detector in 2012. Final states with three leptons and two same-sign muons are considered in which the $Z$ or non-top $W$ bosons decay to a pair of leptons, and one of the $W$ bosons coming from $t\to bW$ decays gives rise to a charged lepton. In a simultaneous fit for $t\bar{t}Z$ and $t\bar{t}W$ production, the $t\bar{t}Z$ production signal strength with respect to the Standard Model is measured to be $0.74^{+0.32}_{-0.28}$ with a significance of 3.1$\sigma$ (3.7$\sigma$ expected), and the $t\bar{t}W$ production signal strength is measured to be $1.35^{+0.61}_{-0.51}$ with a significance of 3.1$\sigma$ (2.3$\sigma$ expected).
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: One of five supporting notes (2LOS, 2LSS, 3L, 4L, combination) for the paper TOPQ-2013-05, “Measurement of the tt¯W and tt¯Z production cross sections in pp collisions at s√=8 TeV with the ATLAS detector” submitted on 2015/09/17 to JHEP

dc:dc.dc:creator: Blackburn, Daniel
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for dark matter and signs of Composite Higgs with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: An overview of searches for composite Higgs bosons and dark matter with ATLAS is presented. Results of these searches for Run-1 data, collected at a center of mass energy of 8 TeV, are presented.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: LLWI2015 conference start date February 15th

dc:dc.dc:creator: Beacham, James Baker
Cranmer, Kyle
Haas, Andy
Kaplan, Benjamin
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for new phenomena in events with at least three photons collected in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 8 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Results of a search for new phenomena in events with at least three photons are reported. Data from proton-proton collisions at a centre-of-mass energy of 8 TeV and corresponding to 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ were collected with the ATLAS detector at the LHC. The observed data are well described by the Standard Model (SM). Limits at the 95% confidence level on new phenomena are presented based on the rate of events in an inclusive fiducial region, a restricted fiducial region focusing on the rare decay $Z\to 3\gamma$, and di-photon and tri-photon resonance searches. For a SM Higgs boson decaying to four photons via intermediate pseudoscalar $a$ particles, limits are found to be $\sigma \times BR(h \rightarrow aa) \times BR(a \rightarrow \gamma \gamma)^{2} \lesssim 4 \times 10^{-4} \sigma_{SM}$ for 10 $< m_{a} <$ 62 GeV. Limits are also presented for Higgs boson-like scalars ($H$) for $m_{H} > $ 125 GeV, and for a $Z'$ decaying to three photons via $Z' \rightarrow a+\gamma \rightarrow 3\gamma$. Additionally, the observed limit on the branching ratio of a SM $Z$ boson decaying to three photons is found to be $BR(Z \rightarrow 3\gamma) < 2.17 \times 10^{-6}$, a result five times stronger than the previous result from LEP.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Volpi, Guido
dc:dc.dc:title: Physics prospects with the upgraded ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Run-I at the LHC has been very successful, including the discovery of a new particle with a mass of about 125 GeV and with properties compatible with those of the Standard Model Higgs boson within uncertainties. Precise measurements of the properties of this boson, and the discovery of new physics beyond the Standard Model, are primary goals of future running at the LHC. The physics prospects based on 300/fb and 3000/fb proton-proton collision data to be collected at 14 TeV are presented. The ultimate precision attainable on measurements of the couplings of the 125 GeV particle to elementary fermions and bosons is discussed, as well as perspectives on the searches for partners associated with this new object, predicted by several extensions of the standard theory. Supersymmetry is one of the best motivated and well-studied extensions of the Standard Model. The current searches at the LHC have yielded sensitivity to TeV scale gluinos and 1st and 2nd generation squarks, as well as to 3rd generation squarks and electro-weakinos in the hundreds of GeV mass range. Benchmark studies are presented to show how the discovery potential can be extended for inclusive strong production of squarks and gluinos, direct production of 3rd generation squarks and weak production of electro-weakinos A considerable fraction of the parameter space for a wide variety of other models has been probed with the 8 TeV data. The prospects of searches for new heavy bosons and dark matter candidates at 14 TeV are explored here. For all these studies, a parameterised simulation of the Upgraded ATLAS detector is used, taking into account the expected pileup conditions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Radescu, Voica
dc:dc.dc:title: Plans for PDF measurements at Run II and role of PDFs in MC tuning in ATLAS

dc:dc.dc:title: Summary plots for overall SUSY mass reach, direct stop, EWK chargino/neutralino production

dc:dc.dc:creator: Kopeliansky, Revital
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for heavy long-lived charged particles with the ATLAS detector in p-p collisions at √(S) = 8 TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment

dc:dc.dc:creator: Plotnikova, Elena
dc:dc.dc:title: Two–particle Bose–Einstein Correlations in $pp$–collisions at $\sqrt{s} = $ 0.9 and 7 TeV measured with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Studies of one–dimensional Bose–Einstein Correlations for pairs of like–sign charged particles measured in the kinematic range $p_{T}$ > 100 MeV and $|\eta|$ < 2.5 in $pp$-collisions at $\sqrt{s} = $ 0.9 and 7 TeV with the ATLAS detector at the CERN Large Hadron Collider, are presented. The integrated luminosities are about 7 $μb^{−1}$, 190 $μb^{−1}$ and 12.4 $nb^{−1}$ for 0.9 TeV, 7 TeV minimum–bias and 7 TeV high–multiplicity data samples, respectively. The multiplicity dependence of the BEC parameters characterizing the correlation strength $\lambda$ and the correlation source size $R$ are investigated at charged–particle multiplicities of up to 240. A saturation effect in the multiplicity dependence of the correlation source size $R$ is observed using the high–multiplicity 7 TeV data sample. The dependence of the BEC parameters on the average transverse momentum of the particle pair is also investigated.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Potter, Christina
dc:dc.dc:title: Standard Model cross-section summaries for February 2015
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Summary plots representing measured cross-sections and limits for various Standard Model processes. The figures include preliminary and published results at $\sqrt{s} = 7\,$TeV and $\sqrt{s} = 8\,$TeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bona, Marcella
dc:dc.dc:title: Recent B physics results from ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment

dc:dc.dc:creator: Schreyer, Manuel
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Supersymmetry in events with a Z boson, jets and large $E_{T}^{\text{miss}}$ with ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for supersymmetric particles in final states containing a Z boson, jets and large missing transverse momentum is presented. The data sample was collected at a centre-of-mass energy $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV by the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider and corresponds to an integrated luminosity of $20.3\ \text{fb}^{−1}$. The search targets GGM models in which Z bosons can arise in the decays of the SUSY particles. An excess of events above the expected Standard-Model background is observed, with a significance of 3.0 standard deviations.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: 4 March 2015, 121st LHCC Meeting

dc:dc.dc:creator: Dallaire, Frederick
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for Heavy Resonances with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A summary of the searches for heavy resonances with the ATLAS detector. Recent results are presented for various final state including dilepton, dijet, lepton+MET, diboson (WW/ZZ/WZ) and HH. Independent limits are shown and constraints set on the parameters of different models. All the analyses were performed at sqrt(s) = 8 TeV with 20 fb-1 of data.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Lake Louise Winter Institute 2015, starting on Feb. 15th

dc:dc.dc:creator: Grevtsov, Kirill
dc:dc.dc:title: Electron and photon energy calibration with the ATLAS detector using LHC Run 1 data
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This poster presents the electron and photon energy calibration achieved with the ATLAS detector using about 25 fb$^{-1}$ of LHC proton–proton collision data taken at centre-of-mass energies of $\sqrt{s}$ = 7 and 8 TeV. The reconstruction of electron and photon energies is optimised using multivariate algorithms. The response of the calorimeter layers is equalised in data and simulation, and the longitudinal profile of the electromagnetic showers is exploited to estimate the passive material in front of the calorimeter and reoptimise the detector simulation. After all corrections, the $Z$ resonance is used to set the absolute energy scale. For electrons from $Z$ decays, the achieved calibration is typically accurate to 0.05% in most of the detector acceptance, rising to 0.2% in regions with large amounts of passive material. The remaining inaccuracy is less than 0.2–1% for electrons with a transverse energy of 10 GeV, and is on average 0.3% for photons. The detector resolution is determined with a relative inaccuracy of less than 10% for electrons and photons up to 60 GeV transverse energy, rising to 40% for transverse energies above 500 GeV.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Glatzer, Julian Maximilian Volker
Hawkings, Richard
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the ttbb production cross section and the ratio of σ(ttbb) and σ(ttjj)using all di-lepton channels in pp collisions at sqrt(s) = 8 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the cross-section of ttbb, the associated production of top-quark pairs with b−quark pairs, with the ATLAS detector at the LHC is presented. The analysis is based on proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 /fb and focuses on dileptonic tt events in the electron-electron, electron-muon and the muon-muon channels. These events are selected using a tt->l+l− +4 jets selection, where two b-jets are required. The number of events for the ttbb process is obtained using a maximum likelihood method based on the b-tagging discrimination variable of the third and fourth jet if ordered by the same variable. The fiducial cross section of the ttbb process and the ratio of the cross sections for ttbb and four-jet ttbar production is measured.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Qian, Jianming
Verkerke, Wouter
Gadatsch, Stefan
Mudd, Richard
Zhang, Fangzhou
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the Higgs boson production and decay rates and tests of its couplings to vector bosons and fermions using the 7 and 8 TeV data in ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Combined analyses of the Higgs boson production and decay rates as well as its couplings to vector bosons and fermions are presented. Included in the combina- tions are the results of the decay modes H → γγ, ZZ∗, WW∗, Zγ, bb ̄, ττ and μμ, and the constraints on the associated production with a pair of top quark and on the off-shell couplings of the Higgs boson. The results are based on the proton-proton collision datasets of approximately 4.5 fb−1 at 7 TeV and 20.3 fb−1 at 8 TeV recor- ded by the ATLAS detector in 2011 and 2012 respectively. The Higgs boson signal yields relative to their standard model predications at a mass of 125.36 GeV are reported for individual production processes and their combinations. Combining all production modes and decay channels, the measured signal yield is 1.xx ± xx ± xx relative to its SM expectation. The couplings of the Higgs boson to vector bosons and fermions are tested in benchmark models of various hypotheses. All results are found to be consistent with those expected from the standard model Higgs boson at 125.36 GeV within the current precision.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Khanov, Alexander
Rizatdinova, Flera
Saleem, Muhammad
Yu, Jie
dc:dc.dc:title: Auxiliary material: measurements of the top pair production cross-section in 8 TeV proton-proton collisions using kinematic information in lepton+jets channel
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Auxiliary material for the paper: Measurements of the top pair production cross-section in 8 TeV proton-proton collisions using kinematic information in lepton+jets channel, which is missing in the main entry.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Calace, Noemi
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurements of the W production cross section in association with jets and of the ratio of the production cross sections for W and Z bosons in association with jets with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The study of the production of a Z or W boson with accompanying hadronic jets is one of the most important Standard Model (SM) processes in high-energy hadron-hadron collisions providing a unique test-bench for QCD in the kinematic region accessible at the LHC. Since the individual measurements of kinematic observables in W + jets and Z + jets events are affected by experimental and theoretical systematic uncertainties the measurement of ratios of the production cross section of V + jets (Rjets) was designed to exploit the cancellation of these uncertainties, building the foundations of a high precision test of perturbative QCD (pQCD), sensitive to direct contribution from new particles production or interactions beyond the SM. The cross sections for the production of a W boson in association with jets and the Rjets measurement have been measured in protonproton collision at sqrt(s) = 7 TeV with the ATLAS experiment at the LHC with the data sample accumulated in 2011, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 4.6 fb^(-1). The Rjets measurement is done for the electon and muon decay channels of the W and Z bosons for jets with transverse momentum pT > 30GeV and rapidity |y| < 4.4. Rjets is measured as a function of many observables and the results are compared to several Monte Carlo generators and with next-toleading order pQCD predictions.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Angerami, Aaron
Cole, Brian
Kosek, Tomas
Perepelitsa, Dennis
Rybar, Martin
Spousta, Martin
Santos, Helena
dc:dc.dc:title: Jet energy scale and its uncertainty for jets reconstructed using the ATLAS heavy ion jet algorithm: HI JES
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The jet energy scale (JES) and its systematic uncertainty are determined for jets measured with the ATLAS detector at the LHC, reconstructed using techniques developed for jet measurements for heavy ion (HI) collisions. The JES is constructed by calibrating the HI jets with respect to the standard jets using the analysis of proton-proton pp collision data. The latter have a well-defined calibration procedure and uncertainty that includes input from various data-driven studies. The calibration of the HI jets is performed using sqrt(s)=8 TeV pp data recorded in 2012 where the performance of the standard jets is well understood. A procedure to adapt the HI JES and its uncertainty to different data samples recorded by ATLAS including pp collisions at sqrt(s)=2.76 TeV, Pb+Pb collisions at sqrt(s_NN)=2.76 TeV and p+Pb collisions at sqrt(s_NN)=5.02 TeV is presented. Finally, the energy scale for jets affected by quenching is studied using Monte Carlo and the uncertainties on the JES obtained from this procedure are validated in data.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Bachacou, Henri
Montejo Berlingen, Javier
Helsens, Clement
Succurro, Antonella
Juste Rozas, Aurelio
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for production of vector-like quark pairs and of four top quarks in the lepton plus jets final state in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A search for pair production of vector-like quarks, both up-type ($T$) and down-type ($B$), as well as for four-top-quark production, is presented. The search is based on $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV recorded in 2012 with the ATLAS detector at the CERN Large Hadron Collider and corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{-1}$. Data are analysed in the lepton-plus-jets final state, characterised by an isolated electron or muon with high transverse momentum, large missing transverse momentum and multiple jets. Dedicated analyses are performed targeting three cases: a $T$ quark with significant branching ratio to a $W$ boson and a $b$-quark ($T\bar{T} \to Wb$+X), and both a $T$ quark and a $B$ quark with significant branching ratio to a Higgs boson and a third-generation quark ($T\bar{T} \to Ht$+X and $B\bar{B} \to Hb$+X respectively). No significant excess of events above the Standard Model expectation is observed, and 95% CL lower limits are derived on the masses of the vector-like $T$ and $B$ quarks under several branching ratio hypotheses assuming contributions from $T \to Wb$, $Zt$, $Ht$ and $B \to Wt$, $Zb$, $Hb$ decays. The 95% CL observed lower limits on the $T$ quark mass range between 715 GeV and 950 GeV for all possible values of the branching ratios into the three decay modes, and are the most stringent constraints to date. Additionally, the most restrictive upper bounds on four-top-quark production are set in a number of new physics scenarios.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Penc, Ondrej
dc:dc.dc:title: Performance and development for the Inner Detector Trigger Algorithms at ATLAS
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A redesign of the tracking algorithms for the ATLAS trigger for Run 2 starting in spring 2015 is in progress. The ATLAS HLT software has been restructured to run as a more flexible single stage HLT, instead of two separate stages (Level 2 and Event Filter) as in Run 1. The new tracking strategy employed for Run 2 will use a Fast Track Finder (FTF) algorithm to seed subsequent Precision Tracking, and will result in improved track parameter resolution and faster execution times than achieved during Run 1. The performance of the new algorithms has been evaluated to identify those aspects where code optimisation would be most beneficial. The performance and timing of the algorithms for electron and muon reconstruction in the trigger are presented. The profiling infrastructure, constructed to provide prompt feedback from the optimisation, is described, including the methods used to monitor the relative performance improvements as the code evolves.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: 4th of March 2015

Montejo Berlingen, Javier
Le Menedeu, Eve
Rubbo, Francesco
Macdonald, Calum Michael
D'Onofrio, Monica
Anders, John Kenneth
Lerner, Giuseppe
dc:dc.dc:title: Summary of the ATLAS Run-I searches for direct pair production of third generation squarks at the Large Hadron Collider
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The extensive effort performed by the ATLAS collaboration to search for the existence of the scalar partners of the top and bottom quarks in proton-proton collisions at a centre-of- mass energy of √s = 8 TeV is reviewed and extended. New analyses are introduced, that improve the sensitivity to specific regions of the model parameter space. New exclusion limits, obtained as the combination of several analyses, are presented both using a simplified model framework, where simple decay chains involving few particles are assumed, and in more complete pMSSM models. The paper results in a comprehensive summary of all the ATLAS searches for the superpartners of the third generation quarks.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Knapik, Joanna
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the total proton - proton cross section at $\sqrt{s}=$ 7 TeV with the ATLAS detector at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The measurement of total proton-proton cross section at $\sqrt{s}=$ 7 TeV with the ATLAS detectors system at the LHC is presented. The data used for the analysis were collected with the ALFA detector system of the ATLAS Experiment. The measurement method is based on the optical theorem. The obtained cross section value is $\sigma_{tot}=$ 95.35 $\pm$ 1.36 mb. The measurement is compared to other published measurements of the total proton-proton cross section.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: This document is the proceedings of a talk from young researchers session at XXI Cracow Epiphany Conference, Cracow, 8-10 January 2015. Conference proceedings deadline is 31th March 2015.

dc:dc.dc:creator: Calandri, Alessandro
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the off-shell Higgs boson signal strength in the high mass ZZ and WW final states with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This poster is focused on the indirect measurement of the Higgs boson width through the constraints on the off-shell Higgs coupling in the high mass region using the H->4l decay channel. The production cross section for the off-shell Higgs boson with decay into vector bosons is proportional to the product of the couplings squared for production and decay. Unlike the on-shell cross section, this observable is independent of the total Higgs width. Therefore, the ratio of the on and off-shell couplings provides an indirect measurement on the total Higgs width. Two different versions of the posters (CONF note and paper results) are provided.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: 121st LHCC Meeting, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, 4 - 5 Mar 2015

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for pair-produced long-lived neutral particles decaying in the ATLAS hadronic calorimeter in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN is used to search for the decay of a scalar boson to a pair of long-lived particles, neutral under the Standard Model gauge group, in 20.3~fb$^{-1}$ of data collected in proton--proton collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$TeV. This search is sensitive to long-lived particles that decay to Standard Model particles producing jets at the outer edge of the ATLAS electromagnetic calorimeter or inside the hadronic calorimeter. No significant excess of events is observed. Limits are reported on the product of the scalar boson production cross section times branching ratio into long-lived neutral particles as a function of the proper lifetime of the particles. Limits are reported for boson masses from 100~GeV to 900~GeV, and a long-lived neutral particle mass from 10~GeV to 150~GeV.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Please enter your comments on CDS by Friday, January 30. The open presentation (version no. 1) / public reading (version no. 2) will follow shortly after. The authorlist for this paper can be found here: <https://atlas-authdb.web.cern.ch/atlas-authdb/authorlists/papers.html>

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Combined measurement of the Higgs boson mass in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 7$~TeV and $8$~TeV at the LHC
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A measurement of the Higgs boson mass is presented based on the combined data samples of the ATLAS and CMS experiments in the \ensuremath{H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma} and \ensuremath{H \rightarrow ZZ \rightarrow \ell\ell\ell\ell} decay channels. The results are obtained from a simultaneous fit to the reconstructed invariant mass peak in the two channels and for the two experiments. The measured masses from the individual channels and the two experiments are found to be consistent among themselves. The combined measurement of the Higgs boson mass is $m_{H} =125.09\pm0.21\mathrm{(stat.)}\pm0.11\mathrm{(syst.)}~\mathrm{GeV}$.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Please enter your comments on CDS by Sunday, March 15. The public reading will follow shortly after. The authorlist for this paper can be found here: <https://atlas-authdb.web.cern.ch/atlas-authdb/authorlists/papers.html>

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the forward-backward asymmetry of electron and muon pair-production in $pp$ collisions at $\sqrt{s}$ = 7 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: This paper presents measurements from the ATLAS experiment of the forward-backward asymmetry in the reaction $pp\rightarrow Z/\gamma^{*}\rightarrow l^{+}l^{-}$, with $l$ being electrons or muons, and the extraction of the effective weak mixing angle. The results are based on the full set of data collected in 2011 in $pp$ collisions at the LHC at $\sqrt{s}$ = 7 TeV, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 4.8 fb$^{-1}$. The measured asymmetry values are found to be in agreement with the corresponding Standard Model predictions. The combination of the muon and electron channels yields a value of the effective weak mixing angle of $0.2308 \pm 0.0005 \mathrm{(stat.)} \pm 0.0006 \mathrm{(syst.)} \pm 0.0009\mathrm{(PDF)}$, where the first uncertainty corresponds to data statistics, the second to systematic effects and the third to knowledge of the parton density functions. This result agrees with the current world average from the Particle Data Group fit.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Please enter your comments on CDS by Thursday, March 26. The open presentation (version no. 1) / public reading (version no. 2) will follow shortly after. The authorlist for this paper can be found here: <https://atlas-authdb.web.cern.ch/atlas-authdb/authorlists/papers.html>

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Observation and measurements of the production of prompt and non-prompt J/$\psi$ mesons in association with a Z boson in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: The production of a Z boson in association with a J/$\psi$ meson in proton–proton collisions probes the production mechanisms of quarkonium and heavy flavour in association with vector bosons, and allows studies of multiple parton scattering. Using 20.3 fb$^{−1}$ of data collected with the ATLAS experiment at the LHC, in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV, the first measurement of associated Z + J/$\psi$ production is presented for both prompt and non-prompt J/$\psi$ production, with both signatures having a significance in excess of 5$\sigma$. The inclusive production cross-sections for Z boson production (in $\mu^+ \mu^-$ or $e^+ e^−$ decay modes) in association with prompt and non-prompt J/$\psi$ ($\to \mu^+ \mu^-$) are measured relative to the inclusive production rate of Z bosons in the same fiducial volume to be (36.8 $\pm$ 6.7 $\pm$ 2.5) $\times 10^{−7}$ and (65.8 $\pm$ 9.2 $\pm$ 4.2) $\times 10^{−7}$ respectively. Normalised differential production cross-section ratios are also determined as a function of the J/$\psi$ transverse momentum. The fraction of signal events arising from single and double parton scattering is estimated, and a lower limit of 5.3 (3.7)mb at 68 (95)\% confidence level is placed on the effective cross-section regulating double parton interactions.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: The new draft is the result of the response to the journal referee. The new draft differs from the submitted draft to some degree, as explained on the second page of the document. We circulate the new draft for three days. Please enter your comments on CDS by Monday, March 23. The authorlist for this paper can be found here: <https://atlas-authdb.web.cern.ch/atlas-authdb/authorlists/papers.html>

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Measurement of the correlation between flow harmonics of different order in lead-lead collisions at $\sqrt{s_{_{NN}}}$=2.76 TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Correlations between the elliptic or triangular flow coefficients $v_m$ ($m=2$ or 3) and other flow harmonics $v_n$ ($n=2$ to 5) are measured using $\sqrt{s_{_{NN}}}=2.76$ TeV Pb+Pb collision data collected in 2010 by the ATLAS experiment at the LHC, corresponding to an integrated lumonisity of 7 $\mu$b$^{-1}$. The $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations are measured in midrapidity as a function of centrality, and, for events within the same centrality interval, as a function of event ellipticity or triangularity defined in a forward rapidity region. For events within the same centrality interval, $v_3$ is found to be anticorrelated with $v_2$ and this anticorrelation is consistent with similar anticorrelations between the corresponding eccentricities $\epsilon_2$ and $\epsilon_3$. On the other hand, it is observed that $v_4$ increases strongly with $v_2$, and $v_5$ increases strongly with both $v_2$ and $v_3$. The trend and strength of the $v_m$-$v_n$ correlations for $n=4$ and 5 are found to disagree with $\epsilon_m$-$\epsilon_n$ correlations predicted by initial-geometry models. Instead, these correlations are found to be consistent with the combined effects of a linear contribution to $v_n$ and a nonlinear term that is a function of $v_2^2$ or of $v_2v_3$, as predicted by hydrodynamic models. A simple two-component fit is used to separate these two contributions. The extracted linear and nonlinear contributions to $v_4$ and $v_5$ are found to be consistent with previously measured event-plane correlations.

dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Search for new phenomena in events with three or more charged leptons in pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: A generic search for anomalous production of events with at least three charged leptons is presented. The data sample consists of pp collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 8$ TeV collected in 2012 by the ATLAS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider, and corresponds to an integrated luminosity of 20.3 fb$^{−1}$. Events are required to have at least three selected lepton candidates, at least two of which must be electrons or muons, while the third may be a hadronically decaying tau. Selected events are categorized based on their lepton flavour content and signal regions are constructed using several kinematic variables of interest. No significant deviations from Standard Model predictions are observed. Model-independent upper limits on contributions from beyond the Standard Model phenomena are provided for each signal region, along with prescription to re-interpret the limits for any model. Constraints are also placed on models predicting doubly charged Higgs bosons and excited leptons. For doubly charged Higgs bosons decaying to $e \tau$ or $\mu \tau$, lower limits on the mass are set at 400 GeV at 95% confidence level. For excited leptons, constraints are provided as functions of both the mass of the excited state and the compositeness scale $\Lambda$, with the strongest mass constraints arising in regions where the mass equals $\Lambda$. In such scenarios, lower mass limits are set at 3.0 TeV for excited electrons and muons, 2.5 TeV for excited taus, and 1.6 TeV for every excited-neutrino flavour.
dc:dc.invenio:conference.notes: Please enter your comments on CDS by Wednesday, April 29. This is draft 4 of this paper. The paper has passed public reading and has been submitted to JHEP. During journal review, problems were found that affect the results. dc:dc.dc:creator: ATLAS Collaboration
dc:dc.dc:title: Searches for Higgs boson pair production in the $hh\to bb\tau\tau, \gamma\gamma WW*, \gamma\gamma bb, bbbb$ channels with the ATLAS detector
dc:dc.dc:subject: Particle Physics - Experiment
dc:dc.dc:description: Searches for both resonant and non-resonant Higgs boson pair production are performed in the $hh\to bb\tau\tau, \gamma\gamma WW^*$ final states using 20.3 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV recorded with the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider. No evidence of their production is observed and 95\% confidence level upper limits on the production cross sections are set. These results are then combined with the published results of the $hh\to \gamma\gamma bb, bbbb$ analyses. An upper limit of 0.69 (0.47) pb on the non-resonant Standard Model like $hh$ production is observed (expected), corresponding to 70 (48) times of the SM $gg\to hh$ cross section. For production via narrow resonances, cross section limits of $hh$ production from a heavy Higgs boson decay are set as a function of the heavy Higgs boson mass. The observed (expected) limits range from 2.1 (1.1) pb at 260 GeV to 0.011 (0.018) pb at 1000 GeV. These results are interpreted in the context of two simplified scenarios of the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model.
